PETITION.TITLE: Port Hedland-Marble Bar Road
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. The Port Hedland/Marble Bar road is in terrible condition;
* As far back as the early 1950s the people of Marble Bar were promised an all weather road;
* The poor state of the gravel road is deterring tourists from seeing the many attractions in the Marble Bar area and causing untold damage to the town's economy.
Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure that funds are made available for the essential upgrading of this important road.
As in duty bound your petitions will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Leader and members of the Senate of Australia, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that the Governor of Victoria has set aside 219 hectares of Reserved Forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest to be the West Barham Big Trees Flora Reserve.
We humbly pray that you consider protecting a larger area of the Otways from logging by listing it as National Estate forest so that botanical, water and tourist values may be preserved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) welcomes the appeal by the Supreme Soviet of the USSR to the world's legislatures and public to take a clear position in favour of the general prohibition of nuclear testing;

(b) applauds the progress made by both the Soviet Union and the United States on the implementation of the Treaties on the Limitation of Underground Nuclear Weapons Tests, and on Underground Nuclear Explosions for Peaceful Purposes, the so-called Threshold Test Ban Treaty and Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty;
(c) considers that these two treaties should not be seen as the final objective of efforts to eliminate completely nuclear testing;

(d) urges that Australia should continue to take a leading role in advocating the early conclusion of a multilateral, verifiable and enforceable Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, banning nuclear testing in all environments for all time;
(e) deplores all nuclear tests wherever and by whomever they may be carried out, and calls on all countries to support a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty; and
(f) regrets, therefore, that on 24 October, two weeks after the Supreme Soviet's appeal, the USSR carried out an underground test, the first it has undertaken in 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the hearings of Estimates Committee A on 20 September 1990, Senator Bishop sought, through the Deputy President, Senator Colston, an undertaking from me in relation to the release of vision tapes of proceedings of the Senate which are held by the Sound and Vision Office.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Order of the Senate on 31 May 1990 laid down conditions governing the broadcasting of excerpts of proceedings by television stations. The Order is silent on the issue of access to vision tapes of proceedings by persons or organisations other than television stations.

Requests have been received from several honourable senators and from organisations other than television stations for access to these recordings of proceedings. The question of access to the vision tapes is a matter for the Senate to determine.

I propose to refer the matter to the Procedure Committee for report to the Senate and, until the Senate otherwise determines, vision tapes of proceedings will not be released to individuals or organisations other than television stations.
I remind all honourable senators that a recording of Question Time is replayed each day at 5.30 p.m. on channel 24 of the House monitoring system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, this Bill will amend the Child Support (Registration and Collection ) Act 1988, the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and the Family Law Act 1975 to give effect to some desirable improvements in the child support scheme and to update references in the Child Support legislation to the Family Law Act which was amended in 1989.

The Child Support scheme has now been operating for just over two years and in that time we have seen a substantial turnaround in the payment of maintenance for children who are living in single parent families. The collection of amounts payable under court orders has increased from around 30% prescheme to around 70% now and many more children can expect to benefit from the scheme as its coverage extends throughout the community.

The amendments in this Bill are minor but nevertheless important as they will free up certain restrictions that were included in the original Bills which, with the benefit of experience in the operation of the scheme, can now be relaxed.

The most important of the amendments is the one which will allow the Registrar to inform custodial parents of the progress of the recovery of amounts due to them and not fear any breach of the secrecy provisions. These people have a right to know what that position is and this amendment will ensure that can happen in future.

Another amendment is aimed at clarifying the position of counsellors employed by the Family Court in relation to the secrecy provisions of the child support legislation. In providing counselling in disputes over custody, access or child support, Family Court counsellors sometimes become aware of allegations of child abuse. If that counselling is provided pursuant to child support legislation, the secrecy provisions of that legislation may prevent the reporting of suspected abuse to child welfare authorities. This Bill will free counsellors from the secrecy obligations of the child support legislation and leave the issue of counsellors' obligations of confidentiality to be determined by the provisions of the Family Law Act.

The Bill will also amend the Family Law Act in two important ways to further complement the operation of the child support scheme. Section 66BA was inserted in the Family Law Act to coincide with the introduction of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 to limit the actions that can be taken in the courts for the ongoing support of children when support could and should be sought from the Child Support Agency by way of application of the administrative formula. In practice this provision has not stopped non custodians from seeking an order from the court to pay before the custodian has lodged an application for assessment. This amendment will stop all persons from being able to circumvent the intended provisions of the Child Support (Assessment) Act.

The other change to the Family Law Act will introduce a new condition under which a maintenance liability ordered by a court under the Family Law Act should cease. In the event that a custodian dies there is no provision for the Agency either in their own legislation or the Family Law Act to act in the best interests of the surviving children. The liability continues under the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act but the person to whom the money is to be paid is deceased. This Bill will amend the Family Law Act to end the specific liability under a court order where the person entitled to the maintenance is deceased and the order makes no provision for the continuation of payments.

Another change to be brought about by this Bill will remove the need for parties to private consent agreements and courts that make orders to depart from administrative assessments to state the amount of child support payable as an annual amount. This requirement was initially included to coincide with the annual outcomes of assessments made by the Agency but is out of touch with how child support is generally viewed by the community. As a result persons and courts will now be able to specify any periodicity in their agreements and orders and they will be acceptable to the Agency.

The remaining changes introduced in this Bill are all of a machinery nature and update references only in the child support legislation to the new enforcement provisions of the Family Law Act which were included in the Family Law Amendment Act 1989. They were not able to be introduced with that Bill at that time.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and examining the proposed expenditure for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The question is that the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I would like to take up the question of the introduction of the legislation which creates the Australian Sports Drug Agency as a statutory body and sets up its board. I think Senator Michael Baume put it properly when he said, in response to something else that was said, that while the functions are being performed in a very efficient and effective way now by Mr Haynes and his group, the legislation will reinforce in the minds of the public the commitment of the Government, the commitment of the Parliament and the commitment of the community to pursue the policy that has been thus far implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there has been a change in attitude. I agree with what Senator Richardson said last night, that there has been a change in perceptions. I suspect, and I do not say this in a disrespectful way, that perhaps some of the officials have been a bit slower than the athletes. I believe that there has been a change in ethos amongst athletes. I suspect it is unfair to criticise athletes who used drugs four, five or six years ago in the same way that one might criticise them for using them now. I think the social mores have changed; I think the ethos has changed; and I think people's attitudes generally right through all levels of sport have changed.

There is now a great focus on this issue. There is a greater understanding by athletes that taking performance enhancing drugs in fact is a form of cheating. Before it was seen more as an aid. Frankly, I think this is not only because community attitudes have changed. We have had the Ben Johnson example and other examples. We now have a much more effective-not absolute-drug testing regime.

Athletes are now more likely to be detected if they use drugs. But this regime will not be absolute until such time as we can create proper profiles of athletes. At the moment one will not catch them all because the job is just too big. One has to actually test athletes within 14 days of the use of steroids before one can be certain that one is going to catch them and that is an enormous task which is beyond the funding of any government. So, in some respects a change of ethos is required. Greater discipline will result because of the risk of being caught.

Having said that, in my moments of glumness I have a sense of despair when I see that some of the attitudes of some of the bodies have not changed. The International Amateur Athletics Federation (IAAF), for instance, chose in the Maurie Plant incident to hang its position simply on a legal argument that at the time Mr Plant solicited a urine sample from a young female Australian athlete for the purpose of allowing it to be substituted-or put crudely, to cheat-such action was not contrary to any International Olympic Committee (IOC) or Australian Olympic Federation (AOF) regulations and, therefore, technically there had been no breach.

The athlete, of course, as a scholarship holder at the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS), had to sign a code of conduct which not only applied in a technical sense to the laws but also imposed upon the athlete quite properly some moral standards. In my view, one cannot restrict oneself strictly to regulations in sporting competition of that nature. There are some moral encumbrances imposed upon athletes, officials and sporting bodies.

The IAAF argued quite properly a technical and legal point that there was no regulation. There was no regulation because it had not been conceived in the minds of officials that that was a way of cheating. The taxation Act is regularly changed because lawyers, accountants and tax cheats find new ways of avoiding tax or, in some cases, evading tax. New skills are being applied to those areas. So governments as they uncover these schemes and loopholes change the laws to accommodate them.

When it was discovered that urine substitution was a form being used to avoid detection for positive samples, the laws were changed. But it has become even more sophisticated than that, as we know. It is not simply the substitution of the sample. As we now know, there has been a system whereby some athletes with empty bladders have had injected into their bladder somebody else's urine, which we might find absolutely horrific and bizarre, but that is the extent to which athletes will go to win. It is not without significance to note that in one of the surveys that a number of Olympic athletes around the world, not Australians, were asked the question, `If it meant winning a gold medal, would you risk your life by taking a performance enhancing drug?'. Without exception, the answer was yes. That is how important winning is. When one understands the involvement and commitment that athletes make to their endeavours, perhaps one can understand it, though none of us would agree with it.

I find it a bit reprehensible that the IAAF says, `Because technically Mr Plant did nothing wrong, we do not propose to scold him, to criticise him, to disengage him or to quarantine him from young athletes who might in future be subject to his seductive skills at extracting samples from athletes'. That is why from time to time I wonder at what pace those reforms are taking place.

I make no secret of the fact that the history of Mr Nebiolo is one, in my view, that has not necessarily been covered with glory. One has only to remember the activities in 1972 and 1973 in Rome when a competition was held up for an hour because their athlete had been disqualified for breaking twice. Ask Raylene Boyle about the pain of that. They invaded the track and had to be taken away by police. Then we had the incident at the world championships in Rome where, after much procrastination and cover-up, it was discovered that Rome officials were caught cheating in the long jump; they just extended the tape a bit. They are senior officials in the IAAF in world athletics. It was not without significance to those with some knowledge of these things that there was a general view that the Olympic Games should not go to Greece because they were seen as part of the Mediterranean mafia in sport. There is an area in sport that very respectable people still see as tainted because it has not cleaned up its act. Comments have been made in respect of the Dubin report. Although an enormous amount of work was done in that inquiry, it does not seem to have fundamentally changed the ethos and the attitude of the IAAF towards sport.

This leads me to ask Senator Richardson whether, in the event-and I know that we will do so subject to the sighting of the legislation-the Government will give a commitment to introduce the Bill and to have it passed so that it is on the statute books at the end of this session as a statement of commitment by the Parliament and the Government as to their attitude towards sport. Subject to the Bill being sighted, if it has enshrined in it those principles, which I understand to be the case, it will have a speedy, rapid and smooth passage from our side of politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before responding to Senator Crichton-Browne, I would like to raise two matters that arose yesterday. One was from Senator Michael Baume and the other from Senator Crichton-Browne and I might lead off with some clarification.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of positive tests in powerlifting, the last positive test for the so-called Drug Free Powerlifting Association (DFPA) was June 1990, and the last test for the Australian powerlifting group which was positive was in July. So it will be difficult to distinguish which will seek to claim the perfect record, because the record does not look too flash.

Senator Crichton-Browne also made some comments about the Australian Weightlifting Federation. I said that I understood that the Weightlifting Federation had notified acceptance, but I was not sure whether we had yet received a letter. I am now advised that we have received that formal acceptance of the Australian Sports Commission's grant to the Weightlifting Federation. A quotation from its letter said, `. . . under the conditions specified in the ASC letter'. That includes adherence to the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) doping policy. I understand that the Weightlifting Federation is currently reviewing its own doping policy to ensure that the administration and the administrative arrangements that go with it comply with ASC requirements. It is, I am told, working closely with the ASC to achieve this.

In response to the comments made by Senator Crichton-Browne, certainly I would agree that we will need to keep ahead of the game if we are to ensure that our testing program means anything. There is no doubt that clever chemists and doctors will spend a great deal of time and money making sure that they invent newer, better, harder-to-detect drugs. We will have to make sure that Mr Haines's outfit is equipped with the capabilities to keep up with those developments and, hopefully, keep ahead of them.

I do not believe that we will ever get a perfect system; I do not think that will be possible. I would not want to set the Australian Sports Drugs Agency that kind of task. But so far as it is possible we will eliminate the use of drugs through this testing program. It is worth noting that, even if steroids were to go through the body in 14 days, some athletes will still be caught, and that will be the sanction, because athletes will not know who will be tested when. Of course, there is only a few hours notice for tests, so athletes who have been involved in taking them will get caught. They will not all get caught perhaps but the random nature of the tests-no one knows when the axe will fall-will act as a very strong deterrent or at least I hope so.

Last night in response to Senator Michael Baume I said that whether legislation goes through or not, the testing program will continue. But I agree with Senator Crichton-Browne's basic point that legislative force will help. Even before Senate committee reports and all the rest of it, I was urging that we should have the Drug Agency and its procedures subject to legislation so that the Parliament would have an oversight of its role. I cannot speak on behalf of the Government; I am but a humble Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are half right.

—I am completely right in that respect and I am subject to all sorts of accusations from some colleagues, I might say, according to the papers this morning. Senator Faulkner disputes the account that Mr Gayler has given; he does not accept it for a second.
—Do you mean to say you are not a political thug?

—Absolutely not; butter would not melt. While I cannot speak on behalf of the Government, I will undertake to have the Parliamentary Business Committee have another look at it on the basis that Senator Crichton-Browne is saying that it can be guaranteed speedy passage. I will go back to my colleagues and attempt to persuade them.
—That is subject to sighting it?

—Obviously, but I do not think that we have anything up our sleeve in respect of this legislation. Senator Crichton-Browne knows as well as I do what is in it. At least I do not think that we have anything up our sleeve. I will go back to the Parliamentary Business Committee and endeavour to persuade it to put it back on the list. If I get out of here today, I shall try to do it today but, if not, tomorrow morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was pleased to receive the advice from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) about the weightlifters. I do not want to labour the point, but these things must be on the record. The Minister said last night, and I understand the reason for his response, that he had no knowledge of positive tests in weightlifting that had not been reported, or words roughly to that effect. May I refer the Minister to a letter signed by Bruce Walsh, the Executive Director of the Australian Weightlifting Federation who wrote to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Further to my recent telephone conversation with yourself at 6.30pm on the 2nd April, I make the following submission to be taken as given in camera and under parliamentary privilege accorded to the Senate Inquiry into Drugs in Sport:

It has been recently brought to my attention that your Committee has made written inquiries to Mr. Sam Coffa concerning Nick Voukelatos and his withdrawal from the 1984 Olympic Games weightlifting team. I have not been consulted about the contents of Mr. Coffa's reply and, as I was involved in the matter, I wish to outline my knowledge of the situation -

After the selection of the weightlifting team to contest the 1984 Olympic Games, Nick Voukelatos was requested by the Australian Olympic Federation to submit to drug testing. As a result of this request I was contacted by Mr. Sam Coffa by telephone informing me that Voukelatos had appeared before Dr. Bill Webb or Dr. Brian Corrigan (I am not sure which one) and had informed the doctor that he would not be taking the test as he had been using anabolic steroids. I asked S. Coffa who had informed him of this information and was told that the source was a person from the A.O.F. He also requested me to contact Voukelatos and tell him to withdraw from the team due to injury or face the prospect of suspension. Shortly after I contacted Voukelatos. He was in a distraught state, alleging that he was affected by alcohol at the time of his admission to the A.O.F. doctor. I informed Voukelatos of S. Coffa's request-
that is, that he withdraw-
and he subsequently withdrew from the team with an injured shoulder. My actions were as a result of a direction by my employer.

The employer was Mr Coffa. The doctor in question was Dr Fitch from Western Australia. I do not read that letter out to score any points but simply to show that there have been major problems with weightlifting in Australia and they have sadly been ignored by the administration for a very long time, and the Coffas particularly. As I say, the letter was signed by Mr Bruce Walsh, the Executive Director of the Australian Weightlifting Federation Inc. It shows that there have been very serious problems. My concern is that, while that was in 1984, the same administration is in place and nothing in its attitude has changed. What has changed is that the athletes will now be subject to random testing in and out of contest times and, if that is no inhibition on the use of drugs, I would be very surprised. I thank Senator Richardson for the commitment he made in respect to the legislation because I think it would be a very useful step for all of us. I want to touch quickly on a few more points. The Minister mentioned last night that I had had a few problems with one particular group of administrators who were new and inexperienced but vastly better than the last administrators. That is absolutely right; there have been some difficulties. I put it down to inexperience, which demonstrated itself during the period immediately prior to the Commonwealth Games in Auckland. I have sought not to be critical of them. I just hope that they understand that when I ask questions I am not being nosy or interfering, but simply need the facts. When I get correspondence back telling me that as far as they are concerned the matter is closed, that is not a satisfactory answer. As far as I am concerned, it is not closed. As long as they are getting hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, I think they have some responsibility to accommodate the requests that are made of them.

I have pursued very briefly the imbroglio last night as to which documents should or should not be tabled. I am no clearer now as to what the honourable senator was saying than I was last night. All I can say for the record is that the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts has a resolution which made the documents public; I did not. They are matters that have already been made public. That is the reason I was quite lost about the whole matter. Honourable senators will notice that I did not even bother to read the letters out. I would have been happy if they were not tabled. Just for the record, there is no doubt as to the status of the documents or the conduct of tabling them.

I seek leave to table a document dated 22 August 1989, which I referred to last night, from Jeanette Brown, the Acting General Manager of the Australian Athletics Union. It sets out the only action taken by Athletics Australia in respect of the urine substitution incident so that it is on the record that, regrettably, during that time Athletics Australia did absolutely nothing about the particular matter in question. Mr Chairman, with your indulgence, I also seek leave to table a letter to me from the President of Athletics Australia Inc. and my response, which was simply just to remind it that there are further matters to be taken up from time to time.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one other matter. I made mention last night of a concern I had about pressure being put on members of the Confederation of Australian Sport. I mentioned that the name of one body had been given to me as having been spoken to with Athletics Australia. I should make it clear that that information did not come from Athletics Australia or anybody associated with it, to my memory. I mention that particularly because there is no point in me saying less than I know if I am to impart to the Minister information which gives him the opportunity to take the matter up. I will not seek leave to table that letter because I do not think it is particularly helpful. It mentions one particular official's name. It is an anonymous letter and I think it would be in terribly poor taste to be producing a document with that characteristic.

SPEECH.PARA: I will conclude on two matters. Firstly, I ask the Minister: What is the status of progress in respect of getting a clear definition of prohibited drugs? For instance, beta-blockers are banned, but valium, for instance, which has exactly the same effect, is not banned; it is not on the prohibited list. A pistol shooter or an archery contestant, whatever they are--

TALK.START.PARA: —An archer.
—That is right. I am still getting used to the word `fisher'. I would be interested to know what mechanisms are in place now so that there is some rationale as to the list of proscribed substances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the last point raised by Senator Crichton-Browne, as far as I know, we totally rely on the International Olympic Commission (IOC) for this. I am not certain of the procedures which it adopts, but I understand that the list is under constant review. We have just accepted its list.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pretty difficult for us to undertake the same task, particularly when what we are about is equality among athletes and making sure that no-one has an advantage. So we really have to try to have the same list applied around the world. We are not trying to change the IOC's list at all; we are happy to abide by it.

I will comment on some of the matters that Senator Crichton-Browne raised on weightlifting and the incident in 1984. I have a couple of things to say about that. Firstly, 1984 was a long time ago. As we have acknowledged, the culture has changed dramatically since then. Part of the statement that I made earlier about weightlifting concerned the administrative body ensuring that its own policy and the administrative arrangements for that policy accord with the requirements of the Australian Sports Commission (ASC). It is not just abiding by an ASC policy; it is changing its own policies to fit in with it. I am not sure that there is much more we can ask of it.

The Australian Institute of Sport and the Sports Commission are still reviewing weightlifting's participation in their programs because it was suspended after allegations were made. I am aware of the letter that Senator Crichton-Browne has quoted from, but that is the view of one person and I do not know how Mr Coffa would respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —He refused to.

—I am saying that I do not know how he would respond to those specifics if he were to give an answer. I am always reluctant to conclude that any one version is necessarily correct until I have heard the other. But I daresay that over time we will all get an explanation for that event. Nonetheless, I think we ought to be more concerned about arrangements for 1994 than those for 1984 and I want to make sure that, if weightlifting is back in the fold, it is back in the fold with the right doping policies.

—As in one other sport, if the same personalities were not still there with the same mindset that I have seen, I would not have raised the matter. That is the only relevance to 1984. My question about the International Olympic Committee (IOC) list relates to the fact that presumably members of the Australian Olympic Federation (AOF) make a contribution to those deliberations. If I am not wrong, Dr Fitch is a member of the medical commission of the IOC. That is something Australia can make a contribution towards. There are two types of drugs that can have the same effect but only one is banned. They are the sorts of things that can help ensure there is an even playing field for everybody.

—I would not seek to mislead. We make a contribution. We tell the IOC what we think of various drugs. We do not seek to duplicate its arrangements but we are constantly telling that body what we think and aggressively putting our view via Dr Fitch.

—I promise to conclude after I raise two further matters. Would it be convenient for the correspondence between Athletics Australia and the International Amateur Athletic Federation in respect of Mr Plant to be made available to me? Further, would the Australian Sports Commission care--
—I do not think we have it.
—My endeavours thus far have failed. I wonder whether the Minister might persuade that body. I do not think it is any matter of great secrecy.
—I want to be clear what I am inquiring about. Is Senator Crichton-Browne talking about correspondence between Mr Plant and the international body or the Australian body?
—The Australian body and the international body.
—I am happy to ask for that but I do not think that I can require those bodies to do so. But I will ask.

—Their response in this respect will give me some indication of whether they have moved into the new world. I also wonder whether the Australian Sports Commission at a later time might like to express a view as to whether Mr Plant is a suitable official to have immediate and direct communication with young Australian scholarship holders who are travelling overseas, who are on the grand prix circuit and who will continue to be subject to some influence from Mr Plant. Mr Plant is able to decide whether they go into competition.

—There are a couple of points to respond to. In normal circumstances, if the incident involving Mr Plant had occurred last week he would have received a two-year ban. Had the rules been in place at the time when this incident occurred, Mr Plant would be back in business now. Ben Johnson is about to run against Carl Lewis again. Ben Johnson got caught red-handed.
—He only got caught doping himself, nobody else.

—Even so, I think Senator Crichton-Browne would agree that Mr Plant probably would have been banned for only two years, so he would be back in business. I am happy to ask the ASC for its view on this point. We do not instruct the ASC. So, I am not going to tell it what its view ought to be. But I am happy to ask it for a view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will conclude on this note: one of the areas that has not yet properly been addressed by Australian society, sporting officials or the Australian Sports Commission and other bodies is the part recreational and social drugs play in the world of sport. I remember some part of the debate that took place when 10 rugby players were detected as having used marijuana. A very good argument can be mounted that it is inappropriate that athletes be tested for those drugs because they are not performance enhancing; they are drugs that relate to the personal performance of the athlete at the lower standard. In some cases these drugs are not on a ban list. In my view this issue has to be addressed by Australian society which, invariably in these matters, is led by governments and sporting officials who ultimately arrive at a conclusion as to whether consideration should be given to putting the drugs on a ban list.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a dilemma because arguments can be put on both sides in terms of one's privacy and whether those sorts of drugs ought to be included. Alcohol, for instance, would fit into the same category. Should people be tested for alcohol when they are engaged in sports where alcohol is of absolutely no use? It is a dilemma for a sport for a number of reasons. I do not think it is a debate that has yet been addressed properly and a resolution has not begun to be developed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The controversy in which rugby league found itself over the issue of testing for marijuana has done a lot to put the issue up in lights around Australia. Obviously, if we go back to that argument, within rugby league some fairly divergent opinions were expressed by a number of people. I hope that we can expand the debate and talk to all the sporting associations about their attitude. As I said, we are not testing for marijuana as a matter of course but only when requested to by an association. We ought to talk to associations about that. I am sure it will be done.

SPEECH.PARA: For what it is worth, my own view is that if we are going to kick off debates we may as well get some views on the table. I agree with the testing for marijuana. It is not performance enhancing; it is the opposite. The problem is that, if an organisation lays out lots of money to athletes-and it is not the case that one looks only at professional sports and says, `South Sydney will be interested because it is paying the player $80,000 a season'-and if the Government is giving thousands of dollars to individual athletes, they are entitled to believe that the athletes are doing their best. There is a fair bit of evidence that the athletes will not be if they are taking marijuana. As long as we are going to kick off a debate, my view will be that we ought to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —From minor premiers to bottom.
—South Sydney won only one game; that is fair evidence. I would be certainly saying that we ought to be testing for it.
—That concludes the matters for examination under the areas of sport and recreation. Using the strategy that we decided upon yesterday, we will now move onto Antarctica.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise some matters on Antarctica under the general reservation made in respect of Senator Michael Baume. Initially, I shall refer to questions that my colleagues Senator Baume and Senator Archer raised. As honourable senators would know, I was not in Australia at the time matters concerning the Antarctica were considered. I would like some answers to some questions.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that at a late hour last night the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) pointed out how patient he had been in respect of the previous matters that had been raised. I can tell him that the patience also extends to this side of the chamber. On more than one occasion I have had the pleasure of listening to my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne, who certainly enlightened me about the drugs in sport issue.

As the Minister and his minders would probably know, I have for some time been pursuing some matters regarding the Antarctic supply vessel Aurora Australis. I preface my remarks by quoting from the mythical Sir Humphrey Appleby, who said that it is the Opposition's job to ask awkward questions and the Government's job not to answer them. The Government has answered quite a few questions but it has not done so to my satisfaction. This has been reinforced--

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor your colleagues'.

—Yes. This has been reinforced by the report of the Auditor-General entitled Antarctic Supply Vessel-chartering arrangements tabled in the Senate on Monday or Tuesday of this week. The Australian National Audit Office has raised some queries about some of the matters that occurred in respect of the contract. On 11 September Senator Baume asked a question about the extra amount being paid as against the original accepted price. He also asked whether it had changed much from the last time we had talked about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I have asked similar questions to this and I have been given various reasons. I refer to part 4 of the Auditor-General's report where he noted matters affecting time charter negotiations. As I said, I read the report by the National Audit Office on the negotiation of the charter for the Aurora Australis. I think it is fair to say that this charter increased the payment to P and O by the Commonwealth, by my estimations-on today's prices anyway-by $25m above its tender offer. It is clear from the Audit Office report that the responsible department, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has concealed critical facts from the Audit Office and the Attorney-General's Department, just as the previous Minister-Senator Richardson-and the Department have consistently concealed the facts from the Parliament. I refer to part 4.1 of the Auditor-General's report:
The audit disclosed that the negotiations over the time charter for the vessel were affected by-
the Auditor-General mentioned some negotiating power and the letter of intent-
the lack of a firm time charter on which the short-listed companies could base their bids.

Quite frankly, that is nonsense. A sample time charter was given to all the short-listed bidders but the final charter was far more favourable to P and O than the sample. This should have reduced the price to the Commonwealth, not increased it. Would Senator Richardson care to comment on that?

TALK.START.PARA: —The hire costs for 1990-91 are $11.1m. There will be an additional cost of $27,000 for the engagement of an ice pilot. If the vessel is not chartered for some other purpose during the off-season, the Commonwealth will be up for $164,000 for the part year between completion of the 1990-91 season and 30 June 1991. Those layout costs have been known right through. I cannot say I have read the Auditor-General's report to which Senator Calvert refers, but going back three or four years when this was all occurring, protracted negotiations went on and on with P and O. The Commonwealth did the very best it could. There were some design changes to enhance the vessel which meant, of course, a change in the cost. This was inevitable. If we seek to have some improvements, we have to pay for them. So there is a difference between what we originally calculated and the final payment. But none of that should come as a shock or a surprise. There was a quite normal period of difficult negotiation. Whenever millions of dollars are involved, both sides will accuse each other of all sorts of horrors during the negotiations. There is no question that P and O considers itself hard done by. Whether it was or not is something for history to judge. But, looking back on it, I cannot see any part of the negotiating process that I would seek to change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: -I reiterate what I said earlier: there were certainly some differences in this particular charter arrangement with what happened before. I will refer later to the letter of intent, which was quite unusual. The fact that it was made known to the charterers 10 months before the contract was signed certainly had financial disadvantages for Australia. This was raised in the Auditor-General's report too.

SPEECH.PARA: Another reason put forward by the Department for the haste in the way this particular charter was carried out was that the ship was required for the 1989-90 season and therefore certain things were done which contributed to the rather large increase in costs. I would contend that the new ship was to be a big improvement over previous vessels and was also more costly. But there was no need for the ship to be ready for the 1989-90 season because the Department could have readily hired a cheaper ship. In fact, it had to do so because of the delay.

I put it to the Minister that, in the final analysis, the reason given for dramatically increasing the long term costs of the new ship being due to the time charter arrangements or the fact that it was needed in a hurry for the 1989-90 season is not a valid one. It had been planned for something like 10 years. Using those two reasons as an excuse for allowing the Commonwealth to be put in a position where it had to pay a quite large increase in the final costs by these unusual circumstances is not sufficient. It is rather irregular, to say the least.

We know that the Australian Government Solicitor warned about this letter of intent. I know that the Minister is well aware of the letter of intent because I have raised this matter many times. I think that even one of his former ministerial colleagues, Senator Walsh, said, when he was chairing one of the Estimates committee meetings, that he found it rather unusual himself. The Australian Government Solicitor did warn the Department that this letter of intent could cause a problem and could prejudice the Commonwealth's position. But the Department then said it needed to give P and O the letter of intent so that it could take advantage of the 20 per cent shipbuilding bounty.

I contend that this is not true also because in the letter of intent P and O had already advised the Department that it had arranged that, if selected for the final negotiations, it would arrange that sufficient work would be done to qualify for the 20 per cent bounty. I have some reference documents and I will explain that in greater detail later.

The Department also stated that the approach it took was a result of its desire to have the vessel in service as soon as possible. That is also mentioned under 6.4 of the Auditor-General's report when, in his conclusions, he said:
The approach taken by the Department was in part a result of the desire to have the vessel built and available for service as soon as possible.

As I said earlier, and I will say it again, this is not true of the Department's approach. The Department originally had a plan which would have ensured a good ship in a reasonable time at the originally tendered price. But, under Senator Richardson's guidance, this plan was thrown out the window and the P and O plan was substituted, as the Minister would be well aware. P and O wrote the letter of intent in a way that was favourable to it and the Department signed it. From that point on, the Commonwealth had no legal legs to stand on. As predicted by the Australian Government Solicitor, and despite his office's best efforts to protect the Commonwealth, P and O led the way and took us to the cleaners.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just plain nonsense. I will lose patience with that; it is stupid.
—The Minister has already admitted that something like $1m per year over 10 years has been paid, which is at least $10m, just on the original bid, plus all the extras.
—That is for a different design. It was enhanced. Acknowledge that at least. Even you can wake up to that.

—As I said earlier, the bidding process for the ship was simply to establish the most competitive bidder. Surely the Minister would agree with that. This was all explained, as he would remember, in the tendering process document which was tabled in Parliament on 20 October 1988. I quote from that document:

SPEECH.PARA: ANTDIV had intended to follow usual commercial practice and resolve qualifications in the preferred bidder's offer later, during the charter party negotiation...

That was in that great thick pink document tabled on 20 October 1988. It is not possible to resolve all points of the short-listed proposals, some of which are ambit bids outside the genuine negotiation process, but this plan was ruined by the signing of that letter of intent.
I get back to the point I raised earlier. I quote part of an answer that was given about the letter of intent:
To get the bounty that was involved the company concerned felt that it had to have a letter of intent.

The Minister has agreed with that. Almost immediately after the Government decision was announced, the Deputy Director of the Antarctic Division, with the Minister's approval, signed the letter of intent. I think that Mr Tierney actually gave the approval. This letter of intent states:

This letter is provided to enable P &O-Polar to act immediately, prior to the completion of the negotiation of the charter, to place an order for the construction of a vessel appropriate for the charter with an Australian shipyard so that construction of the vessel can commence before 31 December, 1987.

Unfortunately, that is not mentioned in the Auditor-General's report. As I said earlier, this letter was issued despite warnings from the Australian Government Solicitor. It certainly prejudices the Commonwealth's position. I quote the two reasons stated under paragraph 4.5 of the audit report:
1. A condition of the P &O Polar proposal was that P &O had to be able to enter into a contract for the construction of the vessel-
which I have just quoted from the letter of intent-

prior to 31 December 1987. This arrangement was designed to enable the ship builders to qualify for a bounty under the Ship Building Bounty Act 1982 which was only available at a particular rate until the end of December 1987. The availability of the bounty was taken into account in the tender price submitted by P &O Polar.

I do not believe that that reason is correct. In a memorandum of 20 August 1988 to the Deputy Director of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Director of Antarctic Division states:

Mr Alistair Baillie of P &O-Polar had advised that the Shipbuilding Bounty of 20% would apply, as it was their intention, if they were selected for the final negotiations, to instruct a shipyard to commence the building of a ``Bounty'' section (e.g. a standard type tank section) before . . . 1987. He pointed out that, even if we were un- able to agree on a contract, the cost of starting a section of a vessel, less the residual value of the section, was relatively small compared to the amount they had already invested in the project.

This information was also given to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I put it to the Minister that the reason why the answer was given to Senator Michael Baume on 11 September and the reason the Minister has acknowledged that this letter of intent was sent was certainly not that it was necessary to get that bounty, because the Minister already had Mr Baillie from P and O saying that it would build a section to qualify. Why was the letter of intent signed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — I must say at the start that I get a bit tired of answering the same questions time and time again. We have been up and down this charter many times. As each new senator and each new shadow Minister comes on, away we go. Everyone will be cleverer than the last person and find out something dastardly, except no-one does.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is quite simple. I indicated that I wanted an Australian built and an Australian crewed ship. Given the fantastic result, I am glad that I did. If an overseas yard had been selected, the whole bounty question would not have arisen and we would not be having this discussion. But all of the tenderers who wanted to build in an Australian yard wanted to get the 20 per cent bounty. To get the 20 per cent bounty they had to place an order with an Australian shipyard and they had to get under way with construction. For them to do that, they needed a letter of intent. The Australian Government's legal advice was, `We wish you did not have to do it but we understand that you do'. In fact, the letter of intent was vetted by the advisers and included phrases composed by them. I would have thought that the correspondence Senator Calvert read concerning Alistair Baillie would have borne out the necessity for it.

Senator Calvert talked about other tenderers not getting the same go as P and O. We selected P and O. That could not have been kept as some sort of secret. We could not have embarked on negotiations with three or four tenderers just so that P and O did not know that we had selected it. That is just ridiculous. We were anxious to get under way. Australia had spent all of those years hiring foreign ships. We were sick of it. We wanted an Australian ship. We were anxious to start. When I became the Minister and got hold of that process, I wanted it to be conducted as speedily as possible. We finally went forward with the recommendation to P and O. It then had to sit down with shipyards and negotiate which yard it would be. As Senator Calvert is aware, in the end there was quite a contest between a couple of yards for that right. But to get the bounty, they needed the letter of intent. The Australian Government legal advisers understood that that had to be done and had a hand in vetting it. They wished it did not have to be done; so did we all. But if we wanted the ship, we had to have the bounty.

What has to be looked at is what is not said in the Auditor-General's report. What would have happened if P and O had not got the bounty? The price of the ship would have gone up dramatically. I would have gone back to Cabinet saying, `There's X million dollars here that you have to give me to make up for the loss of the bounty'. We are not talking about a win-win situation. That is not possible. It was a case of saying, `If they don't get the bounty, I am going to need extra money. We may as well get them the bounty and so we'll facilitate it'. The idea that the Department wrote some favourable letter to give P and O some sort of advantage in negotiations with the Commonwealth does not even bear commenting on; it is just too stupid.

TALK.START.PARA: -I have already said that P and O would have built a tank section to allow for that bounty payment.
—They had to enter into a contract.

—The contract was not signed until 10 months afterwards. Was the letter of intent as good as a contract? All the way through I have been trying to point out that because this letter of intent was given, and P and O knew it would get the job, it took 10 months to sign the original final charter. All these other specification changes which cost money came in. Does the Minister agree with that?
—Absolutely. Thank God we did.

—I put to the Minister the following hypothetical questions: What if the Government had not given P and O a letter of intent? What would have happened if negotiations had proceeded as originally planned? If that had happened, would P and O not have had someone competing with it? The second bidder could have been reverted to if need be. The only reason that the Minister has given me for rushing into the P and O offer was that he wanted to get the 20 per cent bounty.
—That is a pretty good reason.

—The Minister says that that is a pretty good reason, but I have just pointed out that Mr Baillie in his letter said that his company would have built a tank section anyway. So there was no need to rush into it.
—You ought to read the letter again. You don't even understand the letter.
—We will go one step further. If things had proceeded as originally planned, would that bounty have carried over for another year?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I had said that I would not give P and O this letter of intent and that we would go back to another tenderer, the other tenderer who wanted to build at an Australian yard would have wanted the bounty and would have asked for a letter of intent. After I had told the second tenderer that I would not give it to him and had told the fourth, the fifth and the thirty-third, I would then have started the tender process again and we still would not have a ship. That is just not possible. Senator Calvert has to understand that there is a difference between our signing a contract with P and O, and P and O having a contract with a shipyard that is necessary for a bounty. That is where the honourable senator has made his error.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we have gone up and down this track so many times that it is well worn. I have nothing to add now to the answers that I have given on the same points in numerous Estimates Committee hearings and in the Committee of the Whole over the last three years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: -If everything was in order why did the Auditor-General put down this special report on the matter?
—Recommending different procedures for the future.
—As Senator Baume said, and as I was just about to say, the Auditor-General recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in future cases of a similar nature, the Commonwealth's position would be strengthened if:
. proposals were based on a firm, approved time charter document-
as I pointed out earlier-
the specifications are settled prior to any final decision-
and that is not to mention-
. the implications of any assumptions included in a proposal are explored and clarified before the Government's final consideration, decision and announcement.

The Auditor-General has drawn to the attention of the Parliament his misgivings about this whole thing. On the one hand, the Minister is saying that there is nothing wrong with what happened, but on the other hand the Australian National Audit Office is saying that there were certainly some irregularities in the whole process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the suggestion is that we should negotiate all of the specifications with all the tenderers before making a final decision, we will never make a decision. I reject that out of hand and, if that puts me at odds with the Auditor-General, I will have to live with it. One simply could not do that. That is an impossible task to set anyone. The timing of decisions for bounties was not a timing of my choosing; it was just something that we had to live with.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already acknowledged that the Australian Government legal advisers would have preferred that we not proceed in this way. I have already acknowledged that we would have preferred not to have gone this way, either. Just as the Australian legal advisers agreed with us that we did not have a choice, we had to proceed. We proceeded to have changes in specifications. That is quite normal. God knows how many Defence contracts have gone through over the years where one has improved; that is the normal thing that happens in negotiations. As I said, as improvements occur we pay for them. We certainly did pay for them, but we have a better ship than we would have had otherwise.

If this whole matter rests on the bounty or the way in which we handled this issue in respect of the bounty, all I can say is that we would have gone back to other tenderers who had the same problem and we would have finished up not having a ship. Probably, we would have got around it by saying, `Okay, you can build it in a foreign yard'. I put to the Cabinet that that was just not on.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have cost about half as much.
—It would not have cost half as much. Senator Calvert does not seem to grasp things very quickly.
—Don't start that.
—Senator Walters is the champion of grasping things slowly, or not grasping them at all.
—The Auditor-General has grasped you.
—The Auditor-General has definitely grasped you.
—He has grasped me?
—Very firmly. Your heart and mind will follow.

—It will be a while. I have to say that, in looking back after all this time, if we had proceeded to build at another yard that was overseas and if Australians had not got this work, I do not believe Australia would be thankful to us at all. Australian shipbuilding got from the work a new skill that will serve us in good stead for decades to come and I am more than happy with that. I think the trend to believe that everything will be solved by going overseas is wrong. I still have faith in Australian industry and I would like to see more work such as this done in Australia. It must be remembered that one would have had to add to the costs of all the unsuccessful tenderers the cost of what would have happened if they too had had to go through the enhancement process that we went through in negotiations. That is not being done again, but that is because there is a predisposition not to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Audit Office has acknowledged that it is difficult to gauge the extent to which the issue of the letter of intent caused difficulties for the Commonwealth over and above that which might normally be expected in the negotiation of a charter of this kind. So the Auditor-General himself has acknowledged the difficulties involved in this. It is not simply a matter of criticising; he has acknowledged how difficult the process is. I do not think one would ever get through this kind of process without some sort of criticism. Having said that, I do not believe the Commonwealth's position has been compromised by a dollar as a result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: -For the record, I think Reiber's-that is one of the overseas shipyards-offer was $82m for 10 years and P and O's offer was $124m for ten years. So there would have been quite a substantial saving if the ship had been built overseas. As I have said before, it certainly was good for Australia for it to be built here, but my main argument is that, because of the way the contract was written and because of the delay in writing the contract, that $124m increased quite significantly. In his last answer the Minister mentioned the specification changes and the Auditor-General draws attention to those in paragraph 4.17 of his report:

SPEECH.PARA: Another factor which contributed to the protracted negotiations was the decision by the Antarctic Division, within the scope of the Government's decision, to seek changes to the original specifications.

I thought the Government's decision was that no specification changes should be made which would substantially increase the cost of the ship. In fact, the cost of the specifications was expected to be $200,000 per annum-that was back in 1988-but ended up becoming $450,000 per annum by April 1988. Would the Minister like to comment on why the Government changed its original decision that there be no specification changes that would substantially increase the cost of the ship when, in fact, the cost was increased by some $450,000 per year?

TALK.START.PARA: —This comes back to the honourable senator's definition of `substantial'. Is hundreds of thousands of dollars `substantial' in a contract that is worth millions of dollars? It then depends on what one got for those hundreds of thousands. The value judgment is: how great is the enhancement, at what cost? The enhancement was very significant and the Commonwealth believed then, and believes now, that the enhancements were achieved at a very good price. We got a lot of enhancement for hundreds of thousands of dollars, and we made the value judgment then-I do not think hindsight changes it-that it was therefore a worthwhile deal.

- The Government did say originally that it would not agree to any substantial specification changes that would increase the cost of the ship. The Minister is saying that, with hindsight, or during the negotiations, the Government changed its mind. Is that correct?

—No, I did not say that. What occurs when anything is being built-from an Antarctic ship to a submarine, a frigate or a tank-is that in getting down to the final negotiations one seeks to get the very best product. There is a general tender and when it gets down to the details one tries to get every bit of enhancement one can. The Government sat down, as it always does in those kinds of negotiations, to get the enhancements it thought appropriate. We managed to get them and that is why we have got a first-class ship which will stand its ground with other ships of its kind built anywhere in the world.

-I am pleased to hear the Minister say it is a first-class ship. I asked him a question last week about its performance at the moment. While I have not got the answer here because I do not have the Hansard, I think the Minister said that the breakdown in the coupling between the two engines has not retarded its progress and, in fact, the ship will arrive back earlier than expected. I would like to ask a couple of questions about that. I think the Minister said in his answer that the two engines were the same size. However, I think one is smaller than the other.
—I didn't say they were the same size.

—Given the fact that the ship is operating on one engine-and I think the Minister said yesterday that it was carrying spares far in excess of the necessity by classification-was it carrying a spare of the coupling that broke?

—Redundancy is built in for this. I do not think it had a spare coupling on board-it does not because it has the other engine. I did not say that the loss of the engine had not retarded its progress. What I said was that it had been doing so well that it was still two days ahead of its schedule in spite of the difficulty that this had caused. I would have thought this proved how well we have done. There has been a breakdown and the ship is still ahead of schedule because of the arrangements that we made and the design features of the ship. I think one really finds out how good something is if it breaks down and can still perform. Obviously, the right thing was done in the negotiations and I congratulate the Antarctic Division on having done so.
-What would happen if the other motor broke down?
—What would happen if the roof fell in?

—No, I am serious. Given the amount of equipment that was taken down there-the Minister said that there was not a spare coupling-if there were problems with the smaller motor, what would happen then? Regarding the point the Minister made about the ship arriving back two days ahead of schedule, I am quite sure that, if both motors were working, the ship would probably have arrived back a lot earlier and would have cost this country a lot less.

—Even if both motors broke down, we have retractable axial thrusters and they would get the ship home. I must confess that I did not know about these thrusters until a few seconds ago but it just shows again how good these negotiators were.
—What are they?

—I knew that Senator Peter Baume was the sort of person who would ask that question. I will get a very detailed, scientific specification of these thrusters and have it provided to him as soon as possible. I know that he is fascinated about these thrusters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: -During the hearings of Estimates Committee C Senator Archer asked a question regarding the research voyage-the shake-down cruise, or whatever one likes to call it-to Heard Island. Senator Archer asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What was the purpose of it? Was it purely and simply just a running-in voyage, or did you do some work as well?
I think the answer he received from Mr Moncur was as follows:
It was primarily a research voyage. It was a research program that we needed to do and we got some good results from it.
I would like to know what the cost of that voyage was. Mr Moncur said that the Department got good results from it. What were those results worth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have provided these costs to the Estimates Committee. I have not got them with me now but we have already provided them once. If Senator Calvert goes back through the records he will find them.

SPEECH.PARA: In so far as the research program is concerned, it was a marine research program. As I understand it, we were able to do that fairly cheaply because we were able to get it done so quickly on that cruise. As far as the program itself is concerned, I will have an evaluation of it sent to Senator Calvert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: -Getting back to some of the questions that were asked about the Aurora Australis contract, in answer to a question about the cost of the ship from Senator Michael Baume-which appears on page C67-the Deputy Director of the Antarctic Division, Mr Moncur, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, and if you take those into account and you take into account the financial conditions and the tax things that we have been able to negotiate out, I am sure that with the effective price we are in front.
I would like to know how, after having an original contract of $124m-and even in the Auditor-General's report we are looking at an extra $1m a year-we are in front.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, we have provided those figures once to the Committee. We will provide them again if it is necessary. If Senator Calvert reads all that we have provided he might find out.

—I still find it hard to believe that where a vessel has cost an extra $20m we could be in front. Anyway, I will leave that. In answer to a question from Senator Baume, the Minister mentioned an ice pilot and an extra $28,000 a year. He has also been saying how good it was to have an Australian crewed ship. I would like to ask the Minister: what is the nationality of the ice pilot on this voyage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The gentleman occupying the role at the moment is a Norwegian. We will not need an ice pilot for long, once we get an Australian captain with sufficient ice experience, and that will be only a year or two off. We are rapidly approaching the point where, for the first time, we will not need overseas expertise to conduct our own voyages. I think that was, of course, a great part of the exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: I should also add, because I know people in the Australian Public Service are concerned about position and status, that Mr Moncur is in fact the Director, not the Deputy Director. He is actually the trump card here.

TALK.START.PARA: -I think I got confused because I was referring earlier to when he was the Deputy Director; I apologise for that. Reverting to the previous answer, I thank the Minister for telling me that the ice pilot is a Norwegian. Were any Australian firms contacted or asked to provide ice pilotage? In fact, were any Australian ice pilots available?

—I think the point is that the Government was not making the offer; P and O was. It went to three firms, as I understand it; I do not think they were Australian. Australians with this kind of experience are not easy to find; P and O found a very experienced Norwegian and I think was of the view that that expertise was so great that it would rub off more quickly on the Australians around him, and we would have our full Australian effort coming on-stream earlier because of it.

-As a follow-up to that, to the knowledge of the Department, were ice marine consultants consulted? Was Mr Ewald Brune asked whether he could do the job? He is a former captain of the Icebird; I believe he is also a naturalised Australian citizen and he resides in Hobart.

—I do not believe those people were contacted, but that was P and O's decision, not ours. I do not think we are necessarily unhappy. As I said, we believe this will help us to get to the all-Australian position more quickly. There seems to be some doubt about whether one of the gentlemen to whom Senator Calvert referred is an Australian citizen or an Australian resident.
—He resides in Hobart, which happens to be the capital of Tasmania.
—`Resides' is different to being a citizen, as the honourable senator would be aware.
-Am I led to believe that the whole matter was conducted by P and O, and that the division did not have any say about who the ice pilot was going to be? Is that correct?

—Under the agreement we had with P and O, the Government had a power of rejection and could have said, `No, the person concerned is unsuitable', but it would have been pretty hard to suggest that this person was unsuitable and the Government did not exercise the power of rejection.

-I now refer the Minister to chartering a second ship for the season. I believe the Icebird, a regular voyager to the Antarctic, is being chartered this season. Is the division satisfied that all crew members meet the division's previously required standards of Antarctic experience? How much experience does the present captain have?
—We are satisfied that the crew members have sufficient experience for the voyage they have been contracted to undertake.
-How would the experience of the captain of the Aurora Australis, for instance, line up with that of the captain of the Icebird? Is there any intention to use an ice pilot on the Icebird?
