Previously this had been interpreted to include only paintings and the like and sculpture and the like and generally excluded items capable of utilitarian use-that is a good phrase-such as decorative pottery and ceramics even when produced in limited quantities.

SPEECH.PARA: However, a series of court hearings which involved a potter from Braidwood in New South Wales who claimed exemption for sale of items of pottery on the grounds that they were works of art, although capable of being utilitarian, has resulted in an extension of the Tax Office's interpretation to include consideration of the intention of the artist in creating the work. Another recent development which has assisted craftspersons is the increase of the threshold for small manufacturers to $50,000 annual value of sales before sales tax applies. The threshold previously of $12,000 was increased in late 1989.

So, I think we have moved to address some of these concerns and I would hope that if we can monitor the effects of the things that we have just mentioned, between now and the next Budget round, we will be able to see whether we need to do anything more.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Madam Chair would like to ask a question from the chair on that matter?
—Well, no, Senator Michael Baume, I would not but I would like to say that I am most delighted to hear that report, having fought for this for five years and I would welcome a copy of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of brief questions. The Minister mentioned in a laudatory way his activities in the area of film. I wonder whether I could raise very briefly one matter that has emerged. It relates to the funding of a film, an Australian production, called Cotton. As I understand it, it is aimed at being a production under the general national interest head. I have been receiving substantial complaints, as I understand the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has also received complaints, that this film, a national interest production, is not, as appears so far, providing the docu-drama `fair approach' that its producer, when interviewed on a local radio station, suggested was its intention.

SPEECH.PARA: The film is designed to look at the controversial subject of chemical use in the agricultural industry. It is claimed by the producer that the cotton industry formed an ideal basis to look at both sides of the chemical debate. The producer, Ms William, said:

You hear from people who live in cotton growing areas who are concerned, real or perceived concerns, that are still there about chemicals. Of course, a lot of chemicals are used in cotton. You also have the opportunity of hearing from the other side.

There are concerns that this is shaping up not as a balanced `national interest' matter where the issues are fairly dealt with but one in which the people playing real live roles are in fact substantial activists who are strongly opposed to the cotton industry. I have no knowledge of the merits of the case. All I am saying is that there is concern and I wonder to what extent these productions, which are `national interest' productions, are subject to any kind of assessment within the Department and whether it is perceived to be `in the national interest`, as this is a national interest film, for this industry, which is one of the few actually earning any export income at the moment, to be subjected to what is expected to be by those people who have been involved in this as a pretty one-sided production.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Film Australia is currently making a docu-drama called Cotton, which addresses the use of chemicals in agriculture, which is of course an important contemporary issue. It has to be remembered that Film Australia is a government owned company which operates at arm's length from the Government. It has been contracted to produce films under the national interest program which will cover issues of national interest or which illustrate or interpret aspects of Australian society and the lives of Australian people. What it is actually going to make these films of national interest about, of course, is a matter for Film Australia and not the Government. One is always, I think, in a difficult area here of not wanting to be seen to do or actually to do something that could be interpreted as being censorious.

SPEECH.PARA: This new program style of docu-drama is proving very popular. It is where one mixes actors and real persons in fictional stories in a tele-movie format. By doing it that way it is hoped one can reach a much broader audience than one might with just an old style documentary, and that way one might encourage community debate on issues. The kinds of issues that have been covered using this production style in the past are custody, prejudice, malpractice and mortgage. There have not been any complaints about the programs that Film Australia produced on those subjects. If one looks at some of them they are pretty controversial. One could imagine they are more controversial than the use of chemicals in agriculture.

Nonetheless, the use of chemicals in agriculture is, as I said, an important contemporary issue from the health standpoint, certainly from an environment standpoint, and, one would imagine, it also is tied up with our new enlivened discussion on ecologically sustainable development.

Film Australia has assured the Minister that every effort is being made to show both sides of the argument in this docu-drama. If there are people who are concerned about the way this is proceeding then perhaps they ought to take up their complaints with Film Australia but I shall make sure that the Department seeks a further assurance from Film Australia that every consideration will be given to all those with a concern on the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that response.
—Excuse me, Senator Baume, you might be able to help the Chair. I was out of the chamber for a while. Are we still on Arts or are we on film and television?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Actually Mr Chairman, this was just one matter I mentioned in passing. The Minister mentioned his activities in funding film and I mentioned this in passing speedily to get it out of the way.
—So we are still on Arts?

—Still on Arts, yes. It seemed the easy way to deal with the matter. It is the only matter I have in that area. The concerns emerge not because there is environmental concern about chemicals in cotton, but because it has been suggested to me that the matters being raised are really maintaining an unrepresentative environmental concern. In other words, a body has three of its strong supporters involved in real live roles in this film. I am referring to members of the Total Environment Centre (TEC). It has been put to me very strongly, and I repeat: they are unrepresentative of mainstream environmental concerns. On the contrary, they have consistently advocated an extremist view. The industry's problem is that, if their view is to be the dominant view and the only `environmentalist' view, this could do much to undo the work being done in trying to build public confidence in the industry. I also understand that there has been a significant improvement as a result of genuine environmental concerns about the use and abuse of chemicals in the production of cotton.

SPEECH.PARA: To substantiate that, I think I should just mention it has been put to me that three people who are taking a real live role in the film are Dr Kate Short, an environmental activist from the Total Environmental Centre, who is, as I understand it, acting as a consultant to the producers on an almost full time basis and who is well known as having been aggressively agitating public opinion against the use of chemicals in cotton production for the last 18 months-I do not think Dr Short is a medical doctor, I think she has a PHD; Dr Mark Donohue, a Sydney based general practitioner, who actively endorses the anti-cotton industry stance of the TEC; and Ms Pat Jackson, a Mungindi resident responsible for coordinating the community opposition to the use of aerial applied chemicals in cotton production.

I am grateful for the Minister's assurance that concerns would be looked at, but I would hope that by raising the matter here I might be able to encourage the producers to be particularly careful to ensure that while it is a controversial film-and I hope it would be because it would be stimulating and interesting if it were controversial-it provides a fair view of what is a delicate matter, particularly when one recognises that really it is a government supported and government funded body. If a fair view does not emerge Film Australia might find an opportunity to make another docu-drama which presents the other side of the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would not concur with the description of the Total Environment Centre as extremist. Obviously, as an active conservation group, it puts its views firmly. But I do not think I would classify its members as extremists. I know many people associated with the Total Environment Centre; some people in the Total Environment Centre are among my best friends, as they say. But I would not have thought one could say that they were extremist. I do not know Dr Kate Short, but it seems to me quite natural that, if one is going to present a matter of public interest like this, then one would go to those who have a view and involve them. One would also go to the other side of the argument and, perhaps, involve that other side as well.

SPEECH.PARA: These docu-dramas, by their very nature, evolve during their production. It is not like a movie with a set script that just has actors performing their set lines. I would strongly suggest to anyone in the industry who has a contrary view to Dr Short, or to the Mungindi resident to whom Senator Baume referred, to go along to Film Australia and put that view. I am sure that view will be accommodated and that Film Australia-which has a pretty good reputation for making sure that people are treated fairly-will do that. It is hard to imagine a more controversial subject than something like custody, and yet we have not had a flood of complaints from those involved in that issue about the handling of it. I would be surprised if, when this docu-drama finally comes out, there is cause for anyone to complain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I do not want to pursue that further, except that I do note his point that these things evolve. As I understand it, in the course of their evolving there was a suggestion put by the producers that the Bourke Shire Council should include actors and a film crew in a public meeting that it planned to have on this matter. The Council decided that maybe that was not the way it wanted this public meeting to evolve, let alone the way it wanted the film to evolve, and felt it should cancel the meeting if it was not going to be a fair dinkum meeting dealing in a fair dinkum way with this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The next matter I want to raise very briefly, because we are running out of time, is: when will the Government be announcing a new Chairman for the Australia Council? As I understand Professor Horne's time runs out at the end of this year. Could I say that it does seem, in view of the present state of the Arts in Australia, that there is clearly a need for a chairman who has a practical appreciation of the broad spectrum of problems facing the arts. Without making any comments or reflecting in any way on past chairmen, I am wondering whether the tendency to have people with academic backgrounds is necessarily appropriate in the present circumstances of severe practical problems facing the Australia Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are recommendations before Ministers at the moment. I cannot say exactly when the Minister will be making an announcement, so I will have to make an inquiry of the Minister and get back to Senator Baume as soon as I can.
—In that case, it might be worth while to mention that it is 12.45 p.m. Under Standing Orders I put the question that I do leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the Minister of the statements of the Minister's parliamentary colleague Mr Gayler that the right wing faction of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) is involved in thuggery. I ask the Minister: Who are the Ministers in the Government from this faction and was the recent humiliating public attack on the Minister by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, an example of this thuggery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only answer a question which is within the realm of my own portfolio or the portfolios I represent. I must say that I have no particular knowledge of or expertise in the topic of thuggery. So I am unable to answer that part of the question.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator referred to a particular incident and asked me whether it was an example of right wing thuggery. I think that the performance on that occasion was unique to the Treasurer-that is to say, it was something that had nothing to do with factional politics within the ALP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Now that we have been advised by his colleague that this faction engages in this practice of thuggery, I think it is important, in the Minister's capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister, that he put on the public record who are the Ministers in the Government from this faction.
—It is not a supplementary question, Mr President.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. My question relates to a report in the Australian newspaper of 5 November headlined `Gases threat may be hot air' and, in particular, a claim by Dr Brian O'Brien, former head of the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority. Is there any basis for Dr O'Brien's claim that widely accepted and dire assumptions about life on a planet choked by greenhouse gases are exaggerations, based partly on outdated scientific assumptions? In view of a more pessimistic set of predictions in a report from the National Health and Medical Research Council, what should the public perception be about the extent of the problems and dangers associated with the greenhouse effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the article that the honourable senator referred to, but I must say it does not surprise me that there is debate about the greenhouse effect and the implications of the greenhouse effect. That debate largely turns, I think, on questions of time, when the effects of climate change will be felt, and so on. The report of the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is still the best scientific advice that Government has, for that report quite properly emphasised the remaining uncertainties which qualified its conclusions. These uncertainties relate both to the greenhouse effect itself and to its consequences. There has been a debate both in Australia and very much so in the United States about these issues.

ANSWER.PARA: The work on impacts proceeded in parallel with the IPCC's re-examination of the scientific aspects and so was obliged to draw on the best predictions of the rate of change available at the time. The same is true of the report of the National Health and Medical Research Council. I should emphasise that both reports take a very long term look at the consequences of the greenhouse effect. If the effect is slower than earlier predicted, those consequences would appear more slowly. But they would still appear, assuming we do nothing to prevent them.

Let me emphasise that we are doing something. Because of the scientific uncertainties I referred to earlier, we are moving carefully and deliberately, doing those things that it makes sense to do-first of all, things that have economic efficiency benefits as well as greenhouse benefits. When some of the current scientific uncertainties have been resolved, it may be time to think about further measures, and the Government continually has the question of further measures on its agenda.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no basis on which to change that answer. It is a matter of waiting to see what emerges. I will not make any assumptions that there is anything left to emerge from this particular process. I really have nothing more that I can possibly add at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. He discussed only the first part of my question; he did not answer the question: Will the Minister allow the former Western Australian Premier to discuss matters relating to his term as Premier during his current visit?
—It is not a matter of my allowing him or not allowing him; it is a matter of him making his own judgment as to what is consistent with the proprieties of his official office.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to figures released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) relating to average weekly earnings? Do these figures show that the Government's wage policy remains on target? Can this be included among the many other significant achievements of the Government's accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Australian Bureau of Statistics brought out its publication Average Weekly Earnings: Australia, August 1990. As honourable senators will know, the Australian Bureau of Statistics is independent of the Government; its opinions are its own. The survey results for this publication show that preliminary estimates of average weekly earnings released today by the ABS show that the Government's wages policy is on target. The figures indicate virtually no wages drift and a high level of compliance with and commitment to national wage case principles. The ABS information shows that the average weekly ordinary time earnings for full time adults increased by 1.4 per cent in the three months to August and by 6.5 per cent over the whole of the year.

ANSWER.PARA: This compares with a rise in the weekly award rates of pay index for full time adults of 6.4 per cent in the year to August, indicating a low wages drift and a high level of compliance with the national wage case principles. The growth in average weekly earnings has been influenced by the flow-through of the second increase delivered in the August 1989 national wage case decision. The decision allowed for a rise of $15 per week or 3 per cent, whichever was the greater, for skilled workers; $12.50 for semi-skilled workers; and $10 for unskilled workers. This means that the Labor Government's wages policy and our consensus approach-the accord approach-to wage fixation in this country is on track and that that accord approach makes it possible to achieve fundamental workplace reforms while maintaining a wide compliance on the wages front.

I note from reports that metal unions and metal employers are today in negotiation over wages. I hope that leads to a settlement of their negotiations in a way which will be within the parameters set down by the accord. I expect that that would be the case. Also, this morning I referred the matter of the 6 per cent claim for members of the Industrial Relations Commission to the Gleeson inquiry-the inquiry looking at salaries and conditions for the whole of the Federal Commission. That means that there is now no pressure on the wages system, other than the pressure exerted by excessive settlements for senior executives in this country and by senior executive remuneration.

I have tabled figures to show that senior executives are still obtaining wage increases which are well above those of the ordinary work force and I have called upon them to exercise the same restraint that ordinary wage and salary earners are required to exercise. I would appreciate it if the Opposition would give an uncontradictory and completely open endorsement of that call so that it can at least be bipartisan and we can see all sectors of the community complying with the restraint required in these times.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to the proposal to import apple fruit from New Zealand where the disease fireblight has been recorded in all production areas. I remind the Minister that fireblight of apples and pears is considered to be one of the most infectious and devastating diseases known to affect plants and that Australia is one of only four countries still free of the disease. I ask: Is the Minister aware of the devastation caused in other countries by this disease and of the deep concerns of Australian horticulturalists? Has the Government considered the report of its own Horticultural Policy Council, to which the Minister referred the proposal, which recommends a re-examination of the issue on the basis that the present proposal does not provide protection against the entry of fireblight disease into Australia? Finally, when will the Government announce its decision on the importation of New Zealand apples?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My answer to the first part of that question is yes, I am aware of the damage that this disease can do and, indeed, that Australia is one of the few countries in the world free from it. That knowledge is not peculiar to me; it is knowledge shared by all of us in the Government. As a consequence, on this and other matters of this nature we provide for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS)-again, a body that is independent of government-to conduct scientific tests and run risk assessment models in order to assess what risk there would be if importation of particular fruit bearing this disease were allowed into Australia. We are aware of it. There is a mechanism through AQIS to scrutinise properly and scientifically what the risk factors are so that judgments can be made on real knowledge and not on political grounds.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the other parts of the honourable senator's question, we have freely acknowledged-officially as the Government and through officials of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy-that we are considering the proposal to import apples from New Zealand. That is true. The application has been made and we acknowledge it. However, we think that the proper course is to undertake an assessment as to whether those apples would in fact bear the disease.

The report of the Horticultural Policy Council which Senator Powell referred to was not commissioned by the Government; the Council itself initiated that. The recommendations of the Council are now being considered by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service together with other responses to a discussion paper which AQIS itself published. It was prepared on the basis of being able to consult with other scientific opinion outside of the Service and to obtain the opinion of growers and others affected by the importation of this fruit.

I conclude by saying that AQIS has considered the responses that the Horticultural Council has made, that other scientists have made and that growers have made to its discussion paper. It is now preparing a report which it will finalise by the end of this month and, as a consequence of that report, there will be further consultation before action is decided upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I ask the Minister: what has occurred subsequent to the election and can the people of Richmond-indeed, of Tasmania-expect that money to come forward?
—It is a great bridge.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great bridge, as Senator Sherry says. I visited that bridge some time earlier this year, although I cannot recall the date. In fact, it was the third time that I had been there. On the other occasions that I have been there it was as a private citizen touring Tasmania, one of the States that I love.
—It is reciprocated, and we love you.

—I am very glad to hear that from Senator Aulich. Does this sound like a political thug? The family and I were down there several times walking over the bridge and visiting the churches around it, as a matter of fact.

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier this year we actually had an inspection of the bridge. I am always very careful when addressing local government groups-or, indeed, any other groups that are seeking funds-to indicate to them that I will seek to get funds for them. I have never once promised that the funds will be made available if no Government decision has been made. I did say to the council that I would support its endeavours to get funds and that I would approach my colleague Mr Brown, the Minister for Land Transport, to see if I could get them.

Of course, as fate would have it, some weeks later I no longer had responsibility for the portfolio. Nonetheless, the Minister, Mrs Kelly, did take up the matter with Mr Brown. Mr Brown has indicated to the Tasmanian Minister that he believes funds should be made available during the course of the next two to three years out of Commonwealth grants to fix up another bridge.

The Tasmanian Government has already taken some steps. As I understand it, it has put in a new junction near the bridge and introduced load limits to ensure a diminution of those cracks that have been appearing. I might say, by the way, that the Tasmanian Government is trialling some methods of monitoring those cracks which are very impressive. I am not sure whether Minister Brown has got a response yet from the Tasmanian Government to that request. I will endeavour to find out what the Tasmanian Government has said about it.

I think both Mr Brown and Mrs Kelly advised the council and the Tasmanian Government that some funds could be made available through the National Estate grants program for a study on the best way of alleviating pressure on the bridge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another study. There has been study after study. There are studies coming out of your ears.
—I would have thought that having a proper look at how we could best go about saving one of the oldest bridges in the country would have been important.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Walters interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters is history herself. I would have thought that the Tasmanian Government might find it within its capacity within the next year or so to allocate funds to it. As soon as I can get a response from Mr Brown as to the attitude of the Tasmanian Government I will inform Senator Harradine.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer the Minister to questions asked previously concerning convicted Western Australian private investigator Robert Smith and the file referred to as the blue file. Now that the Western Australian Ombudsman has indicated that the blue file is of such consequence that he has demanded a Royal Commission, on what possible basis did the Minister, as the Minister for Justice, believe that further inquiry beyond simply delivering the file to the Western Australian Commissioner of Police was not warranted into matters at the Federal level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a completely incredible, convoluted and confused question. It was not for me to pass a matter for investigation to the Commissioner of Police in Western Australia. The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police (AFP), Mr Peter McAuley, took that decision having exhausted the investigation of the alleged telephone intercepts by Mr Smith. As honourable senators know, that particular investigation led to the conviction of Mr Smith. I think that is to be commended. Honourable senators will recall that on 26 February 1990 Mr Smith and another person were convicted in the Perth District Court of conspiring to commit offences against the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. He was sentenced to 15 months imprisonment and was released during the year after serving approximately five months of his sentence. Smith recently appeared in the Perth District Court on further counts of conspiring to intercept telephone conversations. He was found guilty and sentenced to three years imprisonment with a 10-month non-parole period and directed to enter into a $15,000 recognisance on release.

ANSWER.PARA: In the course of that investigation I was briefed some six times. On none of those occasions was the name Burke ever mentioned in any of the briefs. Further, I am advised by Mr Peter McAuley, the Commissioner of the AFP, responding to my request this morning in these terms:
I am advised there was no evidence at all implicating Mr Brian Burke in the AFP's investigation of the Commonwealth offences which led to the prosecution and conviction of Mr Robert Smith.

In that situation I think it was quite proper that that Commonwealth offences investigation having been properly concluded by the AFP, which is its particular responsibility, Mr Peter McAuley took the proper decision to hand materials over to Mr Brian Burke. He is making the necessary inquiries in accordance with Western Australian police investigative practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Do I understand from the Minister's answer that he has not seen the blue file and that the decision was actually taken out of his hands and made by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police?

—I have never seen the blue file; I hope I never see the blue file. Those matters are properly matters for police investigation and the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police has my absolute confidence in his dealing with this matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Will the Minister comment on the expected effects on the telecommunications equipment industry of the announcement on micro-economic reform of the telecommunications sector announced last Thursday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Beahan for his question because there has been some speculation about this issue in newspapers and elsewhere. First let me make the point that restructuring of the telecommunications infrastructure will provide a more efficient and responsive service to users, both domestic and business. There will, of course, be substantial benefits to business in all industry sectors, particularly those in which communications are a significant element of cost. I refer to industries such as tourism and banking, for example.

ANSWER.PARA: The restructuring will also provide a major opportunity for Australian manufacturers of telecommunications equipment, and particularly for the providers of value-added services. Australia already has quite a well-developed communications equipment industry and is well placed to take advantage of increased market opportunities, and industry development activities will form an important element of the selection of the second carrier.

Without wishing to be prescriptive, it is likely that tenders for the second licence will be committed to activities such as local research and development, either by the carrier itself or by contracting out to local companies or research organisations; will be committed to local sourcing of major equipment either from existing or new suppliers; and hopefully will be committed to exports of locally developed products, again including and emphasising value-added services, network hardware or software, and management and design expertise. Specific opportunities for the telecommunications equipment industry generated by these activities will become apparent as the tendering process progresses.

I make the point that what we are talking about is enlarging the size of the industry, and that will bring benefits. These commitments will, however, not be solely limited to the second carrier network licence. Licence agreements with both carriers will cover a number of things such as industry development activities. In all the reform processes announced by the Prime Minister there is opportunity for increased new private investment, an expansion of total jobs in the telecommunications sector, and the creation of substantial and enduring export opportunities for the telecommunications industry.

—I really doubt whether the question is in order.

—My response would simply be that the question is clearly outside my ministerial responsibilities, but the empire will strike back this afternoon on radio and television and I hope Senator Herron is listening.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health and it concerns acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) research. I draw the Minister's attention to an article that appeared on 1 November in the Adelaide evening newspaper, the News, in which it was claimed by a Sydney University researcher, Ms Lydia Bennett, that health workers who care for people with AIDS are shunned by their colleagues and often suffer further prejudice outside of work from family and friends. With the realisation that the AIDS disease is one which will be around for some time, can the Minister outline what action, if any, is presently being directed towards this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had the advantage of Senator Foreman drawing my attention to the article in question, which quotes from recent statements by Sydney University researcher Ms Lydia Bennett. Certainly, if what she has to say is even half true, it is an indictment of the people who work with those who are nursing in the AIDS field. It is hard to comprehend how fellow health workers could out of ignorance, or malice perhaps, ostracise or add to the tensions and trauma experienced by those who are undertaking this particularly difficult type of nursing. The Government certainly recognises the need to provide additional training and support for groups such as nurses who are dealing with the AIDS epidemic on a day to day basis.

ANSWER.PARA: As part of its strategy, the Government has initiated the Commonwealth AIDS work force information, standards and exchange program. This program provides funding to employers, unions and professional groups to ensure that the work force has access to AIDS related information and resource materials, retraining and skills development programs, guidelines and standards. In fact, we are putting $1.59m into that program this year.

The researcher quoted in the article is involved in a study funded under that program-a 3-year prospective study of AIDS related burn-out-approved in August this year by the Minister for Community Services and Health. Some $60,000 has been devoted to that project. The fact is that burn-out and the battle fatigue induced by working in this area are such that quite often in this demanding job nursing may attract people for perhaps only a year or so and they then move to another area of nursing or out of the profession altogether. The trauma of seeing multiple deaths among young people is too much for them to take if they do not have the support of their colleagues in the nursing and other care professions.

I believe that government funding for education and support programs for health care workers has been provided to a number of organisations, including the Australian Nursing Federation, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australian Association of Social Workers and the Australian Community Health Association. I believe that those funded programs will help alleviate the sort of stress and distress experienced by those engaged in this particularly difficult form of nursing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, follows the answer that he gave to my colleague Senator Knowles. In view of the call by the Western Australian Ombudsman for a royal commission into matters contained in this file, on the grounds that in his view public disquiet cannot be allayed simply by the State police inquiry and, of course, would no doubt deal with matters wider than questions of pure illegality, will the Minister now himself, for the first time apparently, despite the six briefings, look at this file to determine for himself whether or not there are any matters contained in it at the Federal level which should be reconsidered in relation to the question of a royal commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I reply in two parts. First of all, the actual request made by Mr Freeman, the Ombudsman in Western Australia, for a royal commission-and I only have the front page of the West Australian to go by-seems to be somewhat confused. In fact, amongst other things, it is reported in these terms:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Freeman, who turned 63 today, said his successor would review the progress of the police investigation into the affair in three months. The investigation should proceed and nothing should be done to jeopardise it.

I would have thought that the sort of line of questioning and the public hysteria that has been generated about this matter would be designed in some part perhaps to influence the police investigation, and certainly may jeopardise it. I would have thought that if Mr Freeman is properly quoted there, the best thing that could be done is for those who believe in Mr Freeman's general integrity and who want to take note in a serious way of what he says should take note of that part of his statement also and allow the police investigation being conducted by Commissioner Bull to be concluded in a way which will be, as he says, under the constant surveillance of his successor.

Having said that, I would also say that, of course, it is not my intention to look at any evidence seized by the Australian Federal Police in relation to an investigation which they have undertaken, which has led to the successful prosecution and sentencing of persons who were in breach of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. I believe that I can reiterate my utmost confidence in the handling of this matter by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Mr Peter McAuley, who has advised me-and I rely on his advice absolutely and with no qualms whatsoever-that there was no evidence at all implicating Mr Brian Burke in the AFP's investigation of the Commonwealth offences which led to the prosecution and conviction of Mr Robert Smith. In that situation, I certainly would not indulge in anything that might have a colouring of political interference by seeking to look at the evidence which has led Mr Peter McAuley and his officers to that conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Administrative Services. Does the Minister recall a recent letter I wrote to him regarding the Government's specifications for veneers? Is it a fact that the only timber available to meet these specifications is old growth eucalyptus regnans? Is the Government taking any action on this issue?
—You wouldn't write back to him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do in fact recall the letter that Senator Devereux wrote to me and I must say that he has been much more productive than Senator Alston in respect of this issue. In the correspondence to me he suggested that a simple change to the specifications would see an immediate start to a transition from old growth regnans to regrowth forests. He also indicated that such an action would clearly signal to the community that the Government is continuing its support for a sustainable development strategy. I take this opportunity to thank Senator Devereux for raising this issue. The Department of Administrative Services is currently in the process of calling tenders to supply the Commonwealth with a range of commercial furniture, and I am pleased to announce that we have moved away from the strict adherence to the specifications that were previously used and those that Senator Devereux mentioned in his correspondence.

ANSWER.PARA: Previously, 95 per cent of Commonwealth furniture was made with particle board covered by eucalyptus regnans veneer. I am pleased to say that we will now omit reference to straight grains in the tenders and, because of that, the changed veneer specification will now allow manufacturers to use veneers of different colours and grains. Essentially, that means that tenderers will not be required to use old growth forest timber to meet government orders.

The overall question of timbers used in government construction is still under review, but specifically in respect of old growth timbers I must say that very little use is made at the moment of eucalyptus regnans for the purpose of internal partitioning and executive fitouts of buildings. However, it is still used in some cases for built-in furniture but, because of the change in the specification, this should phase out in the near future.

In closing, I take this opportunity once again to thank Senator Devereux for raising this issue in a very constructive way. I hope that the changes I have just announced will contribute considerably to reduce the reliance on old growth timbers and start a transition to regrowth forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to questions asked of him previously concerning the conviction of Western Australian private investigator Robert Smith and his relationship with the then Premier of Western Australia, Brian Burke. I ask the Minister: Has he or his office directed or advised the Ambassador to Ireland not to make public statements concerning his involvement in this matter? If so, why? Does the Minister endorse the reported statement of the spokesperson from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Sue Boyd, who said that the Ambassador could comment on whatever he felt was appropriate; or does he endorse the reported statement of the Ambassador that he was not in a position to answer any of the questions? Finally, does he endorse a reported statement by a spokesman from his office that it was a long established practice that Australian diplomats did not comment on Australian domestic politics or legal matters?

—As to the last part of the question, it is such a practice. As to the second part of the question, I have already answered that earlier on. It is a matter for Mr Burke's own judgment is what I said. That is the answer to the question. As to the first part of the question, any communications that I may have with Mr Burke or any other ambassador is entirely my business and his business and none of Senator Crichton-Browne's business.

—My question is to the Minister for Defence and I ask: Is the Minister able to inform the Senate as to the Government's intention with regard to the Wrigley report on the Australian Defence Force and the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have pointed out previously, the Government regards the Wrigley report as a very important document and being worthy of serious consideration. I can now inform the Senate of the appointment of a high level interdepartmental committee (IDC) to consider the report and to develop implementation proposals. This interdepartmental committee will be chaired by Mr Rod Sims of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It will consist of representatives of the departments of Finance, Industry, Technology and Commerce, Industrial Relations, Transport and Communications and Treasury, as well as representatives of my Department and senior advisers to me and Mr Bilney. The deliberations of the IDC will run concurrently with the force structure review which I previously announced and with the development of a ready reserve proposal which my Department is also working on.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the Government's intention that the IDC deliberations will, along with other reports, be concluded by the end of March next year. We will then consider the resultant reports over April and put down a detailed statement for parliamentary debate in May. I should emphasise that the intention is not simply a cost-cutting exercise. Where savings can be identified, some or all will be redirected within the defence portfolio. The overall result should be a more effective Defence Force, a better local defence industry and greater community interest and involvement in our defence effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware that since the 1988-89 income year the prescribed minimum values which may be used for purposes of valuing natural increase in sheep were increased from $1 per head to $4 per head? Is the Minister also aware that this increase was thought to reflect realistic market value yet currently will result in the woolgrower being taxed on what he will not receive? I ask the Minister: In light of the crisis facing the Australian wool industry, would the Government, as a measure of relief, be prepared to reduce the prescribed minimum value for sheep from the current value of $4 per head to the 1984 figure of $1 per head?

—I am not aware, in the first instance, of how those values have altered, but I am quite prepared to take Senator Bjelke-Petersen's word for those changes. What I am aware of, though, is that the Government, through the Minister responsible, John Kerin, has recently made a statement on all matters relating to the wool industry. I am quite happy to make that statement available to Senator Bjelke-Petersen. It explains the Government's position.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade Negotiations about the status of Australia's carpet wool trade with New Zealand. Is it true that, since this Government's enlightened removal of the major part of the wool tax from carpet wool producers, the New Zealand Government has aggressively supported its producers to the extent that New Zealand growers are paid at least 70c more per kilogram than the price at which their wool is sold on the Australian market? Is this dumping? Does our closer economic relations (CER) agreement permit this situation? If so, why? If not, what does the Government intend to do about it?

—All I can say on this matter is that the Government is aware of claims by the carpet wool trade that the New Zealand Wool Board may be subsidising the sale of New Zealand carpet wool on the Australian market. The issue is of considerable concern and may be raised in discussions in Christchurch that Dr Blewett is having today, I think, with his New Zealand counterpart, Mr Burdon, on CER matters. Any possible action that might be taken in this matter will be considered following Dr Blewett's return from New Zealand. I do not think that there is anything I can usefully add at this stage.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Could the Minister please clarify what he said? Did he say `may be raised' or `is certain to be raised' at the discussions?

—I am not in a position to say what he will raise or what is on his briefing agenda. All I am saying is that we know it is a current issue. I think it is likely that it will be raised, but I am not in a position to assert that it will be because I am not so briefed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL HOBART HOSPITAL: TREATMENT OF VETERANS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the waiting list for admissions to the Royal Hobart Hospital last year doubled that of the previous year, and to the fact that the number of veterans treated in that hospital also doubled. Can the Minister explain whether surgical wards at the Repatriation General Hospital will be reopened to give veterans the priority of access to hospital care promised by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, or has the Government successfully negotiated with the State Government for veterans to jump the queue in the Royal Hobart Hospital as that queue gets even longer in the coming year? In any case, can the Minister also guarantee the quality of care which is due to veterans as the Royal Hobart Hospital cuts back on the length of stay in an attempt to cope with its crisis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the proposed integration of the Repatriation General Hospital in Hobart and elements of the Tasmanian hospital system, including the Royal Hobart Hospital, I believe that consultations are still taking place with the State Government and with ex-service personnel organisations. I am quite sure that unless Mr Field, the Premier of Tasmania, or Mr White, the Tasmanian Minister for Health, was satisfied as to the long term financial or industrial relations matters being satisfactorily resolved as far as the State was concerned, those discussions would not prove fruitful. Nevertheless, I am quite confident that Mr Ben Humphreys, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, will allow them to understand the financial and industrial implications for the State and to satisfy their concerns in those matters.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the general question of the wards that might be open at the Repatriation Hospital in Hobart as compared with wards that might be available at the Royal Hobart Hospital, Senator Newman should be aware that the geriatric rehabilitation unit has already moved from the Royal Hobart Hospital to the Repatriation Hospital and that this move has proved to be extremely successful. The move of that geriatric rehabilitation unit has allowed for space at the Royal Hobart Hospital to be found for the cardiac unit to be set up there.

In fact, that is a very good example of the way in which this integration of services will advantage not only the general community of veterans in their hospital treatment but the whole of the community. I am sure that veterans would recognise that they are part of the community in need of health care.

As to the questions of joining a queue and the quality of care, I am quite certain that, in relation to the consultative committee which has been established and in which the ex-service representatives are taking part and in relation to the monitoring committee that will be set up in regard to this integration, ex-service representatives will ensure that there is no way in which their voice will be crowded out by others in ensuring that veterans receive the best possible hospital treatment, whether within the traditional repatriation system or closer to their homes and families, in many instances, in Tasmania, which is a very decentralised community, in the general public hospital system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his attempt to cover what he can recall of the issue, but it was nothing to do with what I asked. I will ask him again to give him more time to think.
—It is not a supplementary question.

—It is a variation of the question; I am sure it is a supplementary question. There are doubling of queues at the Royal Hobart Hospital and a doubling of the wishes by veterans to access that hospital. How is the Government organising that? Does it have some priority in that queue for veterans? It was a very specific question which the Minister did not address himself to. Have those matters been negotiated already? What will happen? If these old people who are going to be chucked out of their beds very quickly are to be put into the Royal Hobart Hospital, will they be given the quality of care which the Minister is promising?

—I certainly would not respond in the terms in which Senator Newman has used about our elderly veterans being chucked out of hospital beds and moved from one hospital to another. That is disgraceful scaremongering language being adopted by Senator Newman. I am very confident that, between Mr Ben Humphreys, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, and the State Minister for Health, Mr John White, these matters will be resolved in a way which serves not only the veteran community but the wider Tasmanian community. I have already pointed to the very successful move of the geriatric rehabilitation unit to the Repatriation Hospital. I believe that is a good indication of what we can expect by way of improved services to the veterans of Tasmania.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a former distinguished senator, Stan Collard. On behalf of all senators, I wish him well on this visit to Canberra.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to his announcement on 30 January of the establishment of the Australian program of training for eastern Europe (APTEE). Can the Minister advise on progress of the implementation of this program and what other assistance is being provided by the Australian Government to the countries of eastern Europe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has provided, or is committed to providing, assistance of a variety of kinds to eastern Europe. There is, first of all, the capital subscriptions to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development of $45m over five years; there is a $5m food package to Poland-that was announced a number of months ago; there is a package of economic measures, including bilateral investment protection and double taxation agreements, to help Hungary and Poland in their trade relations with Australia; there is a $1m contribution that we have made to the stabilisation fund for Poland; and there is an emergency grant of $50,000 to the Red Cross for Romania.

ANSWER.PARA: I guess the centrepiece of our assistance program is now the Australian program of training for eastern Europe-APTEE-which was announced by the Government in January this year, which will provide training for middle level managers from eastern Europe at a cost of $5m over three years. Applications for the first APTEE fellowships were received in October and fellows will arrive in Australia in early 1991.

APTEE is designed to respond directly to the needs of recipient countries and draws on areas of expertise in which Australia does have a comparative advantage. It comprises two complementary activities: first of all, small in-country training projects, for which discretionary funds have been provided to heads of mission, and secondly-more significantly-120 fellowships conducted in Australia providing academic courses and supervised placements in industry or commerce.

Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland will participate in APTEE in the first year. The inclusion of other eastern European countries and the Soviet Union in subsequent years will be considered. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau will manage APTEE through Australia's overseas missions and an in-Australia contractor. Seventy-two firms have expressed interest in managing it. Nineteen of those have submitted firm proposals. The Hawthorn Institute of Education has been selected to conduct the program and contracts should be signed this month.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister who represents both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's speech which was reported by Senator Cook in Hansard on 5 December 1989 in which the Prime Minister said, among other things:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there will be a review of the current system of tax zone rebates which provide relief to taxpayers in remote and isolated areas.

I ask the Minister whether he is aware that the fixed dollar amount of rebate in zone A of $270 and in zone B of $45 has not increased since 1985, in spite of the fact that since that time there has been a consumer price index increase of about 37 per cent. I ask the Minister when the review promised by the Prime Minister of the current system of tax zone rebates was conducted, and what was the outcome of the review. Will the Minister urge the Prime Minister to use the occasion of the Northern Forum in Mount Isa next weekend to announce a substantial and realistic increase in fixed dollar amount zone rebates for the people of remote Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give the honourable senator what information I have about this matter. It may be that I will need to obtain some more from the Treasurer. The review to which Senator Macdonald refers is completed. It examined over 100 submissions from interested parties and identified a number of anomalies in the current arrangements. As outlined in the Budget, the current zone arrangements have been extended to include King Island and the Furneaux Group in zone B, and Nhulunbuy, Northern Territory and Lord Howe Island in special zone A. The arrangements have been extended to increase the dependence component in the special zone B tax rebate to the same level as that applying in zone A. They extend eligibility for the remote area allowance to pensioners and beneficiaries resident in special zone B. Previously this allowance was payable only to pensioners and beneficiaries in zone A.

ANSWER.PARA: These changes remove some clear anomalies in the situation prior to the changes. They simplify the administration of the rebate arrangements for the special zone areas and represent some $4m per annum in additional assistance to Australians who reside in remote areas. Whether there is anything further flowing from the review other than the information which I have just given the honourable senator, I will make some inquiries and find out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to the need for blind and visually impaired people to have their awareness of the world around them increased. What action has the Government taken to help achieve this goal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Aulich for his question. In doing so, I also note his interest in this area of disability. On 29 October, just a few weeks ago, I had the pleasure to launch a tactual atlas, which had been produced by the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group (AUSLIG) in my Department in cooperation with the braille community as well as the private sector. The atlas is a very special product. It is a unique reference work which breaks new ground in the availability of information to braille readers. In fact, it has no equivalent anywhere else in the world.

ANSWER.PARA: The first volume of the atlas was released in 1987. That volume gave the braille community the best available resource on the shape of Australia and its States and Territories, and the location of Australia in relation to our neighbours and the rest of the world. The second volume, which was released quite recently, in fact two weeks ago, was entitled People and Industry. It provides a wealth of information about the distribution and characteristics of Australia's population. It also covers our agricultural, mining and manufacturing industries. As well, it includes maps of the European exploration of Australia and transport and communications. To accompany this atlas, there are a number of companion books to assist both parents and teachers.
As I say, this atlas represents a break through. It has been the product of intensive research and testing. It has been developed in cooperation with its potential users.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which atlas?
—Tactual; Senator Watson may not understand it.
—Tactile?

—`Tactile' is totally different. Senator Watson should go back to his dictionary to see whether he can work it out. A number of important innovations have been involved in producing this atlas. We were able to do so on a computer-driven drafting machine. That, of course, makes the transcription and production process more efficient. It also has flow-on effects for any other productions that will follow this volume by both government and the private sector. As well as that, the atlas used special interpoint equipment which can produce double-sided braille embossing. This halves the number of pages and simplifies the binding process.

ANSWER.PARA: Another significant development representing the interaction of the private sector with AUSLIG in this particular area was the development of a process--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not dispute the importance of the matters that Senator Bolkus is putting before the Senate. But again, they would be more appropriately put in the form of a statement. I invite you to suggest that he do that in order that we might get on with questions without notice.

—There is no point of order. It is clearly within the Minister's area of responsibility. In the past I have reminded Ministers about long answers. I point out that probably more questions have been asked today than on any other day I can remember.

—Mr President, I think three minutes on an issue such as this is not too much time during Question Time. As I was about to say in closing, another significant development occurred in the printing of the maps. This involved a process called `puff ink' which, once cured and heated, expands to form raised shapes which are clear to braille readers and highly durable to constant use. This is another innovation which will be extremely important to the braille community.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to Senator Aulich, the publication of these volumes of the Australian tactual atlas is important. They were received extremely positively by the community to which they are directed. I am sure that the Government's efforts in this area will be recognised, despite Senator Hill's point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Government aware that the draft report prepared by the panel of review of agricultural and related education, known as the McColl committee, recommends that there be only six recognised providers of agricultural education and training throughout Australia and that, as a result, the University of Tasmania, along with a number of other regional institutions, would be prevented from offering undergraduate courses in agricultural science? Is it true that the Committee's recommendation is in direct contrast to recent Federal Government policy and practice which have deliberately set about to link excellence in research to an effective undergraduate program through the introduction of cooperative research centres? Because of the catastrophic effect which this recommendation, if implemented, would have upon agricultural research and training opportunities in Tasmania, is the Minister prepared to give an assurance on behalf of the Government that the University of Tasmania will not be forced to axe its undergraduate course in agricultural science?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on the issue that Senator Calvert raised. Senator Calvert's question is prompted by one of the recommendations in a draft report circulated recently by the panel undertaking a discipline review of agriculture and related education on behalf of the Commonwealth. The document is, as its name suggests, a draft report. It has been circulated by the panel to higher education institutions offering agricultural and related education and to other interested parties as part of the input into the review process. Comments on the draft will be taken into account in the preparation of the final report which is expected to be completed sometime later this year-in fact, some time in December is the anticipated date.

ANSWER.PARA: The relevant recommendation seeks to strengthen provisions in the disciplines concerned by designating certain higher education institutions as recognised providers of mainstream agricultural and related education. I am informed that the recommendation does not seek to exclude all other institutions currently in the field, as it is envisaged that these would continue to offer non-mainstream programs and would be encouraged to work closely with the recognised providers. The recommendations would clearly have implications for the structure and funding of higher education and would require careful consideration. However, the Commonwealth will need to await the final report of the discipline review before it would be appropriate to respond to any such proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 November Senator Short asked me a question regarding the funding of the Olympic Games in Melbourne and he later asked me a supplementary question. The answer to Senator Short's supplementary question is that I have been advised that the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet that the advice I gave to the Senate is correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The seventeenth annual report 1989-90 of the Pipeline Authority is an interesting document. It is interesting for a variety of reasons. The first reason relates to why the report is so late in being tabled in the Parliament. I think it was presented in the House of Representatives only yesterday despite the fact that the report is dated 16 October and, as I understand it, reached the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) on something like 17 or 18 October. So there has been a delay of several weeks in tabling this report, despite the fact that the Parliament has been sitting. One can draw only one possible conclusion from that and that is that it was hoped that this report would be tabled after the Pipeline Authority (Charges) Bill 1990 had been debated in the House of Representatives. In fact, that is the case. The report was not tabled in the House of Representatives until yesterday.

The Government got its timing slightly out of kilter because the debate on that Bill took place last night although the Bill had been introduced before that. That Bill of course went to the whole core of the future of the Pipeline Authority because the Bill was concerned with raising, by an amount of no less than 56 per cent, the haulage charges of the Pipeline Authority over a 12-month period between 1 January 1991 and 1 January 1992 to prepare for sale the assets of the Pipeline Authority. Of course the main asset is the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline. As we now know, the Government took that Bill through the House yesterday, but both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have said that they will be opposing that Bill in the Senate so presumably the sale will not proceed.

The matter has been the subject of considerable debate and, therefore, the future of the pipeline has been a matter of considerable debate in recent days. The Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, put out a statement yesterday following the Opposition's announced decision to oppose the increase in the haulage charges and, according to the Government-although it is not necessarily the case-thereby putting the end, for the time being, to the sale of the pipeline. He put out a statement yesterday which I find nothing short of extraordinary and which I wish to comment on briefly.

Let me reiterate that the Opposition's decision to oppose the sale of the major asset of the Pipeline Authority was a very simple decision. It was based on a very simple principle, that is, there is a basic requirement of governments to honour their legal contractual commitments. The Government's attempt to do two things- first of all, to break its contractual commitment arrangements so far as the haulage charges of the pipeline are concerned; and, secondly, to try to arrange the sale of the major asset of the Pipeline Authority in such a way as to circumvent a legal first right of refusal agreement that the Pipeline Authority had with the Australian Gas Light Co.-is nothing short of disgraceful. It brings into question the whole integrity of government. If governments are going to play funny games like that with the legal processes of this country, then how can anyone expect there to be confidence in the integrity of government? That is what this issue is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wasn't it your policy to sell it?

—It still is, and we will follow the normal and proper legal commercial processes. We will not involve ourselves in sleazy, backdoor deals which pay no regard to legalities and which pay no regard to commercial practices.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it appropriate to speak on the Pipeline Authority's seventeenth annual report 1989-90 and trace the history of this pipeline, which, I note, is covered in the report. What the report indicates is the failure of these socialist ideologues who think something is going to be a good idea, and now we get to the point where it has come the full cycle and moves are afoot to sell the pipeline. It is worth recounting the background to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may be aware that back in about 1973, because of the discovery of gas up around the Moomba area, the Australian Gas Light Co. (AGL) moved to put a pipeline into Sydney. Of course, Sydney was the major potential user of gas. In stepped the then Minister for Minerals and Energy, the late Mr R. F. X. Connor, and nationalised the pipeline. How did he do it? What the Minister did was to go to AGL and the then Minister for Minerals in New South Wales, Mr Fife, who is in the other place these days, and said to him, `We are taking over the pipeline. We are going to do it by preventing AGL from bringing in pipe to pipe the gas'.

How does it all read? This was the great dream. I remind honourable senators that the late Mr Connor was the mentor of our current Treasurer, Mr Keating. In fact, Mr Keating has been described in various sectors of the media as being at the knee-I think that was the term used-of Mr Connor.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has grown up since then.
—I think a lot of people would debate that. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The first step involved construction of a pipeline linking...Sydney with the natural gas fields in the Cooper Basin in South Australia, with early extension through Wagga Wagga to Albury and Wodonga, and with ultimate extension-
listen to this for the wonderful dream; the Government was going to criss-cross Australia with pipelines at the expense of the taxpayers of Australia-

to Melbourne and the Bass Strait reserves. It was envisaged that the pipeline from the Cooper Basin would later be extended to the Palm Valley field in the Amadeus Basin of the Northern Territory. From there it was to continue to Dampier on the north-west coast of Australia where the resources of the North-west Shelf would be available, and to traverse and serve the Pilbara region of Western Australia. Also a spur was to serve the Northern Territory.
I think my colleague, Senator Tambling, is still waiting for that spur line. The report continues:

In the words of the then Minister for Minerals and Energy, the Pipeline Authority Act 1973 was introduced for the purpose of establishing `an authority with adequate powers to construct and operate a major public utility having the responsibility of making one of Australia's natural resources available to the Australian people'.

I recount that because we may be seeing the end of something that started out as one of those great dreams-the Taj Mahal of Australia; the sort of socialist nonsense that pervaded the country in those days under the guise of nationalism. I draw that to the attention of honourable senators because moves are now afoot to sell it. As mentioned by my colleague, Senator Short, the method the Government wishes to use to sell it is to get the consumers of the gas to pay the subsidy on which they will collect the capital for the sale of that pipeline which should never have been nationalised in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my colleagues Senator Short and Senator Parer concerning the now aborted proposed sale of the pipeline.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting that Mr Heinrich of the assets sale unit appeared before Estimates Committee A. Indeed, over a long and protracted period, in an attempt to get answers from Mr Heinrich, it finally emerged that the idea that if one simply increased the haulage costs one could get a greater price for the pipeline had emanated from that source. The idea that the Government could sell the assets of the Authority and not the Authority itself was part of the overall scheme to avoid the legal responsibilities which the Authority had entered into when it took over the building of the pipeline from AGL back in 1974. That negotiation was renegotiated in 1985. The heads of agreement which were to constitute the pipeline system's deed-they have never been executed; nonetheless the parties have operated in pursuance of the heads of agreement as if the deed had gone ahead-meant that the intention of the legal rights which AGL has ought properly to be honoured.

The cynical way in which the Government has created this scheme to bypass its legal obligations simply to produce artificially a higher price in no way took into consideration the sorts of things raised by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Greiner, such as the impact the increased cost of gas would have on production in New South Wales, and whether one of the major users of natural gas in New South Wales would continue to manufacture the product it uses the gas for in Australia or would look at the proposition of moving offshore. The Pipeline Authority purported to say that it had used the services of a consultant to determine that the increase in haulage prices would not result in a reduction in the volume of gas sold but as recently as today I received, as have some of my colleagues, a letter from Santos Ltd casting doubt over the ability of the consultant used to provide the sort of statistical information which the Pipeline Authority would have needed to work out its calculations.

This has been a sordid and sorry affair. It is probably not very usual that I would agree with a member of the lower House, Mr Frank Walker, on very many things. But on this occasion I think the words that he used-he described this exercise as grubby and said that he was ashamed to be associated with a government that would enter into such a grubby exercise-are sentiments with which I certainly can agree.
