SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Committee of Privileges into asbestos in Royal Australian Navy ships found that the Navy had not deliberately misled the Parliament. From the evidence which was given to the Committee and included in this report, it appears that is probably the case and I accept the Committee's finding. But the fact remains that the Parliament was misled, even though not perhaps deliberately. The Navy claims that its reply to my Estimates question:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . was not inaccurate in any material respect; nor should the reply have led to any misleading conclusions being taken.

In my view, that is an amazing statement, to say the least. The Navy told the Estimates Committee that it had introduced preventative measures in 1966 for asbestos, after research in the mid 1960s in the United Kingdom had pointed out the relationship between asbestos and certain diseases. What else was the Senate to assume-it could only be assumed that it was in the 1960s when the Navy first knew of this problem and thus took action. Yet its own submission to the Privileges Committee acknowledges that it has two files on the matter-apparently it could not find that until after I produced the documents to the Privileges Committee.

One file-file No. 177/51/39-was located in the Sydney regional office of the Navy. Another file-file No. N8411678-was found in the Canberra Navy Office. These files contained the documents that I presented to the Senate; that Senator Ray in this place told us did not exist in Navy files. The 1943 study at the Naval Dockyard, Williamstown in Victoria told us about the problems of inhaling asbestos dust, the danger, the need for ventilation and the need for respirators. It even talked about the possibility that one could get an asbestos related disease in a very short space of time.

Then there was a 1972 letter from the Department of the Navy to the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union agreeing that there was a health risk in handling asbestos and that this had been recognised by the Department since at least 1943 when that study I previously referred to was undertaken in Victoria. The letter also acknowledged that the safety instructions in 1972 had their beginnings in that 1943 test, had been constantly under review and had been considered satisfactory. So clearly, the Navy had known of the dangers of asbestos since 1943. The fact that the sum of knowledge about asbestos had increased since 1943 is immaterial. Yet, part of the Navy submission is based on that.

The Navy's submission to the Privileges Committee demonstrates that not only was the Senate misinformed; so also was the Chief of the Naval Staff. The submission quotes from a source document which had recently been prepared for the Chief of the Naval Staff. Unfortunately, the entire document was not tendered to the Privileges Committee. One wonders why? I put it publicly on the record now that I feel that the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) should make that document available to the Senate. It is suspicious that only parts of that document were quoted from before the Privileges Committee. One of the quotes was:

While the hazards of asbestosis were known in relation to continuous work with this material in asbestos factories and mines in 1943, the intermittent nature of the work with asbestos throughout the world was in 1943 considered essentially safe.

That is not true because the documents I have referred to make it clear that they knew it was not essentially safe, certainly in the Williamstown dockyard. The Navy's own files demonstrated that. I cannot understand the answer they gave to the Privileges Committee.

The Navy claims that the answer to the Estimates Committee was compiled in an hour. One has to ask why was such an important answer given such a short time to be compiled. But even putting that aside, the person who wrote the briefing note for the Chief of Naval Staff presumably had more than an hour, yet produced an inaccurate document.

This is not a nit-picking exercise. It is an important issue, and a particularly important occupational health and safety matter for those who have served in the Royal Australian Navy. I suspect that the briefing note was done in response to the announcement by the late Sir David Martin of his doctor's diagnosis of mesothelioma. But many other people throughout this country who are much less well known than Sir David Martin have been affected.

The Navy's submission claims that the documents I produced do not support the claims that the Navy `knew about the dangers of asbestos prior to the 1960s' in so far as those dangers were relevant to dockyard workers, and this attempt to obscure the issue is quite unacceptable. In fact, I find that the letter from the Secretary to the Department and Vice-Admiral Hudson to the Committee is disappointing in that they have claimed that neither the Navy nor the Department misled the Parliament in any material respect. Their submission does not satisfy me.

The facts are, first, that the Navy was aware of the health dangers from asbestos from at least 1943. Secondly, the Navy does have files on the subject which confirm this fact. Thirdly, the Navy did give the impression to the Senate that measures were introduced in the 1960s as a result of the knowledge that had come from the United Kingdom and in so doing gave the impression that this was the first time it became aware of the dangers. Fourthly, the Navy also misled its Chief of Naval Staff in its briefing note, and one wonders whether it has also misled the Government on this issue. Fifthly, the Navy claims that from 1968 it put preventive measures in place and enclosed them in the submission to the Privileges Committee. Yet I have statements here which make it quite clear that regardless of what safety precautions may or may not have been written-and they are here-as late as 1977-78, these precautions were not being followed at least on the refit of HMAS Brisbane. I quickly read some excerpts from statements I have received from former sailors. James Lawrence Kenna said:

During the course of the refit asbestos was stripped out of the ship. We used to wear masks and used plastic bags to put the asbestos in and the asbestos was then thrown in the rubbish. Other people would be in the area while we were getting the asbestos out doing their normal jobs and they would sometimes have a mask on and sometimes would not depending on what they were doing. The safety precautions in this regard were extremely cavalier.
He went on to say:

I recall that we were sent for chest x-rays when we were all on the Brisbane at Garden Island Naval Dockyard and this was an unusual move. I assumed at the time it was something to do with the asbestos but I never really found out for sure.
Steven Thomas Walsh said:

Asbestos was removed and no safety precautions were given to us at all for the removal of that asbestos except a small face mask. The persons actually removing the asbestos were given the face mask but there may have been 15 or 20 other men in the compartment and the dust was very very thick. They were given no protection at all.
Garry Roland Wilson said:

The asbestos was removed by naval personnel wearing masks but while this was being done the compartment was full of other sailors who had no protective gear whatsoever. The dust was extremely thick and lingered in the air for many days. The Garden Island Naval Dockyard personnel refused to work in the areas whilst delagging was being done and refused to remove the asbestos. They would actually leave the compartment while the asbestos was being removed.

One wonders whether those men, some of whom had an x-ray when they were doing the refit, were given the full plate chest x-rays annually that they were supposed to have been given after their exposure to asbestos. One wonders why some were working without respirators in confined spaces. One also wonders why the people were not kept to a minimum in compartments where asbestos was being stripped as required by the written regulations, and why some of the junior sailors were living on board the ship while asbestos was being removed from that ship, once again in contravention of those regulations.

The failure of the Navy to take the whole issue of asbestos seriously enough, whether by the enforcing of its own regulations, by the information available to the Chief of the Naval Staff and possibly to the Government, by answer made to the Parliament and by the self-incriminatory submission made to the Privileges Committee, places the Navy in a disappointing light, to say the least. It does not seem to be too concerned for the operational health and safety of its members. Why has that refit not been investigated by the Government, as I have repeatedly requested? Why have these former naval personnel not been contacted? The issue is too serious to be smoothed over. It will not go away. The Parliament and the people are not being adequately informed; and they have a right to know.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

—If the honourable senator would like to move that way, I suppose the Chair is obliged to accept her motion. I indicate, firstly, that it is my understanding that this information has been circulated to members of Estimates Committee C and should be in their offices.

—I might be wrong on that, but that was my understanding. Secondly, I have an idea that consideration of the report of Estimates Committee C will be going for a while yet.

—Mr Chairman, does that mean that, if any of the information that has just been tabled now relates to something that has already passed through the Committee, we can go back to it? I am in the Committee's hands, but it just seems to me that I should make the suggestion that I think the report of Committee C will continue to be considered for a little while yet.
—Could the Minister tell me to which section the additional information that we have just had tabled relates?

—What I am objecting to is the fact that, as late as this minute, additional information has been tabled in regard to Estimates Committee C when we are well down the track of asking questions on the information that we have been given. We have just been told that additional information has been given. I have not a clue what it is, and I do not know what it is about. I suggest that we at least report progress until we have had a look at what the information is about.

—The additional information is in relation to the Department of Community Services and Health, and we are not there yet. There are three pieces of information: one is a covering letter of 7 November 1990, the other is disability services program-employment, and the other is acquired immune deficiency syndrome statistics. The fact that we have not reached that Department yet seems to indicate to me that it would be probable for anybody who is interested to be able to see that fairly quickly and we could go on with the Department that we are on at the moment. Can you help further, Minister?

—Just to add to what you have said, Mr Chairman, the reality is that we have not finished arts yet. We have environment and tourism to go. I would have thought that environment would take quite a while. I doubt very much that we would be able to do it quickly. Senator Walters has plenty of time to go through the material. I do not think the procedure we have adopted today in tabling additional information is any different from what happens at every Estimates Committee. It is always the way. One gets information out as soon as one can. This morning I have been answering questions that were asked of me last night. As each bit of paper was given to me I would offer the information, and that is what we have always done. I do not think there is any need to hold proceedings up. We will keep going on environment, or whatever, and when we get to Senator Walters's matter she can raise it.

—That is fair enough. The Minister has to understand that Estimates Committee C does deal with Arts and the other departments that have already been passed. So long as the information deals only with community affairs, I will go and get the material and have a look at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, for your benefit and for that of Senator Richardson, I do not know how long we will be. I do not intend to speak for nearly as long as Senator Richardson would expect me to. I know that Senator Crane will speak. Senator O'Chee will also speak-he says that he will also be brief. Therefore, this discussion may not take as long as might have been anticipated.

SPEECH.PARA: I have only two aspects to query. I am not sure which I should deal with first but as they both come under environmental planning, I guess it does not matter. I will start with the one that Senator Richardson, no doubt, is expecting: the question of the grants and loans made to the Ravenshoe Mill to Plywoods and Plastics Pty Ltd.

At the Estimates Committee and subsequently, Senator Richardson indicated that he had received a report from the receivers of Plywoods and Plastics Pty Ltd. Throughout the Estimates Committee hearing both Senator Richardson and his advisers indicated that they could not make any commitments, could not make any further statements or could not answer questions implicitly until they received this report. A lot of emphasis was placed on the fact that the answers we sought in the Estimates Committee C would not be available until this report was received.

The report was subsequently received. We have been given little pieces of it. Indications were given to the Estimates Committee-in fairness, I will say that it was not an absolute undertaking-that the report would be made available providing there was no commercial in confidence stuff in it or other things that would make it confidential. The Minister has indicated subsequently in answers to questions in this chamber and questions on notice that he has not been in a position to make that report publicly available because further actions were likely to come as a result of it.

I now want to raise with the Minister whether it is possible for us and the Committee of the Whole to look at that report at this stage. I also want to raise with the Minister the current state of the results that flow from that report. I understand from the Minister's answers that the matter was referred to the Attorney-General's Department. That was several weeks, if not a month, ago. I know the Attorney-General's Department is very efficient. I wonder what progress has been made; where we have got to; and what action has been recommended, if any. Most importantly, I wonder whether a further inquiry might need to be instituted into events surrounding the giving of government moneys and loans to that mill; whether the moneys were used as they were supposed to be used; whether they were used at Ravenshoe as was intended or whether they have been used elsewhere; whether there were any criminal act or criminal actions engaged in by others; and what proceedings have resulted from those actions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the same reasons that I did not release the report before, I still cannot. To do so would prejudice Commonwealth action. The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories last corresponded with the Attorney-General's Department on this matter on 2 November. We do not have any response yet from the Attorney-General's Department, but clearly there is action contemplated. I have no problem with the eventual release of the report at a time when Attorney-General's tells us it is not likely to prejudice any action the Commonwealth might take. I am not in a position to give the honourable senator an idea of when that will be. I had hoped that we would get advice from the Attorney-General's Department shortly about what action it believes the Commonwealth should take, but we have not received that as yet.

SPEECH.PARA: Allegations have been made by many people that the money was not well spent at Ravenshoe and was, in fact, used in other places. Obviously that is, at least in part, covered by this report. That is what Attorney-General's is looking at now. We are just going to have to wait for that. We have asked the Attorney-General's Department to be as quick as it can in responding to us, and I would hope to have some sort of response within a matter of weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise another question with some hesitation because eventually I am going to get a definitive answer of no. But so far I have not and that leads me to live in hope that the matter is not yet completely closed. I again raise the matter which concerns me most, although the other things and the misspending of Government money are matters of concern in a very general way which we, as custodians of taxpayers' money, should be interested in, as I am. The thing that concerns me most-I am aware that it concerns Senator Richardson as well-is the money that was lent commercially by the business folk of Ravenshoe and elsewhere in north Queensland to the company in the expectation and on the understanding that, as a result of World Heritage listing, the Government was going to advance money to subsidise the company, to make grants for a 10-year period, to make sure that the mill was able to keep going.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that the Government did that in good faith, but I ask the Minister to accept-I think he does accept it-that in a non-legal but certainly very understandable way, the people of Ravenshoe gave credit to that mill because they believed that the Government would be funding it for the next 10 years. `Funding' is the wrong word, but I use it in a very broad sense. They did not even think that there would be problems in lending that money. The Government is not legally liable to pick up the bill-I acknowledge that-but I do say that these people have lost money by believing that the Government was going to be advancing money over a 10-year period.

I emphasise the point that if some companies lose $30,000 or $40,000 they can pick it up; it is just bad luck and a part of commercial reality these days. But when a small businessman whose only livelihood is this one entity in town lends $10,000, $20,000 or $30,000-or gives credit to that extent expecting it to be paid in 30 days-and does not get it back, he never really recovers. As I have said many times-the Minister is probably getting sick of hearing it-there are 12 families whose lives have been shattered, not really through any fault of their own; just because they believed the Government was going to be there for 10 years. I do not blame the Government for not being there for 10 years. I understand what has happened but, by the same token, it is not the fault of these people. Their lives have been shattered and ruined. Their children go to school there and now they have to move away. They cannot sell their houses in Ravenshoe because there is no-one who would buy them at a realistic price. So this has been an enormously traumatic experience.

This happens everywhere and I acknowledge that the Government cannot pick up every bankrupt person who lent money unwisely, but I continue to emphasise that this is a particular one-off situation. It is unique and it is unusual. It arose out of a whole series of events. There is no point in going back over these, but they were world media events. Even in London people knew what was happening, as well as all over Australia. It all got tied up in the history of the time. This is a flow-on. It is one of those things where I think nobody is at fault but someone has suffered-some 12 or so families have suffered.

Again I ask the Minister whether the matter is still being looked at. Has a submission been made, as the Minister generously said he would, to the current Minister? I know that money is tight but, in the overall course of things, with a Budget of $38 billion the amount involved here seems fairly small, particularly when money is given away in what appears to be a liberal way elsewhere. Can the Minister tell me where that submission is at, where we are going, and whether the door is finally closed yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — The door is not yet finally closed; it is ajar. I would not say that it is wide open. It is obviously a matter for sober and careful consideration because, if the Government were to pick up the bad debts of the company around the town of Ravenshoe, it would set an alarming precedent, and one wonders just how far that means the Government would be asked to go in the future. Senator Macdonald is quite right; we did have international publicity for the battle of Ravenshoe. I might say that in that battle I fought side by side with John Gayler. It was quite a team.
—No longer, I suggest. He has left you, hasn't he?
—I have spent years searching for loyalty in politics. It is often a forlorn search, but one learns to live with it. Ask Barry Cohen.
—That is a bit melancholy.

—It is not melancholy; it is realistic. After all those traumatic times, we sat down to draw up a package for north Queensland to ensure employment for people and obviously we had to rely upon the good will, indeed the good intent, upon the bona fides of those to whom we were giving money. It was always the case that we were going to give millions of dollars to that mill, and we relied upon the company to use it wisely and properly. If that has not occurred, Senator Macdonald is quite right in saying that, legally, the Commonwealth has no obligation. I might say that we never gave a hint, either, that we would be responsible for the company's operations. People may have interpreted it that way, but I think I can be certain in saying that all the Commonwealth ever did was say, `We will provide money to re-equip the mill, to retool it so that it can take on a pine resource and keep employing at least 40 people'. That was the real promise and we kept it. A funny thing happened on the way to the timber yard and it did not remain in that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have asked Mrs Kelly to consider whether or not further sums can be made available from the structural adjustment package to go to businesses in Ravenshoe. The door is not fully closed. I do not yet have a response from her. She has been overseas for the last few weeks and no doubt this is something she will have to discuss with other departments because of the precedent that it could set and the implications this kind of decision has. I am not sure that there is an inevitability of Senator Macdonald getting a negative answer at the end of the day. I have asked Mrs Kelly to consider whether or not it is possible to offer further assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly thank the Minister for that reply. I sincerely appreciate it and do not take issue with anything that he said. I probably agree with him that if we relive those days and if the person who threw the punch and almost hit the Minister had hit the Minister's companion, Mr Gayler, we might all have been better off. I am not a violent person, but I guess that the Minister and I are on very common ground on that aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: I take no issue with anything that the Minister said. I agree with all the points he has raised. If it is of assistance, I will try to find some words or some scheme which cannot let this be a precedent for the future. I fully understand that point. If it were treated as a precedent it would be a horrific one. I have tried to emphasise that this is a very special situation which evolved through a series of unique events that occurred over a period. It is different; it is not a usual situation; it is a one-off situation. There will never be another World Heritage listing battle of the type that went on in Ravenshoe nor will there ever be the sorts of compensation, packages, adjustments and government sympathy that followed from all of that. If I can find and use words that will not let that be a precedent, I will be only too happy to do so. If that will assist in the project, we will all be far better off. I will progress to the other matter I wish to raise very briefly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald, I wonder whether Senator O'Chee wishes to speak to the same matter that you have been speaking to. If that is the case, it might be better if his comments follow yours rather than your going on with a different matter. Do you follow me?
—Yes, I do follow you, Mr Chairman. If that is possible, that would certainly be the most appropriate way to proceed.

—I thank the Minister for his comments about the possibility of money being made available through the structural adjustment program. I also thank Senator Richardson for his representations to Mrs Kelly, albeit in her absence. I am sure that Senator Richardson will be most vigorous in pursuing it when Mrs Kelly comes back.
—She is back.

—Sorry. I wish to raise a couple of matters about this. I take issue with Senator Richardson over the understandings that people had of the Government's assistance. I do not wish to canvass that issue here at this time. We are in Committee of the Whole on Appropriations and we should be as expeditious as possible. Has any representation been made to the Department about the possibility of creating a joint venture project or a cooperative project to run the mill and take it over from the receivers with the effect of the unsecured creditors of the mill becoming shareholders of the mill in some sort of joint venture project with the Commonwealth Government?

—I was not aware that we had such a proposal, but we do. My understanding is that it is under consideration at present. I will have to get an up-to-date report on it and try, over the next few days, perhaps the next week, to get back to Senator O'Chee and tell him where it is up to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to ask the Minister any more questions about that at the moment. I accept his very generous undertaking to come back to me. I would like the opportunity to put a few comments on the record, perhaps for Senator Richardson and Mrs Kelly to consider during their deliberations on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson has intimated that one of his concerns is the danger that giving the money to the unsecured creditors might create a precedent. It appears to me that the possibility of a joint venture scheme could alleviate that set of circumstances. It would not in effect mean that the Commonwealth was doling out money to unsecured creditors of a mill for which the Commonwealth claimed it has no responsibility. The unsecured creditors would be turned into shareholders of the mill at no expense to the Commonwealth.

As I understand it and as has been intimated to me, the scheme would involve some sort of equity injection by the Commonwealth. This would be in the form of money needed to purchase the mill at `for sale' value from the receivers should no other purchaser be found. I hasten to stress the words `should no other purchaser be found'. The idea is that this would be a scheme of last resort. That would mean that the Commonwealth would have not a second or third ranking mortgage debenture but a real equity stake in the scheme. The unsecured creditors would have their debts cleared as their debts would be turned into equity capital in the company as well. I understand that it is suggested that the amount of unsecured debt would be roughly 50 per cent of the total equity capital of the joint venture company.

I believe this would have a very good chance of success at face value because all of the traditional suppliers of the mill would have a vested interest in ensuring that the mill was supplied with necessary raw materials at very competitive prices. Because the costings for the mill would be lower this would ultimately improve the possible viability of the mill over a long period. That is a very exciting prospect.

The other suggestion that has been made about this-I am not sure whether it has been included in the proposal-is the possibility that the Commonwealth's equity stake in the mill could be available for redemption, that is, purchased back by the company or be available for sale to other unsecured creditors in various tranches over a period. This would also ensure that the Commonwealth had some realistic prospect of getting back its equity stake. When the Commonwealth looks at it, that is also very important. The other suggestion raised-I am not sure whether it is included in the proposal-is that, under another variation on this scheme, some of the Commonwealth loan money might be repaid on the proviso that the Commonwealth continue under the provisions of the assistance package to make operational maintenance subsidies over a period.

I stress the point that nobody wants to see the mill close. It would be remiss of anybody to suggest that that was the case. We want the mill to continue to be a viable ongoing concern. SPEECH.PARA: The first concerns the Medicare system. It is a very unusual system. Charges are raised by individual medical practitioners following consultations with individual patients, and the money is then paid by Government per the Health Insurance Commission. It obviously is predicated upon the honest operation of the system by the medical practitioners involved. Therefore, as a doctor, I am very sensitive to any information which comes my way which suggests that members of my profession-and it is a minority of people-are in any way misusing the system. I have become aware from an impeccable source, which is not appropriate to identify here, and also by reading some of the reports of medical board proceedings that some medical practitioners have been sleeping with their patients and then claiming a Medicare rebate for that attendance. That is highly unprofessional conduct but that is a question for the medical board. My concern is that as the law stands, if the attendance is one which is a professional attendance, as it is defined, given by a registered person, it is necessary that a Medicare benefit be paid.

The present law is obviously defective in this small area. It has become apparent recently and it needs to change. A process has been put in train by the Department, a process with which I completely concur. I have had some very helpful letters from the First Assistant Secretary of the Health Care Access Division, Mr NcNeil, on this matter. It seems that the Department has set up some discussions between itself, the Health Insurance Commission and the Australian Medical Association (AMA) in an attempt to settle some amendment to the relevant section of the Act to overcome this problem. The problem then is that it requires the redefinition of the words `professional service'. It may require their redefinition in a certain way, and the Department has proposed that they should be redefined in the following way:

. . . a medical service to which an item relates, being any medical examination, treatment, or test that is appropriate and reasonably necessary for the adequate management of the patient's medical condition that is rendered by or on behalf of a medical practitioner . . .
That would add the extra test, as it were, that it was appropriate and reasonably necessary.

What has happened is that the AMA has had some concern about the implication of that change. The last letter I had from Mr McNeil dated 31 October included a letter from the Assistant Secretary General of the AMA, Mr W. Coote, to Mr Col Bailey of the Medicare Benefits Branch, in which he identified that the AMA had some continuing difficulties with the proposal as to what it might mean. But he did say this:

On the face of it, the proposal gives to the Health Insurance Commission the discretion to make a judgment that services are `appropriate', `reasonable', et cetera before paying Medicare benefits. This would appear to be a substantial departure from the existing presumed entitlement to the payment of Medicare benefits.
Although he was more or less cooperative in his approach, he said that the matter would have to be referred further to the AMA.

All I want from the Minister, who was present during the examinations so he knows the matter which I am talking about, is his agreement, if he is willing to give it, that the situation that is now revealed is really an unacceptable one, because it is quite clear that there is a weakness in it. I would like his agreement that it is desirable that we pursue that process of consultation-the one I have just described involving the three main parties-and that we achieve as a result of that consultation an amendment to the relevant section of the Act. That is what is really required. The third thing I hope the Minister can give us is a commitment that this will be achieved within a fairly rapid time, because I think this is a loophole that should be closed off quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I referred to in my letter of reservations was my concern about the Therapeutic Goods Administration of the Department of Community Services and Health. If the Commonwealth has determined that it will require certain steps to be undertaken by drug companies before they can market pharmaceuticals in Australia, if the Government has then laid down what those processes shall be, and as they are regarded as being among the most stringent in the world, it is incumbent upon the Government to assess those drugs, to assess the applications, to do it expeditiously and to meet its side of the bargain.

The Government is not meeting its side of the bargain and the Therapeutic Goods Administration is failing to discharge its duty. That is the difficulty. It is failing to give fair dealing to the pharmaceutical industry. If it wants to carry out its assessments and reject applications it may do so, but what we have had to deal with is a series of problems. The first is that the Therapeutic Goods Administration cannot recruit people to do its work, and at Estimates examination after Estimates examination, it was revealed to us that the establishment has many unfilled positions. If the Government cannot fill the positions, the Government must stand at fault. If it cannot pay market rates, it has got to find some other way to attract people to these jobs, because the Government has an obligation to carry out its side of the regulatory process.

There are three parts of the regulatory process. One of them relates to clinical assessment of whether the particular drugs are any good-whether they do anything; whether they are safe; whether there is evidence to support claims for their efficacy and so on. It is quite apparent that the Therapeutic Goods Administration is failing in this area and failing lamentably. I believe I am correct in saying that there was a very senior review of the whole Therapeutic Goods Administration area two or three years ago which recommended major changes to this part of the Department. They may have been implemented, but it still does not work. Not only that, but when we questioned the Therapeutic Goods Administration we discovered two other quite alarming matters.

The first is that this country has entered into some arrangements with Sweden. The purpose of these arrangements was to allow us to use Swedish information and to allow the Swedish Government to use our information, thereby hopefully advancing and quickening the approval or non-approval of therapeutic drugs. It turns out that the Swedish Government has been using our assessments, but certainly in the area of clinical trials we have not been using the Swedish ones. The evidence we were given from the officers at the Estimates examination is that they do not regard the Swedish data as adequate for our purposes. That is simply not good enough. On the one hand they cannot get enough officers to assess and process the applications and on the other hand they have an agreement with Sweden which they will not use because they do not like Swedish standards. It is up to the Government as the policy making body to knock a few heads together and to give some instructions or possibly to reconstruct the whole division and the whole process.

The third thing that alarmed me was that when at the Estimates meeting I asked some questions about the length of time which it took to process applications, I received an answer from the Department which was vastly different from the answer I received from the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association (APMA). So being a reasonable person I then asked the officers to go away and try to reconcile the two sets of figures. I have received a very courteous letter from Mr Peter Pflaum, the National Manager of Therapeutic Goods Administration. By the way, when I was Minister of that Department, I had high regard for Mr Pflaum and I imagine I still do. It does not mean that the area over which he presides is operating well because it is not.

It turns out that the processing time which the officers gave was for a favourable three-month period during 1990, that they had omitted an unfavourable processing time over the summer of 1989-90, and that the APMA had been using the processing time for 272 drugs between 1981 and 1989. The differences between their figures were quite marked. The APMA believed that it took 14.4 weeks between the receipt of a general marketing application and a decision on its acceptability for further processing-not approval, but just its acceptability to go on to someone's desk to be approved. The average time between 1981 and 1989 was 14.4 weeks. If that were done in business, those concerned would be out of business. I could not obtain any kind of justification.

The Government now says that the average time taken during a particular three-month period selected during this year was 36 working days. The only other comment there is that, when we asked about the target times which the Therapeutic Goods Administration had set, it turns out that not one of them is being achieved.

First, let us congratulate the Therapeutic Goods Administration on setting some target times, times to which people will work, but let us acknowledge that it is not meeting one of them. How are companies supposed to operate in this country if they cannot even have their applications accepted or dealt with? I raise the case of one company which had its application sent back four times before it was accepted for further processing, and on each occasion for different reasons.

The question is this: does the Government agree that there is an obligation, if we are to have a stringent system of evaluation for therapeutic goods, that the Government should deliver on its side? That means delivering on the processes and within reasonable time. If it is now clear that the Therapeutic Goods Administration is incapable, at least as to part of its administration, of delivering in this way, will the Government undertake to look at the matter and possibly to reform the whole area?
