We hope that the sorts of figures which are emerging of an improved rate of dealing with applications will be continued into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: -My question relates to program 1.3, regarding the national Aboriginal health strategy. I want to know what appropriation for that strategy has been provided to the Department of Community Services and Health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The national Aboriginal health strategy represents a new commitment to cooperation by all governments-Commonwealth, State and Territory-and Aboriginal communities to work together to address the unacceptably low level of health experience by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The recommendations contained in the strategy were considered by a development group established by Commonwealth and State Ministers to advise on structural arrangements for dealing with Aboriginal health matters recommended in the strategy and to develop areas for early action. That is a general description of the program.

SPEECH.PARA: I am told that in relation to that strategy no decision has yet been taken on funding, and that is why one does not find an appropriation. The formal endorsement of the 21 major recommendations put forward by the development group occurred, I am advised, on 10 June 1990. That tripartite strategy between the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and various governments-Commonwealth, States and Territories-is a matter of great concern. The parameters for implementing that strategy and the way in which it will require appropriations of moneys are matters still to be taken either in the supplementary Budget or the full Budget process next year. I understand that the national Aboriginal health strategy generally is intended to be funded on a 50:50 cost-shared basis. I presume that that would form the basis for any appropriation of Commonwealth moneys to support this phase of the strategy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Minister says that it is on a 50:50 cost share basis, does he mean 50:50 between the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs? Secondly, on page 54, subprogram 1.3 of the explanatory notes for the Department of Community Services and Health, it is stated in relation to the national Aboriginal health strategy that the Department provides public health policy and medical advice to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. This would seem to indicate that there should be an appropriation for the national Aboriginal health strategy under the Department of Community Services and Health. Further down on the same page it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Following consideration of the report `A National Aboriginal Health Strategy' by a joint meeting of Ministers for Community Services and Health and Aboriginal Affairs in March 1989, the Development Group was established-
I think that is the group to which the Minister was referring-
to report on arrangements dealing with matters recommended in that report.
Is the Department of Community Services and Health involved in that development group and, if so, is there any appropriation for these activities?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just clarify one matter early in Senator Patterson's question. The 50:50 cost share basis I was referring to is between the Commonwealth and the States, that is, on a half and half shared basis between the Federal Government and the State and Territory governments. I understand that the whole question of funding for the strategy is a matter for further announcement and I am able to give some more precision on that. It is hoped that Ministers Howe and Tickner will announce something about that towards the end of this year and get the matter on the public record and under way at about that time.

SPEECH.PARA: As to Senator Patterson's final question about whether the Department of Community Services and Health is represented on the development group, I do not have an officer present who can give me an answer, but I imagine it would have some input-if not directly, certainly by way of comment on the strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —We asked questions on notice about the average number of children being cared for by the services under the multifunctional Aboriginal children's services program, program 8. The reply was that the Department provided numbers for the utilised places for each of these services. I do not want to hold up the Committee but I wonder whether the Minister could ensure that we get those figures. No explanation was given as to what was meant by a utilised place, what period the term utilised place referred to, the average number of children being cared for by each service or the types of child-care that were being provided to these children. I would appreciate it if the Department could make available at some time the answers to those questions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Patterson for her consideration for the time of the Committee of the Whole and I assure her that I will get those answers to her office by the end of tomorrow before the Senate rises.

—I would like to direct the attention of the Committee to program 6.2, the pharmaceutical benefits scheme claims transmission system (CTS). Is it possible for the Committee or me to be provided with a copy of the determination under paragraph 98(C)(1)(b) of the National Health Act that was made on 16 March 1990 and revoked by the determination that came into effect on 1 August 1990? I asked what differences there were between the March and the August determinations-as another set of determinations was brought down in August-and not the differences between the determination before the CTS rules were added to it and the determination that exists now. I think the Department got my question a bit mixed up, or I may not have made it clear. What I really wanted to know was the difference between the March determination and the August determination. If we could have a copy of the March one, since we have a copy of the August one, we could do it ourselves. The August determination made pursuant to paragraph 98(C)(1)(b) of the National Health Act 1953 requires users of the compulsory transmission scheme to record an identifier for general patients. What I am interested to know is what is the compliance rate by pharmacists with regard to this requirement. Would failure to comply with this requirement mean that a pharmacist could be suspended from using the CTS system for six months? Would a suspension mean that a pharmacist would not be able to make claims?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As to Senator Patterson's request to be provided with the determination of 16 March under section 98(C)(1)(b), that can be provided and will be provided as soon as it can be transmitted to her office. Secondly, she asked what is the compliance rate with the determination of 1 August and what consequences follow from non-compliance. Senator Patterson will be delighted to know that the officers here indicate that compliance has been 100 per cent and therefore the question she raised has not been a practical problem. But I certainly undertake to give her in writing an answer as to the consequences that could follow should there be non-compliance by a pharmacist. It is a proper question, but there is no urgency on the ground as compliance has apparently been very forthcoming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the written answer to my question about changes to the determination it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: These rules (originally CTS rules) were a disallowable instrument. In due course they were examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which requested some changes. After the changes were made the Rules were not disallowed.

It seemed to me that those original rules were brought in under section 99AAA of the National Health Act 1953. I may have got the sequence of this incorrectly and I would appreciate it if the Department could enlighten me, but the March set of determinations seemed to have been brought in under paragraph 98(C)(1)(b) which does not require those determinations to be tabled and under which they are not disallowable. At page 410 of Estimates Committee C hearings I asked Ms Ford about the August set of determinations, which revoked the March set, and how pharmacists were to know about them-I would like the Minister to look at these determinations because they have quite serious implications for pharmacists-and she replied:
The determinations that I sign are published in the Gazette.
Then when I read the written answers from the Department they state:
The determination is neither gazetted or tabled as this is not required by the legislation.

I would like the Department to clarify for me which of those is true. On the one hand, Ms Ford is telling me that they are gazetted and, on the other hand, the written answer is that they are not gazetted or tabled. As it is important that pharmacists know, I would like to know what really does happen.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers with me this afternoon cannot answer the question of whether determinations made under 98(C)(1)(b) need to be tabled or not or whether they are disallowable or need to be gazetted, so I am afraid I cannot answer that. But it is such an important matter on which we really need to get an answer, not by tomorrow evening but as soon as possible, that I will ask somebody to make a phone call to find out. I cannot help any further on that at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two questions here: firstly, are the determinations required to be tabled; and, secondly, are they disallowable? It is my understanding that they are not. The Department tells me one thing in one breath and something else in another.

SPEECH.PARA: I was so concerned when I saw the Senate determinations that I actually asked for some legal advice on their status. If they are items or instruments that were to be tabled and disallowable, what sorts of comments could we have expected from senators? What sorts of comments would I have been able to make in that situation? I received the following legal advice on those determinations-and with the Minister's legal background, I know that he will be interested in this:

There is a considerable number of discretions exercisable under the Determination. Some are unimportant but others seem important. Under section 98c (2) of the Act, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal may be requested to make a report with respect to the matters dealt with in a Determination. In view of the number of discretions, it would be reasonable to ask if such a report had been made.
I do not know whether such a report has been made, but I doubt it. The legal advice continues:

I noted discretions in paragraphs 5, 6 (a) (i), (ii), (iii), and (iv), (b) and (c), 23, 24, 25, 35, 37, 38 (f), 39, 40 (f) and (g), 41 and 42. No criteria are specified for the exercise of most of the discretions-
discretionary powers are given in each paragraph-
and in relation to many of them there may not need to be so.
However, in paragraph 38 there are criteria specified which will render a computer system unacceptable to the General Manager.
They seem appropriate until paragraph 38 (f) which provides that a system may be unacceptable if ``the General Manager deems the system to be unacceptable''.

I think the Minister and I both agree that that is pretty unacceptable in a set of determinations. Again, paragraph 40 provides criteria under which a claim may be of an unacceptable standard. Paragraph 40 (g) provides that it is unacceptable if the general manager deems a claim to be of an unacceptable standard. In both of these cases the result of the exercise of the general manager's discretion could be of significance. There is no requirement provided in the determination for the general manager to give reasons for the decision, nor any provisions for any independent review of the merits of the decisions. As far as I can see, there are no provisions for any independent review.

There are at least three further discretionary decisions that may affect livelihood. First, paragraph 37 provides that an approved pharmacist or approved medical practitioner whose computer system becomes unacceptable to the general manager cannot use the claims transmission system. Secondly, paragraph 39 provides that the pharmacist or medical practitioner may be suspended from using the claims transmission system. Either of these two could occur under the open-ended discretion, which I have referred to, given in paragraph 38 (f) or for other reasons. Thirdly, where a pharmacist or medical practitioner is suspended under paragraph 39, he or she shall not be reinstated until a period of at least six months has elapsed since the date of suspension. So we have a situation where a pharmacist might not be in receipt of remuneration from the Department. I think the Minister would agree that the serious consequences that could flow from the exercise of these discretions emphasise the importance of giving the reasons for the exercise of discretions.

Of even greater importance, there appears to be no provision for independent review of any of the discretions either in the determination or in the Act. There are provisions in the Act for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of some decisions made under the Act but those provisions do not cover the present discretions, the exercise of which would impact on the livelihood of pharmacists or medical practitioners.

There is reference to possible powers of entry. Paragraphs 33 and 36 refer to `operational testing' and meeting `operational audit requirements'. It is not clear to me how these procedures would be carried out and whether they would possibly require entry onto premises or property. If so, there do not appear to be any protective provisions covering this aspect.

Some of the provisions appear to raise privacy questions that may affect pharmacists, medical practitioners and patients. These questions would relate especially to unauthorised computer entry and to the integration of data. I have asked questions about the computer transmission system. We are talking about the system that goes through the telephone line, not the proposed one. The computer transmission system was to be compulsory by February. I stand to be corrected, but now it has been extended to June. I was told in Estimates that it is the most easy to get into system of all; the hackers can get into it. The fact that a senator in this place, a member of the House of Representatives, or a prominent business person is taking some particular drug, or whatever else, can go down the line. That just seems to me totally unacceptable.

We have a set of determinations that do not require tabling and are not disallowable. I hope that the Minister will refer this matter to the Minister responsible and ask that he addresses and looks at, as I am doing, the National Health Act. He should look at various clauses concerned with the making of instruments in respect of which there is the likelihood that the rights of individuals could be denied-for example, the right of review of fairly serious decisions that have been made in a department. I hope that these issues will be addressed on both sides of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that Senator Patterson has raised a very worthwhile point for the consideration of the Senate Committee of the Whole. Perhaps it is particularly apt that it be raised in the Committee. However, I doubt whether the determination and the exercise of certain discretions by the general manager whereby the computer system could be unacceptable simply because it is deemed to be unacceptable by the general manager-if that is a correct reading of the paragraph 38 and the determination-would have survived scrutiny by the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances of this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Patterson has raised some matters which I will certainly bring to the attention of the Minister, given the link between the determination or the exercise of the discretion by the general manager and the impact that could have. For example, with a six-month suspension of use of the claims transmission system the impact on the livelihood of the pharmacist and those dependent on him and his pharmacy is quite evident.

That is all linked back to the question which I am unable to answer as to the exact status for tabling or the nature of these particular determinations as disallowable instruments or, quite apart from that, the simple publicity which ought to be given to them, whether in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette or by some other means, in order to enable pharmacists to become aware of them. In that regard, though, I suppose if the answer I was previously able to give the honourable senator, as advised to me by officials, is correct, that the determination of 1 August has been complied with in all cases nationwide, it is clear that either the professional bodies of the pharmacists in their various guilds and associations, or the Department by perhaps direct contact with the pharmacies, is making the determination and its provisions available to pharmacies to enable them to comply. However, the question of the exercise of discretions which can have such a marked effect on livelihood is one of genuine interest to the Committee and I will certainly bring it to the attention of the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise another issue with the Minister. It is quite obvious that one reason for compliance currently is that the people who are using the claims transmission system (CTS) are using it on a voluntary basis; it is not yet compulsory. One might find that the compliance rate is not quite as successful when it is compulsory. That might be one explanation for the current compliance rate.

SPEECH.PARA: Irrespective of that, if one person fails to comply-the Minister and I have drawn attention to this-and it is deemed by the manager that the system is not satisfactory, that is one too many who will not have the benefit of the process of review to put his case forward. The determination does not allow for that. That is what concerns me.

The other thing that concerns me is that we have seen the introduction of the computer transmission system through the use of a determination which, as far as I have been able to gather-and I have had people look at the legislation for me-was not tabled nor did it appear to be disallowable so we would come to the conclusion that that section of the Act does not require the instrument to be tabled or allow it to be disallowed. We have seen the introduction of the computer transmission system through the use of this clause.

The interactive system, or the black box as it has come to be known, has caused quite a deal of concern in the community, especially among pharmacists. At the end of last year the original proposal was withdrawn on the basis of the disapproval by the Privacy Commissioner and the Pharmacy Guild of the system. I am concerned-I think I express the concerns of many of my colleagues on this side of the chamber-that there is no assurance, because of the way in which the CTS system has been introduced, that the interactive processing system will not be introduced in the same way, that is, by way of delegated legislation which is not subject to tabling or disallowance. That may be the very way in which the interactive processing system is introduced.

I do not expect the Minister to give me this assurance but I hope that the Minister responsible will give an assurance at some stage-the earlier the better-that the interactive processing system will not be introduced in a way that does not enable the instrument to be tabled or disallowed. It seems to me that that is a very sensitive issue. It has great privacy implications. It would only be appropriate that the Minister and the Department table that proposed delegated legislation before the Parliament and allowed adequate and proper scrutiny.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the question of electronic communication and the impact it might have on privacy considerations and security of data is a very real one. The need for the Privacy Commissioner and the Pharmacy Guild to be thoroughly involved in the consultations is self-evident, given the experience to which Senator Patterson alluded last year. As far as the involvement of the Privacy Commissioner and the Pharmacy Guild are concerned, I can give an assurance that that will be undertaken. The Privacy Commissioner will be involved in establishing the guidelines under the legislation to be introduced in this area. Those guidelines will be authorised by Kevin O'Connor, the Privacy Commissioner. I am unable to give an answer as to the status of those guidelines when published under the legislation. I will see whether drafting instructions have been issued which would indicate whether they are to be disallowable in the sense that it has been of concern to us this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On page C395 of the Hansard of Estimates Committee C of 25 September it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Dial-up arrangements-
that is, the transfer by modem-
are the most vulnerable of any system . . .

I guess the problem involves people illegally dialling into the system. What security arrangements are in place to protect the information provided to pharmacists and transferred to the Health Insurance Commission?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that about 400 pharmacists use modems for the direct transmission of claims on a monthly basis. The claims transmission scheme is based on Telecom Australia's Austpac network. The only change seen by the pharmacists since the transfer of pharmaceutical claims processing to the Health Insurance Commission has been a new telephone number to redirect traffic to the Commission. Initially claims transmissions were processed by the former Department of Health's computer.

SPEECH.PARA: As to security, each pharmacist has a separate user ID and password that are checked by the system. There are two other security obstacles that need to be negotiated before access is granted. Once access is granted, it is only for one-way traffic, that is, for the pharmacist to lodge claims with the Commission. This data is checked before being accepted as a valid claim. At present no data is returned or can be obtained by the pharmacist.

In summary, there are at least four security checks-user ID, password and two other checks-before a claim is received. In view of the stringent security conditions imposed, I think that Senator Patterson can see that an attempt has been made to allay the proper concerns that she has raised. Any extensions to the electronic communication will be with the authorisation of the Privacy Commissioner and the Pharmacy Guild. That terminology is stronger than the words that I used a moment ago when I said that the Privacy Commissioner and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia could be consulted. The briefing note I have uses that strong term `authorisation'. I believe that it indicates the concern of the Government to ensure that the Privacy Commissioner's assessment of the security and privacy safeguards that ought to be in place is observed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of questions. I do not expect the Minister to answer them here but I would appreciate it if the Department of Community Services and Health would provide me with an answer. When the Health Insurance Commission moves to interactive processing which will involve a dedicated network rather than a dialling-in, what security safeguards will there be to protect information that is being transferred? Will any attempt to access the system illegally be detected and recorded? How many people and what classes of people within the HIC will have password access to the information? In addition to detecting and recording any illegal access, will that access be tracked and, if so, how? I do not expect the Department to provide an answer now because the questions are quite complicated. Obviously this will come up in the first half of next year and I think that we should be as informed as possible about the development of this process so that we can fully examine the quite considerable privacy issues involved in that exercise.
—I will undertake to obtain those answers for Senator Patterson.
—I am sorry; I will start again because my microphone was not working. As we mentioned before--
—I preferred it the other way, Senator.

—I thank the Minister. Thousands of people who want to listen to the broadcast of parliamentary proceedings are unable to do so because their radios cannot tune into the altered frequency. I cannot even get it in my office in Melbourne. The members of my staff there would not have gone home yet but it would be no good sending them a cheerio call because they would not hear it.
—Come to Estimates E.

—I will do so or I will be ruled out of order in a moment. We were talking about the black box proposal which Dr Blewett withdrew on the basis of the disapproval of the system by the Privacy Commissioner and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. I would be very pleased if the Senate could be told or provided with any documentation as to why the Privacy Commissioner and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia disapproved of the original proposal, on what grounds and how far the new proposal will differ from the original proposal, apart from the fact that Medicare cards will be used.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —At a slightly later date I can provide a general answer to the question as to the improvements sought by the Privacy Commissioner, given some concerns he had with the system which was proposed. The major difference between the two is that this one has the approval of the Privacy Commissioner and the former proposal did not. That is sufficient for the Government to revamp and restructure the matter. I cannot and will not give an undertaking to provide the detailed documentation because the discussions that the Minister or the Department may have had with the Privacy Commissioner may be such that it need not be made available. However, I will get information which makes it clear what the major concerns were and how they have been addressed and remedied in the proposal before us.

-Under this system, will the Commonwealth entitlement file and Medicare enrolment files be matched? If so, am I right in presuming that the Privacy Commissioner will be aware of that matching process?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the two files mentioned by the honourable senator will be matched and, of course, that matching process will be one of the matters which the Privacy Commissioner will put under scrutiny. I further advise that, whilst a single entitlement database reflecting Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits scheme entitlements is proposed, the Commission has given assurances to the Privacy Commissioner that it is not prepared to match claims data from one program against claims data from the other program, meaning the passing of major portions of whole files against each other for the purpose of finding out information about an individual which might not otherwise be available.

SPEECH.PARA: Merging of data is intended to occur only at an individual level where abuse is suspected and where there is reason to believe that the data of one program may be relevant to the explanation of the abuse or to the abuse occurring in the other program. I think that gives an indication of what triggers this process. To allay the honourable senator's major concerns, the answer is that no doubt the Privacy Commissioner has required certain assurances in this area and they have been given to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would appreciate it if the Department could give me some information about the Medicare enrolment file. Would pharmacists and their staff have access to it under the new system? When we have the interactive system, what will happen if the computer tells the pharmacist, when he sends the information down the line, that there has been a mismatch and the person is not eligible for the benefit? That person could be a pensioner and, instead of paying $2.50, he or she will be required to pay the higher price that you, Mr Chairman, or I would pay. Despite my confidence in the Department of Community Services and Health, there will be errors and there will be errors in the social security data.

SPEECH.PARA: As I kept saying in the Estimates committees, what this is all about is the clients at the other end-the patients in the pharmacy. What happens to those people? Will there be any leeway? Will the pharmacist be able to make a judgment about it and decide that, as he has known the person for a long time, he knows he will be reimbursed although the pharmacist bears the cost? What checks and balances will come into play to ensure that people are not left having to either pay out or go without the drug unless the pharmacist bears the cost?

A pharmacist I spoke to the other day told me that what sometimes happens, and what he believes will happen with the new minimum pricing policy, is that if he cannot find the doctor to get a scrip changed and he knows the person awfully well he bears the difference in the cost. Frankly, that is hopeless. Is that what we are forcing pharmacists to do because they have such a commitment to their patients? As one or two pharmacists have said to me, when they know people because they have been going to their pharmacy for 20 or 30 years and they are ill but they cannot get the doctor who has written a scrip for a drug which is not at the minimum price, they will be likely to give them the more expensive drug and bear the cost.

When we develop all these wonderful systems at the coalface-or, in this case, the pharmacyface-we see that things do not always come out smoothly. I have a picture of a pensioner standing in a pharmacy, there being a mismatch on the interactive system and his being told that he is not entitled to his benefit, despite the fact that the pharmacist knows that he is a pensioner and has known him for a long while. I suppose if the pharmacist does that he will be guaranteed his money, but he is going to slow it down. What is the cost to the pharmacist of the bureaucratic involvement he has to go through to ensure that he gets his remuneration in this case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Patterson's first question in the series, I am advised that the pharmacist will only get confirmation of eligibility. As to her second question, it is true that errors may occur and that for some unfortunate reason advice may be received by a pharmacist that a particular person is not eligible for a reduced payment in regard to the pharmaceutical item and yet the pharmacist, knowing the person, may well understand that the person is indeed a pensioner, for example. I believe that in that situation a pharmacist can make the pharmaceutical item available as though the benefit was properly authorised. But in doing so, the pharmacist takes a certain risk.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that is not so much a hopeless situation as a very sensible human situation whereby the pharmacist, as the honourable senator says, having known a customer for a period of years-perhaps even decades-understands the situation and is prepared to bring in the human element to override the evident possibility of failure of the best advised machine or computer system. I believe that is a nice human element to which she has drawn our attention which keeps our society the civilised and compassionate society that it is. As to the same matter, more or less, arising between the pharmacist and the customer where there is a problem as to the doctor's authorisation in regard to a higher priced drug and there is a lesser priced drug available, that problem has already been a feature of pharmacy distribution and a modus vivendi has arisen in relation to its resolution. The main point I am trying to make is that there will be room in the guidelines as put forward to allow for the pharmacist to exercise proper discretion in these areas where he or she knows the situation well from experience with the particular customer.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would like to know when the Government intends to issue a request for tender for the interactive processing system. Also, will the technology include a magnetic swipe card and/or a facility for smart card technology?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is intended that the legislation be passed; in other words, that the Parliament express its will very clearly on this matter before the intended process is undertaken.

-The Minister will be pleased to know that this is my last question on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. What estimated annual savings will accrue from moving the dial-up system to the dedicated line system? The Department has worked out that the savings will be $25m per year under the Medicare card system and $10m per year under the claims transmission system. This is my reading of it and I would like to have it confirmed. I would like to know whether I am correct in saying that this is what the estimated annual savings will be. I ask whether these are net or gross estimates. Do they take into account the additional work for pharmacists? Do the estimated savings-in my estimation, $15m maximum-justify the privacy intrusion of a person possibly having his or her Medicare card swiped at a pharmacy-I think the Minister knows what I mean by `swiped'-and having pharmacy staff maybe having access to HIC files?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told by the officers that they stand by those savings estimates. Savings in benefits payments would be the best way to describe them. As I say, they stand by those figures. As to whether savings of whatever dimension, be they savings of $15m, $20m, $25m or whatever, are worth intrusion into privacy, it is an unfortunate fact that Australia is relying very heavily on fiscal discipline. I am sure that Senator Patterson's party room is very conscious of the need for this discipline; it keeps telling us that we should exercise a greater discipline in this regard, though that is an incredible burden to put on us.

SPEECH.PARA: The savings are made up of the $15m, the $20m and the $25m. That is the arduous process that is undertaken by the Expenditure Review Committee, and it is very painful. It would be very easy if all the decisions taken were such that we got savings or achieved less expenditure in the many hundreds of millions. Unfortunately, as Ministers would know, that is not the case, except for some very big items. As I say, it is an accumulation of these sorts of savings of $15m here and $25m there that adds up to the surplus which has been such a beneficial feature of the Budgets presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) over the last several years.

It would not be worth it if the privacy intrusions were so gross as to bring down the wrath of the Privacy Commissioner on the head of the Government. That has been avoided by the process of consultation to which I have referred. Indeed, it will play a very key role in further development of the programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all know that there are increased costs related to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, but perhaps there can be savings of that order with the CTS system and maybe other savings made by reducing the dependence of Australians on prescription drugs. Comparative figures between Australia and other countries are appalling. Australians take far too many drugs. I would like to see less intrusion into privacy and other methods of educating people. We seem not to do that. We like to legislate and regulate rather than let people make decisions and choices. If we were to educate them as to effective and proper use of drugs, we could hopefully reduce our pharmaceutical costs and improve the health of the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that I deserve an ideological serve, having given Senator Patterson one in my response before. We have the national campaign against drug abuse. In this Australia-wide campaign all the Ministers for health and police Ministers from all jurisdictions-Federal, State and Territory-join together.

SPEECH.PARA: The abuse of pharmaceuticals is a very real problem in our deliberations, along with the abuse of illegal drugs, alcohol and tobacco. Indeed, as I recall, a campaign that was authorised and shown on television early last year dealt precisely with the hoarding and overuse of drugs of a prescribed variety or which could be obtained through pharmacies. I agree with Senator Patterson that much more needs to be done on that score to try to reduce the incidence of unnecessary taking of drugs in our society. We are indeed a drug ridden society. If we could reduce that incidence it would not only help the health of the individuals concerned but also considerably reduce government expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister tell us the present position of the redundancy package that is presently being negotiated between the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Government?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the negotiations and consultations are at the stage just short of signing by the representatives of the pharmacists and that that process is apparently at its very final stages.
—Could the Minister tell me the date the Guild knocked back the previous package
—Does Senator Walters mean the pre-election package or the package since the election?
—I believe that it was just last weekend or around that time; very recently.

—I understand from officers that a formal full-blooded rejection, to which Senator Walters seems to be referring, is not known to them. As I said, we are still in the final round of negotiations. It is expected that those negotiations will be successfully concluded.
—Is the Minister indicating that the Guild knocked back some of the propositions the Government had put, but not the total package?

—All that I am able to say and the officers are able to tell me is that the negotiations are taking place. I imagine that in that context, as with any true negotiations, there will be elements which will be attractive and others which will be knocked back-to use Senator Walters's terminology-in the negotiating process. The final package which is concluded and which will be put to the governing body of the Guild, I guess, is the important one. There will be steps along the way where there will be disparities between what the Government puts forward and what the pharmacists are prepared to accept.
—When do the Government and the Guild propose to sign the pharmaceutical agreement-not the one relating to redundancy-that was put up?

—I think that Senator Walters will be pleasantly surprised in a very short time. I cannot give her an exact time. That would take away the excitement of the announcement. It is not for me to pre-empt the pleasure that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) will take in making the relevant announcement. But I can assure Senator Walters that it is imminent.

—I raise a point about a number of drugs that have now been taken off freely accessible lists. I give the example of the drug Losec. Its pharmaceutical name is omeprazole. I am concerned about this drug, which is used for the treatment of ulcers. I understand that it is a relatively new drug. In fact, it was listed only on 1 August this year. Under the new scheme a pensioner can receive an eight-week supply of this drug, which I understand is two bottles, for $2.50 per bottle. A non-pensioner can receive the same at a cost of $15 per bottle. But after that, should it be necessary for a patient to receive this drug for life, it needs to be determined by a hospital consultant. A continuous supply can then be received from the hospital pharmacy. Is it correct that it must be determined by a hospital consultant? Why can it not be determined by a private specialist who would obviously do all the relevant tests to ensure that the patient needs the drug? Why is it necessary that the drug be dispensed by a hospital pharmacy instead of a private pharmacy?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to confirm that that is in fact the rule that prevails in this situation where there is an apparent requirement for a lifelong supply of a particular drug-in this case, a drug to do with the reduction, I suppose, or treatment of ulcers. I am not able to say whether in fact it requires a hospital consultant to make that assessment or whether it can be dispensed only through a hospital pharmacy. Therefore, obviously I am not able to say why that might be the case. The officers that I have with me are not specialists in that area. Whilst I can strive to get the answer for Senator Knowles, I doubt whether I can get it during this Committee's deliberations tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I understand from that answer that the Minister will certainly try to get me an answer. I should have said that the information I have came from the health insurance office. That is why I am seeking to clarify it; to make sure that there has not been some dreadful mistake.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also been told that the Canberra panel-those are not my words; I am not too sure who the Canberra panel is but maybe it is the Drug Evaluation Committee-feels that an ulcer should have healed with this particular drug within eight weeks and then a patient can go back onto a cheaper drug such as Tagamet or something like that as a maintenance measure.

I have received quite clear evidence from patients that they become immune to Tagamet and they have been put onto this other drug. Therefore, it is causing extreme concern that they cannot continue to receive this drug without paying up to-I have been given various figures-either $105 or $150 per bottle per month. That applies to both pensioners and non-pensioners. Patients cannot cover this cost by claiming on their private health insurance.

There is a lot of concern about this in the community. I wonder what the Minister has to say about that? If that is so, how can we justify this measure in the light of the cost of hospitalisation? An occupied bed per day in the private sector, including medical costs, costs $245 and in the public sector it is $345-$100 more. Patients who are now achieving great results on this drug are worried that they will in fact be hospitalised. Not only will they incur greater costs but also we, as taxpayers, will have to incur greater costs as well if they are hospitalised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think perhaps we need the intervention of Senator Herron to help us with this. But I link this matter with the previous line of questioning from Senator Patterson because, as the good senator from Victoria pointed out, there is a danger in our society of people becoming attached to taking certain drugs beyond the properly indicated medical necessity. From what Senator Knowles has said, it would appear that the general rule in relation to this drug is thought to be that after eight weeks it should have achieved its purpose and then perhaps a different type of medication ought to be offered to the patient. In that situation it may be that the sort of assessment to be undertaken, as the honourable senator suggested, by the hospital consultant would be necessary, as much as anything, in order to protect the patient from becoming addicted to an unnecessary level of medication which might do other damage.

SPEECH.PARA: That restriction may be for the protection of the patient and for the company which produces the particular pharmaceutical, because its own clinical trials might have suggested that eight weeks was the optimum period.

I do not know anything about it, as must be obvious, and I will seek proper information with regard to the honourable senator's questions. I am sure that it is in the interests of all of us that time spent in hospital be reduced to an absolute minimum-both from the point of view of taxpayers in the community and from the point of view of a large number of members of the community who are contributors to health benefit funds. We all have an interest in ensuring that pharmaceuticals, as prescribed by properly qualified medical practitioners, are used properly in a way which can exclude the necessity for the hospitalisation of a person suffering from a particular disease. But these comments are only generalisations. I will make proper inquiries in relation to the honourable senator's particular query concerning this drug, with the trade name Losec.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is a real concern at this stage about getting addicted to the drug because it is a fairly new drug. I understand from specialists that many of the patients who have been on Tagamet have ceased to get any benefit from it and therefore they have had to go back into hospital or have further tests-endoscopies and so on. Instead of patients becoming attached to a particular drug they in fact get rather detached to the drug that is no longer helping them. That is the reason I wish to clarify this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not doubting anything that the patients or the doctors are saying about this matter, or in fact anything that the Minister has said tonight in terms of finding out answers. This is but one example of a drug and I am equally concerned that there may be many other drugs that fall into this category, where people will be faced with a huge cost in order to obtain the drug or will be hospitalised as a consequence of not being able to afford it. I flag that issue with the Minister and I look forward to his answer in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be able to help the Committee with this matter. Omeprazole is a new drug. It is an anti-ulcer agent which has a different physiological action to Tagamet. It may clarify the matter if we could ask one of the officers whether omeprazole is on authority restriction only-that may be the case.
—The officers are unable to answer that.

—As Senator Knowles has said, it is a new drug. It probably is on authority only as it is a new wonder drug and it suffers from that restriction. Some honourable senators may be appreciative of the fact that, as opposed to Tagamet, when using omeprazole a person can continue to smoke cigarettes and have his ulcer healed.

SPEECH.PARA: Harking back to the point which Senator Knowles raised, I am not clear as to the difference in restrictions between Tagamet and omeprazole. As the honourable senator said, it is a drug which is unique in its own field because of its peculiar physiological action acting on the cells that are responsible for acid production. It gets back to the problem of brand name, generic prescribing and the transfer of patients from a drug to which they have become accustomed-which had been effective but which has lost its effectiveness-to another drug, as in the case of Tagamet to omeprazole. That is probably the point that Senator Knowles was making. I, too, would appreciate a reply as to the restrictions on omeprazole as compared to Tagamet.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked for a copy of the speech by Dr Michael Merson, entitled `Global Aids and Prevention Control' at the AIDS in Asia and the Pacific Conference. Could the Minister tell me who gives the Australian statistics to the World Health Organisation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the National Centre in HIV Epidemiology and Clinical Research gives relevant information to the World Health Organisation. With regard to most conferences or international surveys of that sort Dr Tony Adams, the Chief Medical Officer in the Department of Community Services and Health, would be the person who forwards relevant information describing the Australian situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a concern to me in reading the speech by Dr Merson that he ends up by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: We estimate that in 1990, about 60% of HIV infections are transmitted through vaginal and 15% through anal intercourse.
He further says:

The pattern is shifting to predominantly heterosexual transmission all over the world. By the year 2000, it is expected that at least 80% of all HIV infections will result from heterosexual intercourse.

By Australian standards we know that not to be correct. I was wondering whether I could have a copy of the information that was sent to the World Health Organisation on the situation in Australia. That statement is not accurate when it says `all over the world'-and I presume that does include Australia-because, unfortunately, we have one of the highest incidents per capita, I gather, in the Western world. I was wondering whether I could have a copy of the information that was given by Australia to the World Health Organisation that perhaps would have contributed to the paper that Dr Merson gave at that particular conference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be obvious to Senator Walters that the claim is not being made that what might be a global picture of the proportions of the various modes of transmission of HIV are to be found in every part of the globe. In other words, if the 80 per cent transmission through heterosexual intercourse is true, it is clearly not a figure which corresponds with the situation as revealed in Australia. But that does not make the global picture inaccurate; it just means that Australia is not experiencing the same proportion of the various modes of transmission.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the particular statistics transmitted to the World Health Organisation, if I heard the whispers correctly the Australian epidemiological centre sends material to the World Health Organisation under various categories and descriptions which have emanated from the Disease Control Centre in Atlanta. It is those particular categories which form the basis for the comparative work and the global aggregation of the picture which results in the paper to which Senator Walters has referred and from which she has quoted.

Senator Walters asked whether we could supply the material that was provided to the World Health Organisation in accordance with that categorisation. I think we can undertake to do that. I understand it is a published book, so it is a public document available widely, and we will have no trouble in making it available to Senator Walters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister very much. It is recorded in Hansard that I asked the reason for Dr Blewett's statement in the White Paper that 1.6 per cent of reported AIDS cases in Australia resulted from heterosexual transmission, because that was not the figure, the Minister will remember from the discussion, that was given to us in any of the Australian HIV surveillance reports. I got an answer that I do not understand, and I will read it to the Minister. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: At mid-1989 there were 23 cases of AIDS classified by the National Centre in HIV Epidemiology and Clinical Research as having acquired their infection heterosexually. At the end of November, the National Centre revised the definition of ``heterosexually acquired'' to mean only those cases where the exposure category or HIV infection status of the sexual partner who infected the person was known. At this time, 10 cases who only reported heterosexual activity but for whom no relevant information on their partner was available were reclassified from ``heterosexual'' to ``other undetermined''. There are currently 16 cases of AIDS acquired heterosexually where the status of the partner was known.

If the Minister looks at the information we were given-and I refer to the 16 cases in the Australian HIV surveillance report-he will see heterosexual contact, 16. That is made up as follows: sex with an IV drug user, 1; sex with bisexual male, 5; sex with a person from a pattern II country, 6; sex with a pattern II country, 2; sex with transfusion recipient, 1; and sex with HIV infected person unknown transmission classification, 1. That makes up the 16. How can the answer that I was given be correct?

I do not know how the Minister is going to work this out. Unless I had the answer in front of me I could not have taken it all in. Could he try to understand that the 23 cases referred to would have also included all those categories, including that category where the transmission is unknown.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not really in a strong position to answer, except to say that the description of the intravenous drug user, the person from the pattern II country-whatever that means-and so on and so forth, refers to one of the partners. The fact remains that the mode of transmission was heterosexual activity between the two parties, so the figures are not incompatible. Of course, heterosexual activity does not mean vaginal activity, as we determined in the Committee. Nevertheless, it is sexual activity involving the exchange of bodily fluids, I think is the phrase we use. Senator Walters is describing the characteristics of the partner from whom the infection was allegedly received.

—That is not the point, unfortunately. I cannot imagine how the Minister is going to understand this from my just reading it out. Unless he reads it himself he will not be able to understand it. It says there are 23 cases. There are presently 16. It says that 23 was brought down because of a different definition, but the definition is still there. The 16 comprise that same definition. There is still that number of people within that same definition of `person of unknown transmission' category. The 16 still includes that category, even though I was told that the whole reason for it was a different definition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the figure of 23 was reduced to 16 because in the case of seven there was uncertainty as to whether the assertion-I suppose it can only be a claim-that the mode of transmission was through heterosexual activity was indeed the case.
—That is not the answer I have got.

—I suggest that is the proper answer and it is the answer which the officers indicate to me. It was because of uncertainty as to whether seven of the 23 cases were as the result of heterosexual activity as opposed to some other mode of transmission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the parliamentary liaison group on AIDS and as the chair of one of the working panels which helped turn the Green Paper into a White Paper, I would like to contribute to this discussion. I understand the concern Senator Walters is raising. She wants to get the numbers precise and balanced. But there are certain things I would not wish to go unsaid in the Committee. Firstly, the AIDS sufferers we have seen represent infection that occurred some time ago. Included among those figures-and I am going on the Australian HIV surveillance report of October 1990-are quite a large number of women; that is, 63 females. Irrespective of how they acquired AIDS, they are 63 females who got AIDS. They are not just infected people; I will come to infected people in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know, Mr Temporary Chairman, whether you have seen anyone die of AIDS, but it is probably one of the worst ways of dying that there is. For each of those 63 people, only some of whom, by the way, were infected as a result of contaminated blood products, it really does not matter very much whether they acquired the virus from injecting, from heterosexual intercourse, as I understand that term, or in some other way. The fact is they got the virus.

There is a whole range of approaches we must use to try to do something about this disease because it is untreatable once it is acquired. The only effective strategy open to us is prevention. It is interesting that Australia, almost alone among the nations of the world, can point to an effect upon new infections. New infections are dropping in this country. I suggest that that is related to the interventions which have been undertaken as part of the national AIDS strategy, which is regarded in many countries as a model document. It involves an eclectic approach; it involves, for example, the funding of those who would preach chastity and fidelity. Of course it does. I believe large amounts of Commonwealth money-perhaps up to $570,000-have gone to Christian groups to enable them to put their own views on chastity, celibacy, monogamy and fidelity. I applaud that. When I was doing consulting work for the World Health Organisation and went to Pacific countries, many church leaders in those countries, who are very influential in matters like this, were very keen that that should be part of the message WHO put. WHO said, `Of course. We will support that kind of message', as we are here.

It is interesting to look not at the AIDS sufferers who represent infection five to seven years ago, but to look at the infection rate and to look at the number of people infected with this virus, because we know that for those people the future is very clouded. I believe I am correct in saying that in Australia at the moment 457 women are known to be infected with the HI virus. If I look at the transmission categories of some of the most recent cases, I find that none of them got the disease from unsafe blood. Of course we all agree that securing the blood supply is the first absolute necessity, and Australia has done that. By the way, it was a disgrace that in some parts of the world it was delayed even by six or nine months.

If we look at the other categories, of the 10 people who were reported with new HIV infection to 7 September 1990, and over the two previous calendar intervals, we find that five are said to have contracted it from heterosexual contact. The only plea I make is that we remember that with the national strategy we have achieved some results, and that the number of new infections, instead of rising by an exponential rate, as predicted, has flattened. If that happens, Australia is doing something useful. I hope the Parliament will support the strategy and the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will return to what I was saying. I now understand the real answer to my question why 16 was an incorrect figure. I can be corrected if I am wrong but because some of those 23 were put in the wrong category, there was no substantiation that they were infected through heterosexual transmission. Why was I then given a totally wrong answer by the Department?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that the Department has in any way set out to mislead Senator Walters. In fact the material we have provided has been extremely extensive and the number of statistics, correlations, comparative tables and work undertaken is, I think, a measure of the attempt by the Department to provide the Committee with as much information as possible. In that instance, obviously the most expert epidemiologists and those involved themselves came to have misgivings and queries about, as Senator Walters would put it-I think properly-the substantiation of the self-claim of having been infected through heterosexual activity. If that sort of reassessment, and therefore the refiguring consequential upon it, has taken place, the Department may be forgiven for sometimes not always being abreast of the latest reassessment by the experts of the correct figuring. As a result of Senator Walters's persistence in this matter and as a result of what is available to this Committee of the Whole, we are now in a position where the Australian people are well-informed about the correct situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not ask the Minister to respond to this. I understand how the mistake occurred in respect of the 23 people, but I do not understand why a wrong answer was given to me by the Department in answer to a question I asked of it in the Estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1985 Australia panicked and we had the situation where, with all the best intentions in the world, Dr Blewett said that by today 50,000 people in this country would be infected with AIDS. That has now been revised to 15,000, and has been cited by Professor Karmel as being a more accurate figure. I understand that. I have referred to a speech given by Dr Merson. He said:
We estimate in 1990 about 60 per cent of HIV infections will be transmitted through vaginal sex and 15 per cent through anal intercourse.

I find that extremely hard to understand-just as hard as some of the claims that have been made here in Australia. The Minister will remember that I brought to his attention Professor Penny's letter to the Australian in which he made that silly claim that 121 Australians had contracted HIV through vaginal intercourse, which we have established now was totally incorrect. We get all this misinformation.

The World Health Organisation is saying that it is able to assess, in all the countries that it deals with, something that we in this country, with all our sophisticated technology and means of surveys, et cetera, cannot assess. Despite Professor Penny's claim, we know that the National Health and Medical Research Council tells us, `No, we have not got any figures at all in Australia on the transmission of AIDS by vaginal sex'. Yet we had the World Health Organisation saying that it can do it and that it estimates that 60 per cent of cases are transmitted in that fashion.

I know that there are extenuating circumstances in Africa. I am well aware that South Africa is in a very bad position-particularly the women of Africa. We know that blood screening there came very late, and that women, due to their child-bearing, were the ones needing the hospital and medical centres and being given injections with dirty needles. We know that in many of those areas there is no concept of having a new needle every time an injection is given, and in many places dirty needles are used, with needles being kept and used until they break.

We also know that other sexually transmitted diseases are a rife area as a source of infection from vaginal intercourse with an HIV positive partner. We know that the women in Africa who have other sexually transmitted diseases to a large extent go untreated. We also know that, because of the African culture, homosexuality is not acknowledged in the same way as it is here, and so the majority of homosexuals in that country are bisexuals. In those areas, and indeed in some other similar countries, the same sorts of reasons occur. But we must not panic Australians in the same way by saying to them that the same thing could happen here. It was with that in mind that I asked Minister Tate-and he promised that he would-to bring to the attention of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) that there are indeed other sexually transmitted diseases, and certainly cervical cancer, which are far more of a concern to young and promiscuous girls than AIDS will ever be.

As I gave Minister Tate the figures at that time, for a woman in Australia the risk of dying of AIDS is one in 591,569; whereas the risk of a woman dying of cervical cancer is one in 23,663. He promised to talk to the Education Minister, who will be going to that December meeting, and to ask that promiscuous young girls be given that sort of information along with the AIDS information.

Could the Minister also ask the Department whether Professor Karmel or Dr Kaldor now believes that AIDS has peaked, or is it again too early? I asked that in the Estimates, and was told that it was a bit too early to tell yet, but the latest statistics were not out then. Could the Minister tell me whether that belief is still the same or is it still too early? Or following the accumulation of this extra data-as Senator Baume said, the figures are going down-do we believe it has peaked?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters has traversed many areas in the last few moments, starting back in 1985 with the supposed panic on behalf of the Australian authorities.
—Legitimate.
—Which I am pleased to say she now qualifies by the term `legitimate'.
—I said at the time that it was understandable.

—I do not know that the honourable senator did say it at the time. Nevertheless, the fact is that, rather than the 50,000 cases which were predicted apparently as being likely in 1990, there are now some 15,000 identified cases of such infection. I would have thought that it was proper to take some pride as Australians in the fact that, if the various programs to alert members of the community to this disease had not been undertaken, some 35,000 Australians might have been put at risk, in jeopardy, and ravaged by this disease and eventually might have died. It is the cumulative impact of the programs which has the effect of achieving the great reduction in the figures from the projections of 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: As to whether the latest figures would allow one to say that the rate of infection has plateaued-and I think that is what she was referring to-I will ask the Government's senior medical advisers to try to come to some interpretation and see whether the latest figures allow them to be more forthcoming in their description of the plateau or decline effect that might be gauged from the figures, as compared with when we met in the Estimates Committee only a matter of weeks ago. I would say that it would be unlikely, but I will ask the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters, before you begin, I must admit that I cannot find a reservation in the Committee report or reservations that have been included by honourable senators in relation to this particular matter. Senator Walters will realise that we must speak only to matters in the report, or by way of reservation where a senator has suggested that matters should be further examined by the Committee of the Whole. If you can tell me where the reservation is, that would be of assistance to me.

—Mr Chairman, I will explain it very simply. If you will remember-and I am sure that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs will back me in this, although I am not sure that he was present at that time-we sat on Friday when a Senate standing committee was also sitting. I was trying to attend both. Senator Crowley, who was Chairman of the committee, made a promise to me that I would be able to ask any question on homeless youth and the acquired immune deficiency syndrome situation that I wanted, so long as I did not hold up Estimates until the end of the Senate standing committee's sitting. This was the only alternative. That promise was given to me verbally and I presume that it will be honoured.
—I seem to remember what a former Leader of the Government used to say about verbal comments-that they were worth the paper they were written on.
—I am sure that Senator Crowley would not like that.
—I see something that perhaps Senator Walters can hang a reservation upon, but it is very tenuous. Therefore, I would ask Senator Walters to continue.

—I have not many questions, Mr Chairman. I refer to the Australian HIV surveillance report which I requested and which the Department has sent me. I have been valiantly trying to compare the reports. The first one was dated July 1990; this one is dated October 1990. There is no way that I can compare the two. Some of the tables are totally different. I ask the Minister whether table 1.5 as to July 1990 is at least the same as table 1.5 in October 1990. It is a different heading, but if it is read carefully I think they work out about the same. Could we please have the same tables? We have a list of tables relating to AIDS cases and deaths by sex and State or Territory. That is not the same in the other one at all. They are all different. It makes it very tricky to try to follow any continuity or to be able to establish at all what is happening over the period. It almost looks as though it is deliberately done to confuse us.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the two tables are not the same because of difficulty in obtaining proper New South Wales data. In fact, I am told that the October table does not include New South Wales data and that that leads to the difference that I am referring to. I take Senator Walters's general point that it is helpful if, so far as possible, tables are comparable and in a consistent set of categories for ease of reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Minister is saying is that the October 1990 table 1.5 does not have New South Wales in it. Where does it say that?
—I do not know. Apparently it is not specified in the table.
—Minister, how ridiculous can you get?
—How can one get?
—Not you, Minister.
—Not me either.
—Not you either, Mr Chairman. The national centre document reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Deaths following AIDS by sex and exposure category, cumulative to 30 September 1990, and for two previous yearly intervals. Adults/adolescents (13 years and older and diagnosis of AIDS).
It does not mention New South Wales. I cannot see it anywhere.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they ought to be reprimanded, as the honourable senator has done, and I will make sure that they get a copy of the Hansard. I believe that it makes it difficult to carry out comparative work if that sort of essential data is missing and not noted in the footnotes or as a covering caveat to the reader. I would say that it is bad science.
—Could the Minister say whether table 1.5 in the previous lot does contain it?
—We do not have it available to us. Senator Walters's general point is taken and I will pass it back to that independent body. It is not a body within the Department, as the Committee knows.
