TALK.START.PARA: -I want to ask about funding for multipurpose centres. In February this year Minister Staples went around the country-and I am sure that he would say that it was not because an election was coming on. It was because I had pushed him to address the issue of developing a more flexible system for small rural nursing homes. I had taken a particular interest in this matter because, of the 118 small rural nursing homes in Australia, 48 happen to be in Victoria. One of the reasons for my taking such an interest was the number of them in Victoria. When the Department of Community Services and Health had this wildcat idea of merging any small rural nursing homes that were less than 250 kilometres apart, people went into a tailspin, and rightly so.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the solutions and one of the things I kept asking for was a creative program to be developed to ensure that some of these centres would remain viable to enable older people to stay in and be cared for in their own communities. We on this side of the chamber, at least, think that that is the appropriate way for older people to be looked after: if they have lived in a community all their lives, they should be looked after in that community.

The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) developed this concept of multipurpose centres and announced in February the establishment of multipurpose centres-appropriately, many of them in marginal seats. That was all very well. Some of the centres were told in February that they were approved. I know of one in particular that was told on 2 February that it would be an approved multipurpose centre.

Those centres were in regular contact with the Department about when they might see the colour of the money for these multipurpose centres. The centres were to get a smaller amount in the first instance to help them start up and until they reached the requirements for a multipurpose centre, when they would be entitled to $45,000 per annum.

In the Estimates Committee I asked whether funding had gone ahead because the explanatory notes stated that two rounds of funding had been completed. That seemed strange to me, because I had spoken to most of the multipurpose centres in my State and none had seen any money. I was told that, if the legal agreements governing the conditions of award that had been developed in conjunction with the legal services branch had been signed, the centres would be funded.

Miss Murnane implied that the funding had gone ahead. After lunch she came to me and said that she was a little surprised to find that none of the centres had received any of their funding. I was not surprised because I had been told by the multipurpose centres that they had not received their funding. Anyway, what happened was this. I asked my question on 12 October in the Estimates Committee-and this will not be lost on the Minister because the dates are important. On 16 October, it was stated on page 2555 of the additional information that the cheques were dispatched to the four named centres-that is, Violet Town, Rainbow, Avoca and Lakes Entrance, which were the four towns that came off the top of my head when I was asked which four I was talking about-on 16 October 1990, four days after I had asked the question. The document then said:

Legal agreements governing the conditions of Award of Grant had to be developed in conjunction with the Legal Services Branch for each organisation and these conditions had to be accepted in writing by each organisation before payment of grants was made. Acceptance in writing of the Conditions of Awards of Grant were received from Violet Town, Rainbow, Avoca and Lakes Entrance on the following dates:
Violet Town...8 October 1990
Rainbow...17 September 1990
Avoca...14 September 1990
Lakes Entrance...21 September 1990

It might also interest the Minister to know that I had asked a question in the Senate about the funding of multipurpose centres just before that. Two of the centres, but one in particular, received their agreements on 14 September. That is the first discussion that they had had with the Department about the agreement. The wording in the answers makes it appear as though the centres were tardy in the negotiation of these agreements. That is not so.

The first the centres saw, or heard or had anything to do with the agreement was when they received documents saying that, if they signed, their funding would commence from the date of the signing of the agreement. This particular centre signed the agreement, waited a day or two, got some legal advice about the status of the agreement and sent it off. The centre got its cheque on 18 October. That seems to fit in, because we have been told in the additional information supplied to Estimates that the cheques were sent on 16 October.

The two points of interest are that the cheques were dated, as the centres were told, from the date the agreement was signed, 14 September, which is in this financial year. But we have been told in the explanatory notes that two rounds of funding had been completed. It was absolute nonsense. Two rounds of funding had not been completed. In fact, nobody had got funding. The other interesting thing relates to the cheque-I have a copy of it here-that the centre received. I wonder whether the Auditor-General or the Public Accounts Committee might be interested in this. It is a fascinating exercise. The cheque is dated 26 June 1990, but it was sent out on 18 October.

I do not know whether that is an unusual occurrence or whether it is the practice of the Department of Community Services and Health. I hope it is not. Maybe the cheques were sitting in the Department waiting for the agreement to be signed and so on, but it seems strange to me that the funding is from 14 September, approved in February. What will happen? I will give an example of one of the centres. It got its set up money of $20,000 from 14 September. By 14 September next year the centre will not have quite made it to the status of a multipurpose centre. It is hoping to have its hostel beds built by February 1991. It then gets the next $20,000 in September. The question the centre would be interested to ask is: When it reaches the status of a multipurpose centre in February 1991, will it get a pro rata upgrading of that $20,000 to a pro rata of the $45,000 it was due for the rest of the financial year?

I think it would have been much more appropriate had the round of funding been completed, as it was stated, as at the date when it had been approved as a multipurpose centre. In effect, the centres will be $20,000 or more worse off than they would have been had they got their funding when approval had been given. It seems to me that the delay might have been in the legal services branch. Wherever the delay was, it was not in the centres. For the Department even to phrase the information in a way that would intimate that the centres were at fault for not signing their agreements or not engaging in negotiations-those centres rang and rang the Department-is erroneous. I was in constant contact with the centres. I had taken a particular interest in multipurpose centres. I believe it is the way to go. I believe that we need centres that can offer a number of services to the aged people in the community, and I believe that we can make them viable.

The fact that they got their cheque in October-dated in June-is something that needs to be addressed. I do not know whether they were sitting there, waiting, or whether in fact somebody scurried around and wrote cheques dated 26 June so he could retrospectively have the explanatory notes somehow in accord with what was going on, but it does seem very odd. Perhaps the Minister should ask the Minister responsible to look at this. In fact, I hope the Auditor-General addresses it. I have raised it with one of the members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts because it does seem slightly irregular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

In other words, we have a problem of a financial year as far as we are concerned, and a calendar year as far as researchers and universities and other institutions are concerned.

I am so sore about this because I well recall the National Health and Medical Research Council making almost half a million dollars in grants, approximately $450,000 in medical research grants, to a group in the Monash Bioethics Centre-Professor Peter Singer, Helga Kuhse and such people-for the purposes of developing a philosophy, as it were, in favour of human embryo experimentation. They were given $450,000 of medical research grants, when there were many researchers with excellent research projects who were not funded but whose research projects were approved. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make two comments. TALK.START.PARA: -I re-emphasise that I certainly do not mean to reflect in any way on the Department. The Department has done an extremely good job in the very short time that it had to prepare the material.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the new Medicare item for in-vitro fertilisation (IVF), as I indicated I would in the reservation. With the new item for IVF-item No. 840, et cetera-there is a specific prohibition on surrogacy arrangements. The new item came into effect on 1 November. There does not appear to be any clear prohibition of government reimbursement for these items when they are used for purposes related to infertility. However, this year there have been suggestions that IVF procedures could be employed for genetic screening purposes. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 January 1990 entitled `IVF should be for everyone, doctors say' and written by Ruth Dewsbury, Medical Reporter, states:
Australian ethicists have called for fertile couples to have access to in vitro fertilisation, a program restricted in some States to the treatment of infertility.

IVF techniques could not only offer some fertile couples a better chance of a normal baby, argues Professor Peter Singer, director of the Centre for Human Bioethics, but the opportunity for women to delay having children more safely.

In this week's British Medical Journal, Professor Singer and a senior research officer, Dr Karen Dawson, put forward two scenarios for the use of IVF by fertile couples either for medical reasons or as a matter of choice for the woman. I will not continue with the article, but I would be happy to table it and show it to the Minister.

There have been suggestions that IVF procedures could be employed for genetic screening purposes. In September a scientist from the United States suggested that genetic screening through IVF would become common practice within 10 years. That report has built on a report from another conference in the United States. But let us set aside the United States example. There have been discussions within this country about the possible use of IVF for that purpose. Indeed, the Minister will recall that the first submission opposing the Bill which I introduced to prevent destructive experiments on human embryos was from the Murdoch Institute for Research in Birth Defects. That submission to the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 opposed the Bill on the grounds that the Bill would prevent such a scheme being implemented. If it is appropriate, as I believe it is, to deny the Medicare rebate when surrogacy arrangements are involved, surely the same applies to these people who might enter the IVF program simply for the purpose of having their baby measured up to certain standards before it is slotted for either reprieve or destruction.

I am not happy with the introduction of the Medicare item in any event but given the statement by the Minister that the rebate was related to infertile couples why is there not a provision in the details of the new medical benefit scheme item which were provided to the Committee? Why is there not some prohibition in them for persons who are using, or who are likely to use, the IVF programs in the way that is foreshadowed in the material that I have presented to the Committee of the Whole today?

COMMONWEALTH FUNDS MANAGEMENT LIMITED BILL 1990

The Bill completes the new superannuation arrangements that apply to Commonwealth employees and, at the same time, represents a further step in the Government's comprehensive program to improve the performance of government business enterprises.
The purpose of the Bill is twofold.
Firstly, the Bill provides for the transfer of SFIT's trustee function in respect of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund to a joint employer/employee Board of Trustees.
Secondly, it provides for the conversion of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) into a wholly Commonwealth owned public company to be called Commonwealth Funds Management Limited (CFM).
SFIT was established in 1976 under the Superannuation Act 1976 as a statutory authority with trustee responsibility for the management and investment of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund.

The Fund contains the contributions of the members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the income earned from SFIT's investment of those contributions, as well as, since 1 July 1990, employer 3 per cent productivity contributions. Management of the Fund and the investment performance of the Fund are important to both the members of the superannuation scheme and to the Government in its role as a responsible employer.

The Government's superannuation policy, expressed in the Occupational Superannuation Standards, is that responsibility and control for superannuation funds should be in the hands of joint employer/employee boards of trustees.

The new Public Sector Superannuation Scheme established under the Superannuation Act 1990 is fully in accord with this policy. The Board of Trustees have full responsibility for the administration of the scheme and the investment of Fund moneys.

At the time the new Public Sector Superannuation Scheme was introduced, changes were made to the administration of the 1976 Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. A Commonwealth Superannuation Board was established with responsibilities for the invalidity retirement process and setting the interest rate to be allocated on members' contributions. The Commissioner for Superannuation, however, retained his statutory duties under the Superannuation Act 1976.

This Bill reconstitutes the Commonwealth Superannuation Board as the Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No. 2. This joint employer/employee Board retains the responsibilities of the former Board and, in addition, will have responsibility for the management of the Superannuation Fund for the 1976 scheme.

With this amendment, administration of the two main superannuation schemes for public servants will be in line with the Occupational Superannuation Standards, private sector practice, and other new superannuation schemes in the Commonwealth sector.

Members of the 1976 Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme now will have an appropriate say in the management of their superannuation fund through the trustees nominated by the ACTU to represent the members.

Mr President, changes that have been made to the Superannuation Act 1976 relating to the operations of SFIT since it was first established have placed SFIT on a fairly independent footing with the freedom and flexibility to manage and invest moneys of the Fund in a commercial manner. In 1986, restrictions on SFIT's investment powers were removed to enable it to compete with the private sector for investment opportunities. Further amendments, which came into effect on 1 July 1990, have provided SFIT with the power to provide investment services on a fee for service basis to a range of clients within the public and private sectors.

As investment manager of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund, SFIT manages one of the largest portfolios in the country with over $5.8 billion under management. SFIT operates in all major domestic financial markets and has a portion of the Fund invested in international equities. Its performance over recent years has placed it among the top performing fund managers according to published surveys of comparable pooled superannuation funds.

Telecom and Australia Post, and some other government business enterprises (GBEs), whose employees were previously members of the 1976 Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, have now established their own superannuation schemes. As a result, SFIT has lost its monopoly over the management and investment of those funds and is now required to compete with the private sector for their management. Any significant withdrawal of GBE funds would make it difficult for SFIT to maintain, without the changes I am introducing today, the rates of return it has achieved in the past.

To be able to compete successfully with the private sector for GBE funds, and attract new clients, SFIT needs to be allowed to operate as a truly commercial enterprise able to respond quickly in the market place free from day-to-day regulatory controls. Moreover, freeing SFIT from its trustee responsibilities has marketing advantages because it will no longer be seen by prospective clients as having to give priority to the management of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund.

The reform package is therefore, a necessary step in the continued development of SFIT. The objective is to establish it as an efficient and commercially focused organisation able to compete profitably and effectively with the private sector in the domestic and international market place. Conversion of SFIT into a wholly Commonwealth owned public company incorporated under the Companies Act 1981 will enable this objective to be achieved but at the same time provide for an organisation with the capacity to ensure the protection of the returns of members of the Commonwealth superannuation schemes.

There are a number of important elements in the CFM reform package. Firstly, there will be new planning and accountability mechanisms for CFM. These will include the provision by CFM of a three-year corporate plan which will define the company's goals, financial targets and strategies to achieve those goals. Financial targets will be set and CFM will report annually giving an account of its performance against goals.

CFM's memorandum and articles of association will be registered, as with any public company, with the National Companies and Securities Commission. The Minister responsible for CFM will exercise control on behalf of the Commonwealth as the shareholder, in a similar manner to shareholders in any other company. The proposed memorandum and articles of association will provide for the Minister responsible to have the power to appoint and dismiss the CFM board of directors. Also the Minister responsible for CFM will be able to issue guidelines to the Board.

With CFM's establishment as a general funds manager competing for the management of other funds, it will be important that Board members have suitable investment experience and business acumen. The Board will be appointed by the Minister from suitably qualified men and women in accordance with Government policy. Existing members of SFIT will be eligible for appointment to the Board.

In addition CFM will be required to operate in accordance with the Companies Code. This will provide for the protection of the interests of the Commonwealth through its rights as a shareholder of the company. Under the Companies Code the company's directors have specific responsibilities to shareholders as well as other defined obligations. There will also be revised remuneration arrangements for the chief executive officer.

CFM will be expected to continue to comply with Government wages and industrial relations policies, in particular with those guidelines developed specifically for GBEs in March 1989. It is intended that CFM operate as a public company limited by shares and incorporated in the Australian Capital Territory.

The arrangements proposed for CFM are essentially the same as those already applying to other GBEs such as Australian Airlines Ltd, Australian National Line and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation.

Mr President, I now summarise the key elements of the Bill. The Bill provides for the conversion of SFIT from its current statutory authority status, to a public company incorporated under the Companies Act.

The Bill comes into effect in several stages, on Royal Assent and through two proclamations. This is to facilitate the creation of the capital structure, incorporation of the new company, the transfer of SFIT's trustee role to the Board of Trustees and the repeal of sections of the Superannuation Act 1976 relating to the establishment of SFIT and its operations as a statutory authority. This also allows for the development of an appropriate memorandum and articles of association, an appropriate balance sheet, financial performance indicators and a strategic plan to enable the Minister responsible for CFM to undertake strategic oversight of the company.

The Bill provides for all of the share capital of CFM to be issued to the Commonwealth or its nominees and, in view of the Commonwealth's ongoing interest in CFM, it provides that CFM shares cannot be transferred to non-Commonwealth interests.

The Bill ensures the continuity of SFIT as a legal entity during the transition. Legally, continuity of the corporate entity dispenses with the need to transfer assets and liabilities from SFIT to a new body corporate. This means that all contracts, agreements and arrangements entered into by or on behalf of SFIT which are in force immediately before transition in respect of most of the assets and liabilities automatically apply to the new company. However, because of the need for some financial adjustments to be made between SFIT and the Board of Trustees, the Bill provides for the transfer of certain assets and liabilities of a non-trading nature. In addition, the assets and liabilities held by SFIT in its capacity as manager of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund will be transferred to the Board of Trustees.

The Bill ensures continuity of employment and staff conditions during the transition. Each staff member of SFIT will become an employee of the new company on the same terms and conditions as applied to his or her employment by the statutory authority. Accordingly there are provisions enabling current employees' accumulated entitlements, rights under Part IV of the Public Service Act 1922 and rights of entry into the Australian Public Service to be maintained.

The Bill provides for the establishment of SFIT as an incorporated company limited by shares through the registration of the memorandum and articles of association for CFM with the National Companies and Securities Commission.
At the same time SFIT's trustee function in respect of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund is transferred to a joint employer/employee Board of Trustees.

The Board of Trustees becomes responsible for the management and investment of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund which is to be known as Commonwealth Superannuation Fund No. 2. The Bill provides for CFM to be retained as the sole investment manager of the Fund, and the Fund of the new Public Sector Superannuation Scheme, until at least 30 June 1995. After this date, it is proposed that CFM will have to compete, for the management of the Funds, with other fund managers.
I will now address the financial implications of the Bill.

The Bill does not involve additional expenditure by the Commonwealth. It does, however, provide that CFM be given a Commonwealth guarantee on initial borrowings of up to $20 million borrowed prior to 30 June 1995 for working capital purposes. As a wholly Commonwealth owned public company, CFM will be required to pay dividends to the Commonwealth. The Bill provides for exemptions from Commonwealth, State and Territory taxes on the transition to a company and transfer of assets, recognising that there has been no change in the beneficial ownership.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I now present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVESTOCK (QUOTAS) BILL 1990

The purpose of this Bill and the associated Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Amendment Bill 1990 is to provide the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) with the power to implement and administer schemes to control the level of exports of Australian meat and livestock to particular markets where the Board of the AMLC considers such arrangements would be in the best interests of the industry.
Experience with the live sheep trade to the Middle East highlighted a deficiency in the AMLC's powers in respect of its ability to impose and administer schemes controlling the level of exports.

The AMLC, for many years, has had the power to administer quota schemes where limitations have been, or are considered likely to be, imposed by the Australian or foreign governments. This Bill will empower the AMLC to also introduce quotas on its own initiative where they are considered to be in the interests of the industry.

Because quota arrangements can, at times, result in windfall profits to exporters granted quota access it has been decided to empower the AMLC to sell quota entitlement by auction, tender or other means so that part of the price premium can be recouped for use for the benefit of the industry generally.

I would stress at this point that the AMLC will have the discretion to sell quota entitlement where it is considered appropriate. Where it is not necessary or appropriate it will continue to allocate quota without charge as it has done in the past.

To ensure all quota arrangements are equitable and seen to be equitable, the associated AMLC Amendment Bill has a clear requirement for all details of quota arrangements to be set out in the AMLC Corporate Plan which must have ministerial approval. These details must be available to all exporters.

Appropriate provisions are also included in the AMLC Bill to provide a right of appeal to the administrative appeals tribunal in respect of AMLC decisions regarding the period of validity of a quota and variations to quotas granted. The AMLC will also be required to publish details of all quotas sold or allocated in its annual report.This expansion of the AMLC's powers is in line with the Government's policy to encourage statutory marketing bodies to make the necessary commercial decisions to protect and foster the welfare of their respective industries.
I commend the Bill to the honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
COMMONWEALTH BANKS RESTRUCTURING BILL 1990

This Bill represents the completion of action by the Government which has resolved a developing crisis with the State Bank of Victoria. It will at the same time strengthen the Commonwealth Bank and enable it to develop further as a major national institution.

The Bill will create a new structure for the Commonwealth Bank as a public company, so that the additional capital it must have for the acquisition can be contributed by all Australians as joint shareholders with the Government. Grasping the opportunity to acquire the State Bank will secure the future of the Commonwealth Bank as a flourishing enterprise, and a central one in Australia's economy. The acquisition of the business of the State Bank will bring the Commonwealth Bank the substantial share of the banking market in Victoria which it has lacked until now, and will make it the largest Australian bank in terms of domestic assets.

The Commonwealth Bank will become for the first time in its history a major institutional force. The purchase of the State Bank will enable it to mount a competitive challenge which the other major banks will have their work cut out to meet. The great strength of the State Bank of Victoria is as a retail banking business.

For a time earlier this year the losses sustained in Tricontinental Holdings, its merchant bank subsidiary, and losses in the State Bank itself, threatened to overwhelm it. If the public had come to doubt the ability of the Victorian Government to deal with the enormous financial consequences of Tricontinental's losses, confidence in the State Bank would have been undermined. It is Australia's fifth largest bank with extensive liabilities overseas, and a loss of confidence in it would have threatened the very stability of Australia's financial system. This was a situation which the Commonwealth Government could not allow to occur. Fortunately the Victorian Government for its part faced up to its responsibilities, and decided that given its own budget position, the only fully adequate way to deal with the situation was to offer the State Bank for sale.
That decision does the Victorian Government credit.
It offers a sharp contrast to the circumstances of the Commonwealth Bank's acquisition of the Government Savings Bank of New South Wales in 1931, which are worth briefly recalling.

During 1930 a run on deposits in the Government Savings Bank had developed. It reached panic proportions in March and April of 1931, and culminated in the closing of the bank on 23 April 1931. Negotiations between the Commonwealth Bank and the NSW Government eventually led to the acquisition of the Government Savings Bank by the Commonwealth Bank, but not before great distress had been caused to the people of New South Wales.
The tragedy of it was described by J.T. Scullin in another place on 16 October 1931:

Had the serious position of the State Savings Bank been firmly grappled with a few weeks before the bank closed, the business could have been taken over by the Commonwealth Bank as a going concern without financial loss to the Government or people of New South Wales'.
In this case, the State Bank of Victoria is being taken over as a going concern, and a valuable one now that Tricontinental has been separated from it.

As part of the Commonwealth Bank it will continue to serve the people of Victoria. The Commonwealth Bank, after its due diligence review of the State Bank, signed on 8 November a contract to buy it for $1600 million. That price reflects the addition which will be made to the net earnings of the Commonwealth Bank when it has added and integrated the business of the State Bank.

The Bill will authorise the payment of an amount not exceeding $413 million as compensation to Victoria for the revenues forgone through the Victorian Government's sale of the State Bank and the tax losses it has agreed not to access after taking Tricontinental back into direct ownership.
The payment will be made in the near future, when an agreement is in place specifying the tax-related conditions and a mode of payment which involves debt redemption by the Victorian Government.

The other main purpose of the Bill is to restructure the Commonwealth Bank and convert it into a public company, in order to raise from the public the additional capital necessary to fund the Bank's acquisition of the State Bank of Victoria.
It is the value of the Commonwealth Bank as an institution, and the services which it provides to the community, which are paramount-and not whether it is exclusively Government owned.

The structure we are creating, with the Government as permanent majority shareholder and non-government shareholders as a substantial minority, will give the Commonwealth Bank access to additional capital while preserving its unique quality as a Government-owned major bank. The Commonwealth Bank as a Government-owned and Government-guaranteed bank has a vital place in our financial system. It represents an entirely secure place to deposit money, which is something that many customers throughout Australia value.

It represents a discipline on other banks in the kinds of credit risks they can assume, and so contributes to proper banking practice in the system as a whole. The Bank has established its track record as a commercial and profitable business under full Government ownership.

Under this Government the Commonwealth Bank has become more commercially oriented, more soundly managed, better equipped for the future, and more profitable. That strong record is a good basis from which the Commonwealth Bank's first offer of shares to the public can be launched.

The advent of non-government shareholders will not require the Government to become a passive shareholder and to disappear from the picture. The Government will be carrying the responsibility for the Government's guarantee of the liabilities of the Bank, which is not to be altered by this Bill.

The Government will also be carrying responsibility for the large investment of all citizens of the Commonwealth in the Bank, which will not have been diminished in any way by the issue of shares to additional shareholders.

The Government intends to know what policies are being followed by the Bank, and to see that it continues to be run wisely, efficiently and profitably. In this, the Government expects to be fully in accord with the Bank's other shareholders. With these continuing Government responsibilities in mind, the Bill will retain in the Commonwealth Banks Act a number of its existing provisions which help to define the Government's relationship with the Bank-in a few cases, with modifications to reflect the Bank's conversion to a public company.
Section 9, containing the Bank's``charter`` responsibilities to the people of Australia and the Australian economy, will remain.

Section 11, providing for an annual corporate plan to be prepared and given to the Treasurer, and containing a power for the Government ultimately to prevail in the circumstances of a formal difference of opinion, will remain.

A power will remain for the Treasurer to appoint the Secretary to the Treasury as a member of the Board of the Bank-which this Treasurer proposes to use. At the same time, the conversion of the Bank to a company and the issuing of shares to non-government shareholders will bring about other positive changes.

Firstly, with the conversion of the Commonwealth Bank to a share company there will be an opportunity for it to have an employee share ownership plan. The Government intends to see that there will be such a plan, established quickly, and integrated with the plan for the first issue of shares to the public.

Secondly, part of the restructuring of the Bank done through this Bill is a change in the legal status of the Commonwealth Development Bank. It has until now been a separate Bank under the same ownership, the same Board and the same Managing Director.

The Bill will make it a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Commonwealth Bank, in the same way as the Commonwealth Savings Bank has been for a long time. The Development Bank's special charter will remain unaltered under its new status. It will continue to act as a specialised lender to, and financier of, small business.

Thirdly, the issue of shares to the public will introduce a new kind of market scrutiny of the Bank's performance. The Government intends that the Bank will be able to have its shares listed by the Australian Stock Exchange, which will maximise the tradability of the shares, and will also focus analysis on the Bank's performance relative to other listed banks. This market attention and analysis can be expected to add a further discipline and stimulus for the Bank's Board and management.
I now wish briefly to describe the features of the share structure of the Commonwealth Bank for which the Bill specifically provides.
Foreigners will be prohibited from subscribing to the first public issue of shares in the Commonwealth Bank.

The aim of this restriction is to give priority to Australian residents in subscribing to shares in the Bank. However, foreigners will not be prevented from buying shares from subscribers and holding them thereafter. The wish of foreign persons to buy some of these shares in trading after the issue will add substantially to the effective demand for the shares, and hence to the prospects of success of the issue and to the market value of the new shares.

The proportion of voting shares to be held in aggregate by persons other than the Commonwealth will be limited to 30 per cent through the Commonwealth Banks Act. This will operate as a binding restriction on both the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth Bank.

As a separate matter, the Commonwealth will be prohibited from selling any of its shares in the Bank. Through amendments which this Bill makes to the Banks (Shareholdings) Act, interests in voting shares in the Commonwealth Bank will be limited.

Domestic and foreign banks will not be permitted to have any interest, directly or through associate relationships, except that banks or entities within banking groups will be permitted to hold voting shares as managers or trustees on behalf of other beneficial owners.

No person (apart from the Commonwealth) is to have an interest exceeding five per cent of the voting shares in the Commonwealth Bank. In conclusion, the changes being made through this Bill are historic.

We shall have created from the existing Commonwealth Bank and State Bank of Victoria a whole new force in banking, while protecting the State Bank's depositors and the wider community of Victoria and averting a financial calamity.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE CORPORATION (SALE OF ASSETS AND ABOLITION) BILL 1990

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1990 will provide legislative authority for the implementation of the Government's decision to sell the business of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (HLIC) and for certain staffing arrangements associated with the sale.
It will also provide for the abolition of the HLIC on a date to be proclaimed after the sale is completed.
The proposed sale of the HLIC business was included amongst a number of major asset sales announced in the 1989-90 Budget.

The Minister for Finance indicated on 30 October 1990 that the CIC Insurance Group has been identified as the preferred purchaser of elements of the HLIC business-and also as the proposed agent of the Commonwealth in carrying out the services required to be performed as a result of the consequential abolition of the HLIC.

Negotiations are currently under way with the CIC Insurance Group to finalise the detailed contract for that agency arrangement and to complete the sale of the HLIC business by 31 December 1990, if possible.
As indicated at the time the sale was announced, housing loan insurance is now widely available in Australia on a commercial basis.
In these circumstances, there is insufficient justification for retaining the HLIC in public ownership.
Essentially, the Government has better uses for the assets which the Commonwealth now has invested in the HLIC, particularly at the present time.
The HLIC was established in the public sector 25 years ago to meet a structural deficiency which existed in the highly-regulated finance environment of that time.
Its primary charter was to help low income earners with small deposits to obtain housing finance from institutions which tended to allocate their then scarce housing funds on a least risk basis.
Since the establishment of the HLIC, a competitive private sector mortgage insurance industry has developed in Australia.
Together with the finance industry reforms introduced by this Government, this has removed the old structural deficiency in the housing finance market.

Under the terms already agreed with the preferred purchaser, the CIC Insurance Group will continue the present mortgage insurance operations of the HLIC in a separately managed subsidiary, and will also act as agent for the Commonwealth in administering, under contract, the insurance obligations entered into by the HLIC before the sale comes into effect.
The CIC Insurance Group is Australia's fifth largest private general insurer.
It is jointly owned by the Norwich Insurance Group of the UK and the Winterthur Swiss Insurance Company, with a minority equity holding by the Chiyoda Insurance Company of Japan.

In its future mortgage insurance operations, the CIC Insurance Group will be required to satisfy the prudential and other requirements applied, under the Insurance Act 1973, to all private mortgage insurers by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC).

With its strong international backing, the CIC Insurance Group is expected to provide effective competition to the other existing private mortgage insurers, thereby helping to ensure that premiums are kept low.
The maintenance of competition in this industry, between firms operating on an equal footing, has been an important objective of the Government throughout this sale.
I am satisfied that the proposed sale arrangements will achieve that objective.

I would also draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the Bill explicitly continues for an indefinite period the Commonwealth guarantee on all insurance policies entered into by the HLIC prior to its abolition.

Under the proposed sale arrangements, the CIC Insurance Group will acquire the goodwill and physical assets of the HLIC and, having obtained a mortgage insurance licence from the ISC, will write new mortgage insurance policies on its own account in future.
The HLIC itself will be abolished after the sale is completed and its remaining assets and liabilities will then revert to the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth will contract with the CIC Insurance Group to manage, as its agent, the administration of the unexpired portion of all insurance obligations entered into by the HLIC prior to its abolition. Moneys will be set aside by the Commonwealth in a special account established by the CIC Insurance Group, and replenished as and when necessary, to meet claims against the pre-sale insurance obligations of the HLIC.

To help it continue the business, the CIC Insurance Group will employ the bulk of the present HLIC management and staff on terms which, overall, are comparable to those they now enjoy. The HLIC has a staff of over 50.
Equitable treatment of the present HLIC employees, and their continued welfare, has been a major consideration for the Government in developing the staffing arrangements associated with the sale.
The great majority of the present HLIC staff and management will be able to continue their careers in mortgage insurance on terms as good as or better than at present.

Those few to whom the CIC Insurance Group decides not to offer equivalent employment will be made redundant by the HLIC prior to the sale completion date and will receive all of the Award and other entitlements due to them in such circumstances.

Since those who accept equivalent employment with the CIC Insurance Group would otherwise lose some accumulated entitlements, the Commonwealth will contract with the CIC Insurance Group for the re-instatement of certain redundancy benefits and sick leave credits.
HLIC employees transferring to the CIC Insurance Group will also have additional superannuation benefit options, over and above those normally provided on resignation.
Those benefits are being made available by Regulation under the authority of the new, recently enacted, section 155B of the Superannuation Act 1976.

In cases like this, where there is, in practice, an opportunity for continuity of employment when a Commonwealth business is sold into the private sector, it would be inappropriate for the Government to make all employees eligible for large redundancy payments and the associated lump-sum superannuation benefits.
Accordingly, the Bill deems to have resigned those HLIC employees who reject an offer of equivalent employment from the CIC Insurance Group.
A similar provision was included in the legislation enacted to implement the staffing arrangements, developed in conjunction with the ACTU, for the sale of the Williamstown Naval Dockyard in 1987.
The Bill provides for the HLIC to be abolished on a date to be proclaimed after the sale is completed.

As part of these arrangements, a final report and detailed financial statements as at the date of sale will be prepared by the HLIC. After being audited by the Auditor-General's Office, they will be tabled in the Parliament in due course.
Under the arrangements provided for in the Bill, all of the residual assets and liabilities of the HLIC will be transferred to the Commonwealth.
These include both the outstanding insurance obligations of the HLIC and the investments underlying the provisions made by the HLIC to meet those obligations.

The overall return to the Commonwealth from the sale, and the associated abolition of the HLIC, is estimated to be around $80m in net present value terms-after allowing for the costs to be incurred in future in administering the continuing pre-sale obligations of the HLIC.
More than $100m is expected to be credited to Consolidated Revenue in the current financial year.
The bulk of the return to Consolidated Revenue will come from the realisation of the investments held by the HLIC to under-pin its provisions for future claims.
Independent actuarial analysis suggests that these provisions by the HLIC are significantly in excess of the level required to meet claims that can be expected to arise in normal circumstances.
The final outcome will, of course, depend on the actual level of claims made against the HLIC's existing insurance obligations.
To a large extent, this will be determined by the state of the Australian economy.

Any consideration of the down-side risk associated with the run down of the insurance policies in place prior to the HLIC's abolition needs to recognise that the Commonwealth is already exposed to that risk because of its statutory guarantee of the operations of the HLIC.
I conclude by pointing out to the Senate that the sale of the HLIC business is not the fire-sale of a failed operation-unlike some of the private sector asset sales we have seen recently.

Rather, it is the natural culmination of a successful public sector initiative which has met its original objective and, by so doing, has made it unnecessary for the Government to continue to be directly involved in this industry.
I commend the Bill to the honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
MINISTERS OF STATE AMENDMENT BILL 1990

Unless the Parliament provides otherwise, section 66 of the Constitution prescribes a maximum annual sum for the payment of salaries to Ministers. Amendments to the Ministers of State Act which sets this sum, are thus required from time to time to cover changes to ministerial salaries. The sum appropriated is to meet the cost of salaries and no more. While the Act covers the total cost of salaries it does not set the amount of individual salaries for Ministers.

Following the enactment of the Remuneration and Allowances Act 1990, it is necessary to amend the Ministers of State Act to increase the limit on the annual sum appropriated to cover the increase in salaries as provided for in the Remuneration and Allowances Act.

The effect of the Remuneration and Allowances Act was to alter the commencement of several increases for all parliamentarians with increases being phased over several stages. The Act also provided for linking the basic salary level for parliamentarians to the top of the senior executive service band one in the public service.

In its 1989 review the Remuneration Tribunal in report No. 2 of 1990, recommended substantial increases in salary for Ministers (increases for senators and members of this Parliament were also recommended in subsequent determinations).
The immediate increase proposed for Ministers was disallowed by the Government.

The Government had proposed in its submission to the Tribunal that in accordance with recent determinations for other groups in the Commonwealth sector, and consistent with the structural efficiency principle aim of simplification of salary structures, the Tribunal should incorporate expenses of office allowance for Ministers and parliamentary office holders into additional salaries.
The principle of incorporating Ministers expenses of office allowance into salary is consistent with the Government's policies.
The increases for senators and members were for 6 per cent from 1 July 1990, 6 per cent from 1 January 1991 and for approximately 5 per cent from 1 January 1992.

There is a similarly proportioned increase in the salaries of Ministers of State. That is Ministers' salaries are increasing in the same way that salaries of senators and members of the Parliament increase-that is from 6 per cent from 1 July 1990, by a further 6 per cent from January 1991, and by 4.8 per cent from July 1991.

For consistency to be maintained with wage and salary movements in the community at large the Government did not adopt the full range of increases determined by the Tribunal. The national wage guidelines are completely met by the proposals adopted by the Government. With respect to ministerial salaries an ongoing link is established, as Ministers are to receive the same percentage increase in additional salaries as members of the Parliament and phased in the same way.
Mr President, the costs are significantly less than would have been incurred had the Tribunal's determinations been implemented in full.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly on what is not a major issue. The reason I rise is that I have just come fresh into the chamber from watching the evening television news. TALK.START.PARA: —It is unnecessary to keep showing it.

We now have direct substantiation of the offence this is giving to the Muslim community in Australia, who no doubt transmit this offence to their friends and relatives in Iraq. SPEECH.PARA: All I am saying to the television news people is that we have seen this footage enough. I find it very annoying-I think that is a mild word for it-that when they run stories, as they did again tonight, about statements the hostages themselves have made about the problems this film is still causing for our fellow Australians in Iraq, the television news bulletins accompanying these stories continue to run the most offensive sections of this videotape. It adds nothing to the news story at all; it simply continues to give offence-and I understand why people are offended-to the Muslim community and obviously continues to exacerbate the very problem the news reader is commenting on while these sections are being shown.

I respectfully suggest to the television channels in this country that by all means they should continue quite properly to run these stories and continue to report the direct evidence we have from the returned hostages about the continuing problems this videotape is causing for our fellow Australians who are still, to the regret of us all, detained in Iraq, but they should stop continuing to screen in accompaniment to these stories the actual footage causing the offence. It may not be a major issue, but it might help a bit.
